Former Postmaster General James A. Farley said last night that if he had been nominated, he would have defeated Governor Rockefeller for Governor last Tuesday.

More than 200 works by Ameican, Israeli and French artists, as well as 40 Picasso ceramics will constitute the benefit art exhibition and sale of the women's division of the American Technion Society. The display will open at the St. Moritz with a supper reception Tuesday night in the hotel's Sky Gardens for patrons and invited guests.

The dazzingly individualistic talents of Larry Adler, the harmonica virtuoso, and Paul Draper, the dancer, are jointly on display here for the first time in 12 years. Their presence at the cavernous Village Gate is a show-business triumph perhaps even more significant than the reunion of Bert and Harry Piel.
BERLIN, Nov, 11 (AP) An East German border guard raided a West Berlin store, apparently in search of food, during the night, the West Berlin police reported today.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes asserted yesterday that the city should be as lenient as possible in enforcing parking bans until adequate offstreet space was available.

A top executive of Icelandic Airlines said yesterday that Scandinavian Airlines System, one of its chief rivals, made "an informal merger proposal" at talks between the two companies in Stockholm last month.

Architects to Fore Last week Doubleday published the last work of Frank Lloyd Wright, "Architecture: Man in Possession of His Earth," a history of architecture in terms of its basic materials stone, brick, wood, glass, steel and concrete.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 11 (UPI) President Kennedy chauffeured his wife and friends today to look over his new Virginia hunt-country estate.

The Phoenix Theater will function in two playhouses when it opens its 10th season on Jan. 18. It will continue to run the hit play, "Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' So Sad," at its home base on East 74th Street and will sponsor three revivals at the 1,700-seat Phyllis Anderson Theater, Second Avenue and Fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Chancellor Adenauer will visit President Kennedy this week for meetings that officials here consider far more important than they did when...

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 11 The marriage of Miss Evelyn Caplan, daughter of Israel Caplan and the late Mrs. Mary Praissman Caplan, to Dr. Robert B. Perch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Perch of Philadelphia, took place this afternoon. Rabbi Harry B. Kellman performed the ceremony in the Walt Whitman Hotel.

FRENCH opera must have friends, and many of them went to Carnegie Hall last night to support the first program of the Friends of French Opera, conducted by Robert Lawrence. The piece de resistance was the entire fourth act of Meyerbeer's "Les Huguenots," and by the time it was over a good portion of the audience was limp, thanks to Nicolai Gedda.
Opposing plans for the development of Breezy Point on the Rockaway Peninsula have split the Board of Estimate. One plan calls for a park and beach, the other for a private housing development.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Nov. 11 One man was missing and presumed drowned, and two men and a boy were rescued today after their motorboat struck a sandbar, broke up and sank in the mouth of Fire Island Inlet, west of Point Democrat.

Printers' negotiations for a new contract with the city's major newspapers have been scheduled to resume next Friday. The local union's leader contends an agreement ending a news and commercial employes' strike against The Daily News last Thursday was "far too short for acceptance by the typographers."

Events today: "Don Giovanni," Lorin Maazel, conductor; Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, William Steinberg, conductor, Claude Woolman, speaker, Walter Carringer, tenor, Paul Ukena, baritone, choruses of Carnegie Institute of Technology and Duquesne University, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
CAGUAS, P.R., Nov. 11 Roger Penske of Gladwyne, Pa., and his Zerex Special, with 2.7 Climax engine, ran away from the field today in winning the first Grand Prix of Puerto Rico.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP) A swept-wing RB-47 jet rose today from a runway at MacDill Air Force Base, then suddenly dipped its right wing and crashed in flames. The three crewmen were killed.
Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, last night urged the development of a profession of "counselor in ethics."

James V. Lowe made his New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The baritone has performed in Europe and has sung with with the New York City Opera Company, so his polished stage presence was no surprise.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) The unbeaten and untied Green Bay Packers, show-' ing a fine balance of running and passing, crushed the Phil-' adelphia Eagles today, 49 0. It was Green Bay's ninth straight victory of the National Football League season.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 11 Hofstra College today accepted a bid to play in the Cement Bowl in Allentown, Pa., on Dec. 8.

Mills College of Education at 66 Fifth Avenue has bought from Ellis P. Jones the eightstory University Residence Club at 45 West 11th Street to provide accommodations for expected increases in enrollment from the present 270 students to 500 or 600 in the next five years.

Elbert A. Gruver of Warwick, R.I., a stage manager for Leland Hayward, the producer, died yesterday in University Hospital. His age was 57. He was taken ill while on tour with the play "A Shot in the Dark."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Some industries have a double standard of pay under which men receive more money that women do for the same job, Government surveys showed today.
Ground was broken for a new $756,000 building for a Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association center in Little Neck, Queens, yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. President Kennedy's LaborManagement Advisory Committee meets here this week on an extra-curricular assignment.
The annual benefit dinner dance of the League for Cardiac Children will be held Saturday at the SheratonEast. Mrs. Milton Stark and Mrs. Robert R. Fagin are cochairmen of the event.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 11 Leonard B. Harris, naval architect and engineer, died here yesterday at the age of 85.

Defensive football seemed to be a lost art yesterday during a lively touchdown festival at the Polo Grounds in which the Dallas Texans outscored the New York Titans, 52-31. The 83-point total established a season high in the American Football League.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Announcement has been made by Mrs. Lillian K. Heyer of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Wetherby Heyer, to George Humphrey Gallup, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Westcott Gallup.

Organization of the Viking Fund, Inc., a private investment corporation to specialize in Scandinavian securities was announced yesterday by George J. Nelson, president. The fund's shares will not be sold to the public for the time being.
The inauguration of Dr. John H. Fischer a president of Teachers College, Columbia University, is a major event in the progress of teacher education.
Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at Local 400, Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, 550 Bergen Avenue, the Bronx.

The nation's voters approved 89.8 per cent of all bond proposals placed before them at last week's election. They approvd issues totaling $1,751,000,000 and defeated issues totaling $196,900,000 by the end of lest week, according to The Bond Buyer, a trade paper.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 12 The United Nations ordered today an immediate response by its fighter aircraft against any offensive operations by Katangese aircraft.
Bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange swelled yesterday in concert with the rise of volume in share trading.

TRAM, Vietnam, Nov. 6 A battalion of South Vietnamese regulars has found hidden deep in the jungle a village of some of the world's most primitive people. It was exactly what the battalion was looking for.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 Princeton University announced today that it had applied for $250,000 in Federal funds for student loans under the National Defense Education Act.

The obedient Football Giants, who eat Wheatena, smoke only filtered cigarettes, wash behind the ears and never take the field on Sundays with unshined football shoes, will be severely tested by their coach this week.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 (AP) The Russian national men's team defeated the United States A.A.U. All-Stars, 68-59, and the Soviet women beat Nashville Business College, the United States women's A.A.U. champions, 51-40, tonight.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 The State Board of Elections got off to a slow start today in its recount of votes in the neckand-neck race for Governor between John A. Notte Jr., the Democratic incumbent, and State Representative John H. Chafee.

TWO compulsive talkers have been belaboring each other with words for the better part of two months. It has been a lively exchange. However, the put-up-orshut-up stage is fast approaching for the venerable Archie Moore and the youthful Cassius Marcellus Clay. The heavyweights will collide on Thursday in Los Angeles, a match of singular attractiveness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Official here have been aware that Chinese Communist ambas sadors have been recalled to Peking for consultations.

WINCHESTER, Va., Nov. 12 (AP) Col. Daniel Lee Wright, U.S.A., retired, the last surviving member of the first Army Engineers contingent sent to build the Panama Canal, died on Saturday in Newton Baker Hospital near Martinsburg, W.Va. He was 78 years old and lived here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Admitting that somebody made a mistake, the Post Office today halted the sale of its new Dag Hammarskjold stamps while it tries to determine how many imperfect ones were printed and where they are.
BONN, Nov. 12-- Der Spiegel published today its second edition since the news magazine's publisher and four of his top aides were jailed. It sold like a collectors' item.
LONDON, Nov. 12 The Nyasaland Constitutional Conference opened here today with African leaders of the British protectorate seeking full internal self-government as the next step toward independence.
Mr. Hugh D. Auchincloss, the mother of Mrs. John F. Kennedy, said yesterday that the National Cultural Center in Washington would serve "an international function."
BOSTON, Nov. 12 Border towns in southern New Hampshire reaped another harvest of Massachusetts dollars today during the observance of Veterans Day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) It will take a new antimonopoly law to check the rapid decline in numbers of sales finance companies, officers of the American Finance Conference said today.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Lucius D. Clay will address the dinner meeting of the Economic Club of New York tonight.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 The "liquid lunch" is losing ground as a status symbol in Chicago.

BREWSTER, Kan., Nov. 12 (AP) Lud Strnad, prominent in the Kansas Farmers Union, charged today that the National Farmers Union was attempting to interfere in the election of a president of the Kansas organisation this week in Kansas City, Kan.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Premier Khrushchev has reported that tentative estimates show 144,693,000 tons of grain will be produced in the Soviet Union this year, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

EAST MEADOW, L.L., Nov. 12 Ben Benith scored four touchdowns on runs of 2, 2, 30 and 38 yards to lead the Clark High eleven to its seventh straight victory of the season, 40 13, today, against Farmingdale.
Administering the Agency for International Development, which has responsibility for the nation's huge foreign aid program, is one of the most demanding posts in government.
The co-winner of the 1962 Nobel Prize for chemistry delivered an impromptu lecture yesterday to 100 students at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was honored yesterday as "one of the greatest military leaders of all history."
ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) Experts from 25 nations began today a one-week study of how to use insecticides on foodstuffs of poison the pests without harming people.

The food consumer "never had it so good," Paul S. Willis, presidentof the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said yesterday at the opening of the group's 54th annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The newly independent nations may face critical internal problems unless the world community helps in the training of national leaders, Andrew W. Cordier, former United Nations Under Secretary, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) N.E. Halaby, administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, said today that European plans to develop a supersonic airliner might force the United States to speed up its own plans.

"I had the odd idea that streets are made for moving traffic and not for parking lots." The man who had this "odd idea" last March, three months after he took over as New York City's Traffic Commissioner, was Henry A. Barnes. We shared his odd idea and approved his stand, taken early in his regime, for stiff enforcement of the traffic laws.
Alabama won a close battle of the ballots from Southern California yesterday and took first place in The Associated Press's weekly college football poll.

LONDON, Nov. 12 Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan arrived in Britain today for a threeday official visit. On Wednesday he will attend the signing of a trade treaty between the two countries that is expected to open a new era in their economic relations.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) An international tennis competition for women, similar in many respects to the Davis Cup for men, will be held for the first time next year. The matches will be held at the Queen's Club June 17-20, the week preceding the Wimbledon competition.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 Britain accused South Africa today of "oppression" in South-West Africa through the deliberate denial of basic human rights to the people of the territory.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation, and the Skelly Oil Company announced yesterday plans for the construction of a 210-mile petroleum products line from Sinclair, Wyo., to Denver, Colo. The line will connect Sinclair's Wyoming refinery and Skelly's refinery in Denver.
BONN, Nov. 12 Chancellor Adenauer gave qualified approval today to the idea of an EastWest summit conference.
Emergencies have been shunted aside temporarily to permit the Living Theater to resume performances tonight of "Man Is Man."
Harvey Stack, a partner in the coin company that mounted the collection for the Truman Library, said in New York yesterday that it was the only one of its kind and "almost irreplaceable."

TORONTO, Nov. 12 (AP ) Capt. Hector Zatarain, riding Goliath, won the International Scurry Stakes tonight at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair Horse Show and moved Mexico into second place in the over-all international jumping standings.
Frank W. Mace, president of Lambert Feasley, Inc., advertising agency, died Sunday, after a long illness at his home, 251 Hillside Avenue, Douglaston, Queens. He was 56 years old.
PARIS, Nov. 12 More and more, it seems likely that the 1968 Olympic Games will be staged at Lyons (population 470,000) in central France.
ROME, Nov. 12 L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican City newspaper, said today that the acquittal verdicts at the van de Put trial in Belgium did not "cancel the moral guilt of the protagonists."
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 12 (AP) Officials resumed checking county totals today in the closest governorship race in Minnesota's 105 years.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 Hugh M. Pierce Sr., a retired mechanical and electrical engineer, died today of injuries suffered in a fall at his home on 350 Stratton Road. His age was 74.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 12 Supporters of Senator Joe Bottum prepared petitions today in an attempt to recapture the seat he apparently lost to George McGovern, Democrat, in Tuesday's vote.

A four-alarm fire fed by hair sprays and tonics swept a Harlem plant last evening and filled the area with heavy, aromatic smoke. Three adjoining tenements were evacuated and three firemen suffered minor injuries.

HONOLULU, Nov. 12 (AP)-- The death toll of typhoon Karen, the most disastrous on record to sweep across the western Pacific island of Guam, rose to six today. Damage was reported by an official as "well into the hundreds of millions of dollars."
ALBANY, Nov. 12 Work on the budget Governor Rockefeller will submit to the Legislature by next Feb. 1 moved into high gear today with the start of 13 days of a privates hearing.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UPI) The General Electric Company and the Home Entertainment Company of America, Inc., today announced that they had signed a contract for the development of equipment for a home pay-television system.

THE wife of a modern crusader has a tough, perplexing time. If she is devoted to the fellow, she must pick up the pieces of his broken lances. And if he is only a half-way warrior for his conservative or radical causes, her lot is hardly worth the clangor of his semi-rugged grandeur.
ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Nov. 12 A photo-mural of Camp Shanks, one of the largest military embarkation bases during World War II, was dedicated here today at the Orangetown Office Building.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 12 (AP) The United Nations administrator for West New Guinea said today that he would "stand strictly" by terms of the Indonesian-Netherlands agreement to let the Papuans decide their own political future in 1969. The agreement, signed in August, ended Dutch control of the area.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Nov. 12 The opening of the New York City Ballet last night in this ancient and handsome Ukrainian capital established two precedents on the company's tour of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Eldon Paul King, who retired in April as director of the International Tax Relations Division of the Internal Revenue Service, died today after an illness of several months. He was 69 years old.
OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 12-- County Circuit Judge W. M. O'Barr ordered the Lafayette County grand jury today to refuse evidence gathered by what he called "unlawful" Army searches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 President Kennedy met today with his chief planners and negotiators on the Cuban situation to review the Government's strategy for the removal from Cuba of weapons it considers offensive.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 12 (AP) Michigan State placed all five of its runners among the top 16 finishers today to win the Big Ten cross-country championship.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) Richard T. Gosser, an international vice president of the United Automobile Workers, was among three men charged tonight with conspiracy for allegedly attempting to take files from an Internal Revenue Service office, according to John J. Barone, United States Commissioner.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI) Dr. Harvey F. Smith, often credited with having discovered the famed pitcher Christy Mathewson, died in his home today at the age of 91.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry Fleck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Bonnie Fleck, to Jerome Edward Oppenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oppenberg. Both families are of the Bronx.
LONDON, Nov. 12 The International Chamber of Shipping rejected today a resolution by its United States members calling for a halt in trade with Cuba.
Steel production advanced last week for the third week in a row, achieving a new high point since early May.

A golfer of 300 years ago, two sumo wrestlers, a forgotten sculler named John Biglen, ancient and modern tennis players and a ballplayer just making it into base are among the athletes who stand, sweat and strain today at the I.B.M. Gallery.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 12 The Penrose Gold Medal, highest award bestowed in this country in the field of economic geology, was given today to Dr. Alan M. Bateman of New Haven, Conn., Silliman Professor Emeritus of Geology at Yale University. The presentation was made here by Dr. Olaf N. Rove, president of the donating group, the Society of Economic Geology.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) Jacob France, a lawyer and a banker active in state Republican politics, died today. His age was 80.

Mrs. James Reeves will be hostess at her home at 907 Fifth Avenue this afternoon at a reception in honor of the chairman and committee members planning the eighth annual International Debutante Ball. The event, which will benefit the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York, will be held at the Astor on Dec. 27.
The training program required under the reorganization of New York courts for justices of the peace who are not lawyers will begin this Friday.
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 12 (UPI) Hunters using bows and arrows took their usual big haul of deer yesterday at Holland Island, State game wardens reported.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) Auto assembly lines are humming at a faster clip this month than in any other this year but total production will not set a record.
WARSAW, Nov. 12 Communist China has recalled its ambassadors in Eastern Europe, presumably for consultations on the widening Soviet-Chinese rift, diplomatic sources said tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 12 Australian wool production in 1961-62 was a record 1,700 million pounds, according to official figures released in Canberra today. This is 20,000,000 pounds better than the previous highest figure in 1959-60.

All visible medium and intermediate range missile sites in Cuba have been demolished. Forty-two objects cradled in metal skins on the decks of outward-bound Soviet freighters have been counted and photographed by observers aboard American ships and planes. Premier Khrushchev has announced his missiles have been removed from Cuban soil.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Milk production, already at a surplus level, is expected to increase further next year.

BRITISH capabilities in the field of documentary-film reporting were absorbingly illustrated last night in an hour's summary of the global controversy over capital punishment. The program was seen over educational station WNDT on Channel 13.
BRIGHTON, England, Nov. 12 (AP) Three men were accused today of a long-term conspiracy to drug race horses.
HONG KONG, Nov. 12 Chinese Communist opposition to Soviet policy on Cuba found expression today in a Peking newspaper article attacking President Tito and Yugoslavia's Communist regime.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 12 A collection of rare coins was stolen early today from the Harry S. Truman Library.
ALTON, Ill., Nov. 12 (UPI) An Alton store woner and the state's attorney at Decatur, Ill., fought today twin drives by groups tying to end the sale of Communist-made goods.

A British-Canadian investment concern has acquired a substantial interest in the Savoy Hilton Hotel property at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street and will own the hotel jointly with Webb Knapp. The BritishCanadian interests are represented by the British Commercial Property Investments (Canada), Ltd., of Toronto.
The recent crisis over Cuba left its mark yesterday on observances of Veterans Day by Americans at home and abroad, in the armed forces and civilian life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A new and potentially far more accurate method for tracking satellites will be tried out early next year. A narrow beam of red light will be used to illuminate a satellite 600 miles from the earth.
BROCKVILLE, Ont., Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) John C. Udd, hotel executive and industrialist, died today at his estate near here. He was 61 years old.
The Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York began a campaign for $14,247,000 last night to build new structures, remodel its old buildings and expand its programs throughout the city.
Governor Rockefeller and Newsweek magazine were in disagreement yeaterday as to what the Governor had said about his Presidential chances.
Tom Stith will play in his first National Basketball Association game for the New York Knickerbockers tonight at Madison Square Garden.
CAIRO, Nov. 12 (AP) A pilot introduced as the commander in chief of the Jordanian Air Force defected to the United Arab Rapublic today in a military transport plane.
OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 12 (UPI) The Army released today a list of items found in the University of Mississippi's Lester and Baxter Halls during a search conducted recently by troops.

The International Salt Company announced yesterday it had set the price of its highway rock salt at $6.40 a ton, f.o.b. its three Northern mines. The price in some areas will now be as much as $1 higher than quoted during the past bidding season. The company's mines, include those at Retsof, N.Y., Detroit, and Cleveland.
Jerome Weidman, the author of "I Can Get It for You Wholesale" and other novels, will write television scripts for the Columbia Broadcasting System. This is his first commitment in television.
The relative merits of improvised and prepared material for topical shows were discussed here yesterday by three performers appearing in Broadway and Off Broadway productions.
The main event of the wrestling program at Madison Square Garden ended last night with both participants outside the ring.

WESTPORT, Conn., Tuesday Nov. 13 A 50-year-old woman was strangled in a bedroom of her house here yesterday, and her 14-year-old daughter was kidnapped and held for 12 hours the police said early today.
Penn State tops the list of football teams under consideration for the Gotham Bowl game Dec. 15 at Yankee Stadium.
IN a discussion of the London version of "Brecht on Brecht," Kenneth Tynan, The Observer's drama soothsayer, says that George Tabori's program of Brecht's writings ignores his Communism.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes disclosed yesterday that he would meet next week with officials of the Transit Authority to discuss express bus service on expressways.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 12 Frank F. Navarro, a 32-year-old former star lineman at Maryland, was appointed head coach today of the Williams football team. Navarro will replace Len Watters, who will retire next June after having coached the Ephmen for fifteen years.
NEWARK, Nov. 12, (AP) The Tristate Transportation Committee announced today it was making a study of transportation habits in the Connecticut-New York-New Jersey area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Administration is working on a step-by-step approach to the tax reduction and reform that it is committed to propose next year.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman urged dairy industry groups today to resolve differences over a national dairy program or face the threat of loss of Government assistance.
LONDON, Nov. 12 Owen Lattimore has been appointed director of Chinese studies at Leeds University, it was announced today.
Dr. Alberto Rembao, the editor since 1931 of La Nueva Democracia, a Spanish-language quarterly, died of a stroke Saturday in his home at 90 La Salle Street. He was 67 years old.

Nat E. Holman, vice president and general manager of D. Kaltman Co., wholesale druggists, of 425 Park Avenue died Saturday night of a heart attack in Las Vegas, Nev. He lived at 205 East 63rd Street. His age was 47.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today the establishment of a securitycompliance directorate with company-wide responsibility.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 Venezuela laid claim today to a large part of British Guiana.
GENEVA, Nov. 12 The World Council of Churches has sent a message of "profound sympathy" to Indian Christian leaders "at this critical hour for the life and spirit of India."
Democratic Congressional candidates outpolled their Republican opponents in the New York election, 2,737,821 votes to 2,647,205.

HAVANA, Nov. 12 (AP) Anastas I. Mikoyan's activities in Cuba were not mentioned today in the Havana press for the third consecutive day. This fanned rumors that his negotiations with the Cuban Govern ment were not making much headway. Mr. Mikoyan is a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union.
GENEVA, Nov. 12 Canada announced today she would withdraw from the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration at the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A basic intra-Governmental conflict over whether international law, treaties and the needs of national defense shall have legal primacy over the national labor statutes as interpreted by the National Labor Relations Board and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is reflected in a brief filed before the Supreme Court last week by the Department of Justice. This conflict accounts for the urgent request made in the brief.

Wall Street's Black Monday on May 28, when the value of stocks dropped off by $20,800,000,000, is still having its Broadway repercussions six months later, Two dramas enveloped with historical significance, "The Moon Besieged" and "The Advocate," have encountered difficulties.
WHY are sprouts, depite their close ties with British cui sine, always attributed to Brussels? The answer probably lies in the flat but fertile land immediately northeast of the Belgian capital.
The New York Mets will start their second year in the National League at the new Flushing Meadow stadium on April 9 against the St. Louis Cardinals, the club said yesterday.

Stockholders of the Albemarle Paper Manufacturing Company, at a special meeting in Richmond, Va., approved yesterday the paper company's ambitious plan to raise $200,000,000 to purchase the Ethyl Corporation.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12-- Gilberto Figueroa Norgueron, a publisher and managing director of the morning newspaper Excelsior, died of a heart attack this afternoon. His age was 59.
GARDINER, Me., Nov. 12 (AP) Bleachers holding nearly 2,000 persons collapsed today during a Gardiner-Augusta high school football game, injuring scores of spectators.

A champagne preview tomorrow at the Wildenstein Galleries will herald the opening of "The Painter as Historian," a new exhibition of five centuries of French painting in the realm of mythological, religious and secular subjects.

The funds of Polish Mutual Assistance, Inc., an organization dedicated to giving aid to Poles who have been forced to flee their country, will be increased by the proceeds of the seventh annual Polonaise Ball.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 12 Hofstra College will be without the services of its firststring quarterback, Len Garille, for at least two more weeks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) All grain futures except rye and December wheat advanced in quiet dealings today on the Board of Trade.
Events tonight: "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Jose Iturbi, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; National Orchestral

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The commander of the United States Marine reinforcements flown in here at the start of the crisis over Cuba told today how he had investigated
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) European steel producers are putting the squeeze on American steel exports and it may get worse, a steel executive, said tonight.

George Gallantz, New York attorney for Paul Pender, said yesterday he would file suit next week against the New York State Athletic Commission to force the restoration of Pender's share of the world middleweight crown.

THE snip of scissors in many New York barbershops signals the transformation of more and more boys into likenesses of Prince Charles. And as the boys are acquiring their eyebrow-deep bangs, their little sisters are emulating Caroline Kennedy by sweeping their bangs to one side and fastening them with bows or barettes.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said tonight he had urged Chancellor Adenauer to commit West Germany fully to the defense of West Berlin.

LAUREL, Md., NOV. 12 Match II of France won the $125,000 Washington D.C. International today, but the real hero of the race was his rider. Yves Saint-Martin, a 21-yearold jockey from the southwest of France, gave an exhibition of persistence and daring that evoked comparison with the best riders of this country.
With the help of a computer, Harold Clayton, an analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Co., brokerage house, regularly keeps score of most of the common stocks listed on the Big Board.
Controller Arthur Levitt suggested yesterday that the term of the State Controller be lengthened to 14 years to insulate the office from partisan pressures.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP) The new syndicate taking over the Cleveland Indians baseball club will be composed mainly of Clevelanders, William R. Daley, the club president, revealed today.
DALLAS, Nov. 12 (AP) A second psychiatrist has examined former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker and left Dallas, Mr. Walker's attorneys said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) A Presidential emer gency board recommended today that the Railway Express Agency and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters negotiate a new wage contract providing increases of 10.28 cents an hour, retroactive to July 1.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday expansion and realignment of its cargo sales department.

The work of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society will receive support from a theater party at the performance next Tuesday of "Lord Pengo," the night after the play opens at the Royale Theater with Charles Boyer starring.
ALGIERS, Nov. 12 Premier Ahmed Ben Bella returned today from a three-day tour of poverty-stricken eastern Algeria. He was received on his trip in friendly, sometimes wildly enthusiastic fashion.
LONDON, Nov. 12 Prime Minister Macmillan declared tonight that a "good start" toward disarmament could be made by an agreement to ban nuclear weapons tests.
Michael Brown, the chief attraction of a mixed bill at the Blue Angel, is a polished, urbane, 41-year-old singer-composer who bears a fleeting resemblance to the late Leslie Howard.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 A credit union set up to aid tenants in a public housing project began operations today. The credit union is the only one in operation in a project and one of the first Chicago Housing Authority of its kind in the nation.
Former President Harry S. Truman agreed yesterday with former Postmaster General James A. Farley that Mr. Farley could have defeated Governor Rockefeller this year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) An underground network of blast-resistant cable is being installed to keep the nation's telephones operating in the event of nuclear attack.

IF hair spray is to be handy, it should be out in the open where it can be easily reached. A spray can, however, rarely adds glamour to a bathroom or dressing table. Johns Manville Corporation expects 1963 sales to total about the same as the estimated $395,000,000 of 1962, Clinton B. Burnett, president, said here yesterday. Sales in 1961 amounted to $378,000,000.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 12 (AP) Oscar W. Underwood Jr., a retired law professor at the University of Virginia, died here yesterday at his home. He was 72 Years old.

ALTHOUGH the defense was misplayed and the contract should have gone down three, this deal is worth reporting because a useful, but relatively rare, play occurred not once but twice in it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Daniel G. Aldrich Jr., Dean of the University of California's division of agricultural sciences, said today that this country was now experiencing the third of three great migrations affecting agriculture.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 12 High-ranking Indian sources denied today rumors that their contingents with the United Nations forces in the Congo would be recalled to India soon to help fight the Chinese.

Announcement has been made of the marriage here last Wednesday of Mrs. Margot Morris Buckley to Alexander Byers Slater. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Morris of New York and her husband is the son of Mrs. Lyon Slater of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and Nelson Slater of San Remo, Italy.
IN his career, George Crews McGhee, now Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, has been an oil prospector in Texas and a Doctor of Philosophy at Oxford.

After a 14-year hiatus Congress has finally approved funds for the often-postponed Census of Transportation. The project will begin early next year.

When Frank Rienzo became coach at Archbishop Molloy High seven years ago he set a three-point objective for the school's track team. Yesterday, Point 2 was achieved when his boys won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, with 94 points.
Cotton futures rose 5 cents a bale to $1.85 yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Despite direct intervention by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, the nation's two leading amateur sports organizations made little progress yesterday toward settling the differences between them that could seriously reduce the United States' Olympic might.

Before this musical season ends, some 300 hopeful young American performers will have gambled huge chunks of their personal savings and their peace of mind on the harrowing but necessary undertaking known as the New York debut.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 12 Republican leaders of the Ilinois Legislature decided today to deny Gov. Otto Kerner's request for shortrun use of gasoline tax funds to meet increased public assistance needs.

The discovery of a pool of gasoline about five inches deep on the tracks caused subway service to be suspended for about four hours yesterday at three stations at the end of the IRT Flatbush Avenue line in Brooklyn.
North American Aviation, Inc., had record revenues and earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

There was considerable evidence yesterday at the opening of the forty-seventh annual National Hotel Exposition at the New York Coliseum that the boom in the nation's hotel and motel construction this year would result in record orders at the show.
Senator Barry Goldwater said here last night that President Kennedy should oust Adlai E. Stevenson and three other top officials from his Administration.

Reductions in freight rates of from 17 to 20 per cent for coal shipped in solid trainloads from northern West Virginia and Pennsylvania to electric generating stations in the New York harbor area have been proposed by four Eastern railroads.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 A number of delegates said today that there was little prospect that the International Red Cross check-up of ships bound for Cuba would ever be carried out.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy sharply criticized Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday for calling for leniency in enforcing parking rules.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 (AP) At least a dozen New York colleges believe the state should increase the maximum payment to students under the Regents' scholarship and scholar incentive programs, the Education Department reported today.

BONN, Nov. 12 Thirteen former Nazi storm troopers and security police officers went on trial today on charges that they had murdered or abetted the murder of 170,000 Jews in the concentration camp of Chelmno in Poland.
Four business experts will discuss "Social Change: The American Economy" at 8 P.M. Thursday at the Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

The New York commodities markets were generally quiet yesterday in a semi-holiday trading atmosphere. Over-all operations were slowed somewhat by the bank holiday and the fact that a number of markets wool, coffee, sugar and cocoa were closed.

In 1948 Colonel Wright told how teams under his command reduced Greece's annual malaria cases from 1,000,000 to 50,000. The campaign began under the auspices of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitattion Administration soon after the liberation of Greece in World War II, and was continued, still under his leadership, by the World Health Organization.

THE third annual "Les Boutiques de Noel," a five-day Christmas sale to benefit several charities, opens today. And, as in the past, hundreds of volunteers have been busily transforming a New York town house into a charming shopping center for the occasion. This year the site is a six-story Gothic mansion at 46 East 70th Street.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 The head of the Federal Housing Administration characterized the current market for homes as a "guyer's market" today.
NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 12 The pro-American Liberal Democratic party won 17 seats, a majority, yesterday in the 29seat Ryukyus Legislature.
Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, president of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, has been awarded the sixteenth annual John H. Finley Medal of City College, the college announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 12 The Screen Actors Guild will not ask for wage increases in its next contract negotiations with producers in order to stimulate production of movies in Hollywood. The present contract expires on Jan. 31 of next year.

Someone forgot to open or close several window blinds at 6 P.M. yesterday at the Equitable Society building at 51st Street and the Avenue of the Americas. As a result, attempts to publicize the closing days for enrollment in a nonprofit New York health plan went awry.
A 9-year-old girl visited her birthplace yesterday for the first time since she had debarked from it.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (AP)-- Prince Philip of England arrived tonight to address a Wednesday session of the English-speaking Union's world branches conference here.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 The cornerstone for Nassau's six-story county office building has been found not in its proper position at the corner of the building but in the basement.

ROME, Nov. 12 Premier Amintore Fanfani's Government received a new lease on life today when the national council of the dominant Christian Democratic party voted its confidence in the Government and authorized it to discuss a political agreement with the Leftwing Socialist party.

A taxi driver spotted two men with guns running from the West Harlem Pork Center at 2302 12th Avenue, near West 131st Street yesterday, and when they jumped into a car, he followed them to 92d Street, where the cab driver hailed a policeman and had the two men arrested.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12 (UPI) A record price for a weanling colt in the Keeneland; Sales was set tonight as 91 head of thoroughbred breeding stock sold for $1,082,300.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Several Republican leaders have emerged from the elections with a strong feeling that the party needs more professionalism from top to bottom.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12 (AP) State Representative Wellborn Jack of Shreveport predicted tonight that James H. Meredith, Negro student at the University of Mississippi, would be killed.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) Charles W. Engelhard's Nassau Hall scored a 1 -length victory in the $29,175 Jersey Shore Stakes at Garden State Park today before a crowd of 19,320.

New Federal tax law affecting income from foreign business operations was termed a "welter of confusion" yesterday at an American Management Association seminar in the Astor Hotel.

The prospective purchasers of the New York Titans are residents of the metropolitan area, Commissioner Joe Foss of the American Football League said yesterday. Foss said he knew of no plans to move the franchise to another city.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Nov. 12 Miss Charlotte Dallas O'Neil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward O'Neil, and Otis Morgan Oliver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wood Oliver of Fox Chapel, plan to be married in January.

The greatest hazard facing college educated women is that they will find it necessary to abandon their intellectual talents, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, said yesterday in her final President's Report at Barnard College.

New York's formula for distributing seats in the Legislature was attacked by Radio Station WMCA yesterday as a device that had insured Republican control of the state despite Repubhican failure to get a majority of votes.

DETROIT, Nov. 12-- Walt W. Rostow, said today that the Soviet Union faced a solemn decision whether to accept the principle of international arms inspection or to go another round in the cold war tensions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today approval of an $86,000 contract with Robert R. Nathan Associates, Inc., of Washington, for a study aimed at expanding coal exports.

IF you find the mystical subject of Zen Buddhism ob scure, you will not be enlightened by Rolf Forsberg's bill of two short plays titled "A Tenth of an Inch Makes the Difference," which opened last night at the East End Theater.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 A study of teen-agers has disclosed that the state's alcohol law has not prevented children under 18 from drinking.
PARIS, Nov. 12 Gen. Lauris Norstad, Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, said today that his forces were critically short in a number of ways and that the deficiencies were serious.

PARIS, Nov. 12 The administrative head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization pleaded today for funds to meet the "dizzying needs" of the world's developing countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The states collected $5,500,000,000 from motorists in 1961 and spent $4,800,000,000 for construction, maintenance and administration of highways and streets.

PARIS, Nov. 12 A spokesman for the French Socialist party said today the party would throw its votes to Communist candidates in the second round of the elections, to defeat the Gaullists. The twostage elections will be next Sunday and Nov. 25.
PARIS, Nov. 12 Economic growth in the European Economic Community, even under favorable conditions, will not be as rapid in this decade as in the last, a new expert study has concluded.
Four-foreign visitors who had won two-week tours of the United States in an essay contest said yesterday they had found Americans a friendly people.

John P. Nicholson, an art dealer who had a gallery bearing his name at 38 East 57th Street, died Saturday in a residence and gallery he also maintained in London. He was 61 years old. His New York home at 444 Central Park West.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) The chairman of the Ameri can Petroleum Institute said today a new law to free natural gas producers from Federal price controls is imperative.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Senate Internal Security subcommittee published today a collection of articles describing how the Communists subverted and took over the free press in Soviet satellites.

Raymond R. Corbett, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., announced yesterday that he had sent telegrams to Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner announcing his organization's opposition to the redevelopment of Breezy Point, on the Rockaway Peninsula, as a waterfront recreation area.
Brooklyn Tech, the Public Schools Athletic League defending football champion, ran its victory streak to 16 games yesterday with a 30 8 victory over Lafayette. The game was played at Boys High Field.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Endicott Peabody gained 1,323 additional votes in Boston today after an official tabulation of all but one ward in Tuesday's gubernatorial election.

LONDON, Nov. 12 Many buyers returned to the stock market today, and industrial share prices responded with many modest gains.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 The virgin lands of Kazakhstan, one of the Soviet Union's key graingrowing areas, have failed for the fourth consecutive year to fulfill the Grain delivery plan.

The United Federation of Teachers has asked that the city's 40,000 teachers be given raises ranging from $700 to $3,555 a year.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 Howard P. Homans, former senior partner of Homans Co., an investment firm in New York, died yesterday in his home at 33 Lafayette Road. He was 83 years old.

Mrs. Ethel Ebin of Forest Hills, Queens, and Herbert Ebin of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Hildreth Ebin, to Dr. Roland Gilbert Kallen. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Kallen of Newark.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12-- Pressure mounted today for Alvaro C. Alsogaray, Argentina's Minister of the Economy, to change his policy or to resign.

SEATTLE, Nov. 12 Basic disagreement between the United States and Japan over the provisions of the nine-year-old North Pacific Fisihng Treaty was exposed here today.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Nov. 12 Soviet submarines operated in the region of the Guantanamo naval basse during the peak of the crisis over Cuba and some were-forced to surface by United States patrol aircraft and ships stationed here.

AMARILLO, Tex., Nov. 12 (UPI) The state will not attempt to bring Billie Sol Estes to trial on antitrust charges until it is determined whether the president of Commercial Solvents Corporation of New York will be brought to Texas to face the same charges, District Attorney Frank Baughman said today.
The Hunts Point section of the Bronx and the Jersey Meadows in Hudson County provide almost equally suitable facilities for a new wholesale meat and poultry market, a Federal survey has found.

Herbert G. Klein, press secretary to former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, said yesterday that an American Broadcasting Company program about Mr. Nixon shown Sunday night attempted to "distort the life of a great American."

UTICA, N.Y., Nov., 12 Thomas C. O'Donnell, an author and a retired editor, died yesterday in the Masonic Home here. He was 81 years old and had lived in Winter Park, Fla. He formerly lived in New York and Boonville, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A dispute between George Meany and Walter P. Reuther that had threatened to split the A.F.L.C.I.O. was patched up today.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 12-- Military sources here said today that they thought Imam Mohamad al-Badr's guerrilla forces had a good chance to regain control of Yemen.

BRANT BEACH, N.J., Nov. 12 Duck hunters will go anywhere, do anything, suffer any adversity. Their perseverance puts them at the top of the heap of hunting types. Anyone who disputes this obviously is not a duck hunter and therefore is ineligible to argue.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 James Barrington of Burma urged the Soviet Union and the United States to keep the nuclear arms race from being extended into space.
Edward Field, a 38-year-old resident of New York, has been named winner of the 1962 Lamont Poetry Selection for his first volume of poems, "Stand Up, Friend, With Me."
A series of 14 Japanese films will be presented on double bills at the Hollis Repertory Cinema in Queens for two

ALBANY, Nov. 12 Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney said today that the approval of Amendment 4 on the ballot last week constituted a public endorsement of the present method for apportioning seats in the Legislature.

H. Allen Jerkens, who does the horse trading as well as the horse training for David Shaer, a Newton, Mass., shoe manufacturer, solidified his reputation yesterday as a shrewd appraiser oF thoroughbreds.
Lectures, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, 11 A.M. "Survey: Etruscan Art," Blanche R. Brown; 11:30 A.M. "Portraits in Painting," Angela C. Bowlin.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 12 Babe Culnan, a well-known boxing and wrestling promoter for forty years, died last night of a heart ailment at his home, 38 Overlook Avenue. He was 65 years old.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12-- A Federal district judge said today that he had never read a newspaper account of an incident with which he was familiar and found it a reasonable report.
ROME, Nov. 12 The second session of the Ecumenical Council will begin May 12 and continue for seven weeks ending June 29.
The United States Court of Appeals criticized mass criminal-conspiracy trials yesterday and recommended that the number of defendants tried at one time be restricted.
Thomas Hunt Barber, a retired investment banker and author, died Sunday in his home at 1170 Fifth Avenue. He was 73 years old.
KINNELON, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) The body of a 79-yearold woman doctor missing for a month was found today by two youths hunting in a heavily wooded area near Boonton Reservoir in Morris County.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) Robert Welch, the founder of the John Birch Society, charged last night that American naivete is helping Communism gain support in this country.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 Thousands of Russians are going about their tasks with the blood of deceased fellow citizens coursing through their veins.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 12 Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, said today the way to improved farm inocme was a dual-price system.

Directors of the American Hardware Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 40 cents plus an extra of 15 cents on the common stock. They are payable Dec. 28 to holders of record Dec. 7. The company paid 35 cents in previous quarters, and total divi dends for 1962 are $1.60.
The Newspaper Guild of New York, which settled an eightday strike against The Daily News last Thursday night, scheduled new negotiations yesterday with other major newspapers to start today.
Stock prices surged upward in surprisingly heavy trading yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (UPI) The president of United Air Lines today accused unions of failing to "inspire members to advance and fulfill themselves as human beings."

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 12 High level negotiations are in progress over the fate of the biggest industrial project ever considered in New Zealand. This is a $300,000,000 plan for an aluminum smelter using the abundant cheap electricity available from high country lakes in the South Island.

The annual Lighthouse Gala dinner dance was held last night in a setting of gold and white brocade in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. It was preceded by a cocktail hour in the Terrace Room, where guests bought contributed gift certificates for designer gowns at a Carousel Boutique.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 13 --The Plainfield Symphony will open its 10th season of young people's concerts at 3 P.M. Sunday in the South Plainfield High School under the direction of Samuel Carmell.

A pointless new dissipation of labor's energies on internal warfare has been averted by the apparent patching up of the feud between George Meany and Walter P. Reuther. Even though the two strong men of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are too explosively different in personality to encourage hope of a future totally devoid of friction, they have wisely decided to join hands in new organizing efforts instead of tearing the federation apart in a sterile power duel.
The election of Julius K. Nyerere as the first President of Tanganyika, which is to become a republic next month, restores him to his proper status among the important leaders of Africa.

Southern California, one of the nation's four unbeaten and untied major powers, replaced Northwestern as the No. 1 team yesterday in the United Press International's major college football ratings by a board of coaches.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 13 (UPI)--The president-elect of the American Medical Association said today that last week's election did not change the lineup in Congress against medical care for the aged. He predicted that the Administration-backed bill would be killed again in the next session.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UPI)-- Federal Judge Julius H. Miner postponed today until Jan. 16 start of a libel trial involving Krebiozen, the controversial cancer drug.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 13-- Yale comes up to its Big Three games against Princeton and Harvard with a record lacking in distinction.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 13 (AP)--The police have issued pick-up orders for four men in the theft of a valuable coin collects on from the Harry S. Truman Library.
TORONTO, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Mexican Equestrian Team moved within 2 points of the first-place United States Team tonight at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair Horse Show.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Nov. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Norman Olsen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jan Stuart Olsen, to William W. Garretson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Garretson of Scarsdale. A wedding in January is planned.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 14 (AP)--All 26 persons aboard a South Vietnamese commercial airliner that crashed Saturday were found dead today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--On paper, the new Senate looks more liberal than the old one. But the first new Democrats to reach the Capitol lost no time today in declaring their independence.
GENEVA, Nov. 13--For the first time in the negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear testing the Soviet Union raised today the possibility of, using robots to detect underground explosions.
Mayor Wagner strongly hinted yesterday that the city would have to impose new or increased special taxes to have a balanced and reasonable expense budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
GENEVA, Nov. 13--Yugoslavia and the United Arab Republic were accepted today as provisional members of the 44-country General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP)-- Governor Rockefeller's office said today he had signed extradition papers clearing the way for Texas authorities to return Maynard Wheeler to that state to stand trial on anti-trust charges stemming from the Billie Sol Estes case.

COBLENZ, Germany, Nov. 13 (UPI)--A witness testifying in Germany's biggest war crimes trial since the Nuremburg cases, said today that Nazi S.S. (elite guard) troops lashed children with whips to separate them from their parents before the children were shot.

Medical Aid to Cuba reported yesterday that 50 persons, acting as individuals, had signed a telegram to the House Committee on Un-American Activities protesting subpoenas to its chairman, Mrs. Melitta del Villar, and its treasurer, Sidney J. Gluck.
The price of gold in London often reflects the heat of world crises.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13--Experts here on Chinese Communist affairs believe the Peking Government is making a desperate effort to persuade Premier Khrushchev to abandon his policy of "peaceful coexistence" with the West.
Two quarterbacks, Gary Wood of Cornell and Archie Roberts of Columbia, have set records in the Ivy League.

The president of the Sentinel Investigation Service, Inc., spent last night in jail for lack of $100,000 bail after surrendering on an indictment charging grand larceny, fraud, forgery and conspiracy in supplying watchmen for state construction jobs here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13-- The State Supreme Court today unanimously rejected an appeal by eight major motionpicture film distributors seeking repayment of $4,637,258 in taxes paid over a 39-year, period under the outlawed Movie Censorship Act.
TRENTON, Nov. 13--Gov. Richard J. Hughes criticized today the interim report on teen-age drinking made public yesterday by State Senator John J. Marchi of New York.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 14 --The police intensified their search here today for the strangler of a 50-year-old housewife.
Cyrus S. Jullien, a lawyer and president of the Finger Lakes Race Track in Canandaigua, N.Y., died here yesterday at his home, 1111 Park Avenue. His age was 79.
The disputing parties in the waterfront labor stalemate have completed the presentation of their demands and offers in a series of joint sessions under Federal mediation auspices.
WARSAW, Nov, 13--Poland's League of Soldiers' Friends, a Propaganda organization with a membership of 1,000,000, became today what appears to be the nucleus of a territorial army.

To a passing motorist the steel skeleton of the new stadium, now rising on the flats of Flushing Meadow, still looks pretty drafty despite stout assurances it will be ready for the National League's 1963 baseball season opening on April 9.
Christmas will be a little more glittering in New York this year. The circus, usually a spring event, is coming to town.

George L. Bagby, chairman of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, 501 Fifth Avenue, which has given concerts here for many years, died last evening in St. Joseph's Hospital, Lexington, Ky. He was 82 years old.
A kind of "latent McCarthyism" poses a constant threat to constitutional democracy in this country, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins said yesterday.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Nov. 13--James Russell Colean of 300 Broadway, a senior partner in the architectural firm of Kiff, Colean, Voss Souder at 230 Park Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack yesterday in Dobbs Ferry Hospital. He was 71 years old.

THE gift of storytelling can often be passed down though several generations of a family. Lesley Frost, poet and author of stories for children, attributes her talent to her father, Robert Frost, and to her Scottish grandmother, Isabelle Moodie Frost, who also wrote stories for children.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)-- The directors of United Fruit Company declared an extra dividend today of 10 cents a share on the common stock payable Dec. 14 to holders of record Nov. 23. This brings the total for 1962 to 60 cents compared with 50 cents in 1961 when no extra was paid.
WHY did they come, the emigrants who for some 350 years left Europe and everything they knew for the un known perils and golden hopes of life in America?

A jury verdict holding both the city and a realty company liable for damages in the deaths of six firemen who were trapped in a Bronx fire six years ago was set aside yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon.

A 15-year-old senior transferred from a Queens high school yesterday after having been ordered to stop wearing a pacifist arm band in classes. The girl, Tedi Farber, of 19615 73d Avenue, Fresh Meadow, Queens, said she intended to continue her education in Syosset, L.I., and live with relatives there.
Despite the inroads of private brands, seven out of every ten purchases of packaged food and household products continue to be of major advertised brands.

Giulietta Simionato returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night after a season's absence, reaffirming her stature as a majo rartist. The Italian mezzosoprano appeared in "Cavalleria Rusticana," as Santuzza, a role she has sung with the company, and once again she created an impressive characterization through her acting and brilliant singing.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 13 --A new technique for treating certain birth defects before the afflicted infants are born was described by University of Michigan medical researchers here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 13--Carman Canastra, North Brunswick police chief, was fined $300 today on a contempt of court charge stemming from an investigation of the fixing of traffic tickets in his department.

THE young instrumentalists of the National Orches tral Association, who have been rehearsing since Oct. 5, gave their first public concert of the season last night. It was at Carnegie Hall, and they were led by John Barnett, who is in his fifth season as the association's director, trainer and conductor.
The Circle in the Square is going ahead with its revival of Eugene O'Neill's "Desire Under the Elms" despite the withdrawal of Franchot Tone.
WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 13--There are still wild, tangled forests left in the state. The north side of Whiteface Mountain is one of them.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 13-- Kenya's main African nationalist party threatened today to withdraw from the Government unless Britain speeded up the timetable for the colony's independence.
QUEBEC, Nov. 13--The people of Quebec go to the polls tomorrow to decide a crucial question for Canada's largest province.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (UPI)--The United States has orbited a satellite so small it could be held in one hand. The device will map radiation resuiting from recently stepped up atomic tests.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 13-- The Bulgarian Communist party congress completed most of its work today, approving new party statutes, a statement of political aims and the outline of a 20-year development plan designed to speed industrialization of the country.
The restoration of West 42d Street from a hodgepodge of art and rerun movies and novelty stores to its former grandeur as the center of the legitimate theater was envisioned yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13--The Soviet Union and Cuba submitted a joint proposal on the Cuban crisis today to U Thant, Acting Secretary General.

DALLAS, Nov. 13 (AP)-- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga said through an aide here today that his planes had bombed sectors of North Katanga, but that the bombs had been "directed at troops besieging Kongola."

The kind of progressive education that allows children to learn "what they could rather than what was good for them" was deplored yesterday by Dr. John H. Fischer, who was inaugurated as the fifth president of Teachers College of Columbia University.

Hempstead, L.I., raised $5,796,000 yesterday for various purposes on bonds due 1963-81. A group led by the Chase Manhattan Bank was awarded the issue on a bid of 100.3399 for a 2.70 per cent coupon. This set a basis cost of 2.64 per cent to the borrower.

An important realignment in the management of the Superior Oil Company, a leading independent oil producer, was announced yesterday. The company also stated that it would move its headquarters from Los Angeles to Houston, Tex.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The Post Office decided today to begin mass production of misprinted Dag Hammarskjold commemorative stamps to reduce the value of the few hundred that were sold by mistake.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)--Four of last week's races for governorships and one for the Senate are still undecided. Recounts axe likely in all five.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 13 (UPI) --Charles Laughton, ill with cancer since January, was described today as in "quite serious condition" from the spreading malignancy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany arrived tonight to discuss Berlin and other problems of the Western alliance with President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

Montgomery Ward Co., mail order and department store concern, has switched its private brand tire account to the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company from the United States Rubber Company. Trade sources valued the account at about $40,000,000 a year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13--Adlai E. Stevenson accused Senator Barry Goldwater today of distortion in quoting remarks he made last September in the General Assembly.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 13--Dr. Erval R. Coffey, Town Health Director, called on residents today not to contribute to the current Christmas seal campaign of the Connecticut Tuberculosis and Health Association.
VILLAGE VANGUARD, 178 Seventh Avenue South. Miles Davis's Quintet; the Shirley Horn Trio.
Increased enrollment among junior high school pupils in foreign-laguage courses was reported yesterday by the Board of Education.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 13-- The election of Dr. Caryl P. Haskins as a trustee of Yale University was announced today.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 13 (UPI)--Rod Laver of Australia, the world's leading player, defeated his countryman, Bob Howe, 6--4, 6--3, today and advanced to the quarter-final round in the South Australian tennis championships.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- Congressional critics are beginning to question whether the space agency is planning to get its money's worth out of the more than $700,000,000 invested in developing the Saturn superbooster rocket.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 13--The lower rouse of Parliament unanimously approved today a deal between the Netherlands and Vincent van Gogh, son of Theo van Gogh, the famous Dutch painter's brother.

Mr. and Mrs. Alistair Cooke of 1150 Fifth Avenue and Nassau Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Cooke's daughter, Miss Holly Hawkes, to Cyril Gordon Clowes Hosking. He is the son of Mrs. Harold William Hosking of Richmond, Surrey, England, and the late Mr. Hosking.

ELBERON, N.J., Nov. 13--A June wedding is planned by Miss Beth Jane Leichter and Dr. Arthur Beryl Farfel. Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Leichter have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Farfel of Portsmouth, Va.
William S. Murray, a copy editor for 15 years with Fairchild Publications, died of a liver infection yesterday at Whitestone (Queens) Hospital. He was 56 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13--The Acting Secretary, General, U Thant, plans a meeting of his Congo advisory committee within a few days to consider Katanga province's apparent disdain of his Nov. 15 deadline for agreeing to unification with the Congolese Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--President Kennedy, is now looking over his team to see whether it can be strengthened for the second half of his term.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision that a California law requiring imprisonment of narcotics addicts as criminals inflicts cruel and unusual punishment.

The Long Island Rail Road has agreed to sell 230,000 square feet of land under its freight tracks and air rights over them in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, for the construction of a middle-income cooperative apartment house development.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--Arizona and California renewed in the Supreme Court today their 40-year-old controversy over the division of the water of the Colorado River.

MOUNT LEBANON, Pa., Nov. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Max B. Nobel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Louise Nobel, to Michael George Hirsh. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hirsh of North Adams, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
A screen drama called "Sacco and Vanzetti" will be based on the trial and execution of the two Italian immigrants who were charged with robbery and murder in 1927 in Massachusetts.
Borough President Abe Stark of Brooklyn called yesterday for an attack on slums in Brooklyn through stricter enforcement and higer fines for building and heath violations.
Wall Street's new optimism was reflected yesterday as bond prices fell.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 13--A Brazilian film, "The Keeper of Promises," was chosen today as the best picture in San Francisco's sixth annual International Film Festival.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13 --An assistant conductor of the Israeli National Opera will stand trial here on charges of turning thousands of Jews over to the Nazis in Poland during World War II.
BONN, Nov. 13-- Chancellor Adenauer, who has gone to the United States for talks with President Kennedy, has left, behind a political situation that is growing more tense and Serious.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13 (AP)--A Detroit trucking executive testified today that bills made out to James R. Hoffa had been paid by a trucking concern operated under Mrs. Hoffa's maiden name.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.
MANY mortal joys may be hollow, as Gilbert and Sullivan sing ironically, but there is no diminution in the delights of "The Mikado."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13--Britain offered today to discuss around a conference table Venezuela's claim to a large part of British Guiana.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- Terry Downes, the British middleweight champion, defeated Phil Moyer of Portland, Ore., on a technical knockout in the ninth round tonight. Downes weighed 164 pounds, Moyer 165.

WASHINGTON; Nov. 13-- The Budget Bureau said today that the Federal budget would show a deficit of $7,800,000,000 this year instead of a surplus of $500,000,000, as estimated by President Kennedy last January.
ARRAS, France, Nov. 13--A key race in the French legislative elections is being conducted in an unexciting way in this austere northern city.

The New York Knickerbockers played rather respectable ball for most of three quarters last night. But when you're playing against the Boston Celtics it's mandatory to go all out for the limit of four quarters.
RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 13-- Mrs. Annie Denike Brearley of 1256 iPerpont Street, died today in a nursing home in Plainfield at the age of 100. Her husband, Samuel M. Brearley, died in 1899.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes appealed to New Jersey's town and city authorites today to cooperate in a stepped-up national civil defense program.
Commodities futures prices on the New York markets were mostly higher yesterday following the partial holiday on Monday.
A two-part television program about the United States Supreme Court will be shown on "C.B.S. Reports" early next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 --Prince Philip acclaimed today the "generally excellent relations" between English-speaking people and said they had been achieved without "spectacular campaigns or streams of propaganda."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 13--The United Nations said today that according to "relatively reliable" sources, the Katangese had again bombed a village in North Katanga. The Congolese Government has said that North Katanga is not a part of secessionist Katanga Province.

In the interest of assuring the strongest possible United States representation in the 1963 PanAmerican Games and the 1964 Olympic Games, the ruling amateur sports bodies of the nation arrived at a "preliminary agreement" yesterday to resolve their long-Standing differences.

If, as now appears likely, Ronnie Ferraro captures the national riding championship, that feat hardly will be traceable to his exploits at Aqueduct. Yesterday the 19-year-old jockey had six mounts but failed to ride a winner.

Losses of the Curtis Publishing Company continued to mount in the third quarter. The big Philadelphia publishing house indicated yesterday that its net loss in the quarter rose to $6,439,667 from $5,708,844 a year ago.
Macy's held its annual stockholders' meeting yesterday, and the inevitable reference to Gimbels was made. But this year, Ohrbach's proved even more nettlesome to Macy's officials.
ONE of the most memorable arguments in the 30-year history of the Mayfair Bridge Club followed upon a deal that had been passed out.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Nov. 13--An Indian's right to eat vision-including cactus buds in half-Christian, half-pagan ceremonials was defended today by the American Civil Liberties Union as a matter of religious freedom.

HAVANA, Nov. 13 (AP)-- Security officials said today that they had captured the leader of a band of heavily armed, United States-trained saboteurs who landed in Cuba the weekend before President Kennedy ordered the naval quarantine of Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- President Kennedy led a wildly cheering audience that greeted a performance of the Bolshoi Ballet tonight. It was his first social outing since the start of the Cuban crisis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to rule on the validity of a New York law ending the terms of office of members of the New York City school board and setting up a new plan for selection of their successors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- Officials expressed doubt today that they could obtain satisfaction from Moscow on a United States demand for long-term guarantees against a military build-up in Cuba.
Fifty Episcopal women visited a jail yesterday to learn how to be more helpful to women prisoners.
Charles Rosen, a pianist gave a recital in Town Hall last night devoted to four works.
It is customary for the Ivy League football coaches to spread the back-of-the-week honor among the member schools as much as possible.
Dr. Milton S. Fine, a supervising surgeon for the Department of Corrections at the City Prison in Manhattan, died of a heart atack yesterday in his home at 365 West End Avenue. His age was 70.
ROME, Nov. 13--Pope John, speaking in a humorous vein, chided today pessimists who contend that "we will need 10 years to finish the Ecumenical Council."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 13 (UPI)--James E. Mills, editor of The Birmingham Post-Herald, was arrested today on a charge of violating Alabama's Corrupt Practices Act in an editorial printed Election Day. He was freed on $100 bond.
A program to develop chefs and cooks among restaurant workers of lesser skills was announced at a labor-management conference yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 13--More and more American families are moving into apartment houses, and the dramatic shift in their mode of living is having a profound effect in construction and real estate.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13(UPI) --Former President Roque Gonzalez Garza died here last night at the age of 77.

Dr. Ralph Lester Barrett, for 25 years chairman of the New York County Medical Society committee on maternal mortality, died of a heart attack Monday evening in Madison Square Garden where he had been watching professional wrestling. He was 70 years old.

A Bronxville apartment house cooperative accused of violating the State Law Against Discrimination has agreed to comply with the law. The cooperative had been accused of barring Jews as tenant-stockholders.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP)--The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has set aside a sentence for contempt of court imposed on Dr. Sidney Martin Fox, a New Jersey chemist. Dr. Fox is accused of conspiracy in connection with the alleged sale of secret formulas for pharmaceuticals.

OTTAWA, Canada, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press)--The interest rate of the Bank of Canada was cut sharply today to 4 per cent from 5--the third reduction since the rate was pegged at 6 per cent during the June foreign exchange crisis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--A prominent educator proposed today passage of legislation that would enable a prompt court test of Federal grants to church-related colleges.
Marty Tananbaum, the president of Yonkers Raceway, yesterday predicted "a hellish series of races on Friday night."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)--Two Marines lost their legs and a third broke both legs in a land mine accident 10 days ago at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, the Marine Corps said today.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 (UPI) --The Soviet Union and Poland will continue to help India develop its oil and mining industries, Keshava Deva Malaviya, Indian Minister of State for Mines and Oils said today.
