PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 13--Sid Tomack, film and television actor, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home. His age was 55.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 13--An international team of economic and fiscal experts will be dispatched soon to Senegal and Gambia on one of the most unusual technical aid projects yet undertaken by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--A vastly expanded role for cooperatives in the economic life of the nation, including operation of their own chain stores, mail order houses and processing plants was outlined today before the Cooperative League Congress.
LONDON, Nov. 13--Prime Minister Macmillan yielded to Opposition demands today and announced a full judicial inquiry into the "circumstances" of the Vassall spy case.
Following the recent sharp rise in stock pricees, investors are moving back into the market--but in a cautious manner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The National Urban League offered today to help the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations end racial discrimination in the labor movement.
The faming of Henry C. Brunie as chairman of the foundations committee of the $104,000,000 building fund campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 13--The countries of the European Economic Community along with Britain, a prospective member, are heading toward a showdown, possibly this week, over multimillion-dollar financing that carries grave implications for the future of the Common Market.

TOKYO, Nov, 13 (UPI)-- Typhoon Karen was reported moving toward Okinawa tonight after raking tiny Guam with winds up to 175 miles an hour. All aircraft were being secured in preparation for the expected storm.
The Transit Authority gave limited endorsement yesterday to a proposal to permit commuter buses to run on expressways and "similar roads."

NEW DELHI, Nov. 13--India's upper house of Parliament adopted a resolution today, an old retired clerk decided he could get along without most of his pension and a 7-year-old boy marched to the Prime Minister's house with a fistful of coins.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The Supreme Court let stand today a Court of Appeals decision setting aside contempt-ofCongress charges against Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military deficiencies have long been a matter of common knowledge; too few commanded by too many, and the few inadequately trained and equipped.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13--The estate of Harold H. Swift of the meat-packing family was estimated at $7,500,000 today. An inventory of his assets was filed in Probate Court.

Specialty shops in Northern New Jersey, New York and New England will display a wide variety of Christmas gifts and decorations, for which orders may be placed, at the third annual Christmas Showcase to be presented by the Vassar Club of Essex County, N.J.

An intra-family lawsuit involving promoters of the second and third Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship fights was delayed in going to trial yesterday while lawyers tried to arrange an out-of-court settlement.
LONDON, Nov. 13--The British Government suggested today the transformation of the European Economic Community into a group of 13 states and about 260,000,000 people.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--President Kennedy has accepted the resignation of Fowler Hamilton as head of the foreign aid program, the White House reported today.
The president of the National Retail Merchants Association said here yesterday that he "personally" disapproved of the sale by American stores of merchandise made in Communist nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) --Senate stockpile investigators accused a Canadian company today of "arm-twisting" the United States Government into large profits on a Korean-wartime contract for $150,000,000 worth of nickel.

Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, friend and ally, has arrived in this country on one of his periodic visits to review the international situation with the President and his advisers. The Federal German Chancellor will receive a respectful hearing; his achievements command much respect.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press)--Justice T.G. Norris accused the Seafarers International Union of Canada today of "reprehensible" tactics and said a deliberate attempt was being made to delay and frustrate his investigation of labor strife on the Great Lakes.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that he had telephoned James C. Hagerty Sunday morning to "express astonishment" over a television appearance by Alger Hiss.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- Six Government economists predicted today that there would be no recession in 1963--and not much expansion either.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 13--The big book store on the Yale campus will close tomorrow shortly before 6 P.M., as usual. But it will slowly perk up again, and soon will seem to be dancing and swinging with literary gremlins.

Mr. and Mrs. Goodman A. Sarachan of Rochester, N.Y., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Ellen Sarachan, to Martin L. Lawrence. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Larry of Rockville Centre, L.I. The wedding is planned for next month.
Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., the only eligible Mercury astronaut who has not yet been rocketed into space, has been named for the next Mercury flight.

The latest sneak play used successfully against the New York Football Giants has resulted in the team's biggest loss of the season--a 15-by-37-foot flag.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- United States officials believe that Anastas I. Mikoyan is making a survey of the fundamental political and economic relations between Cuba and the Soviet Union.

Dr. John Boyle Rearden, a leading obstetrician and gynecologist here, died Monday of a heart ailment in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 360 West 245th Street in Riverdale, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- A final design for the United States exhibition at the New York World's Fair was adopted today with the tacit approval of the White House.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The police wounded three persons today in a gunfight at the headquarters of a leftist political organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The United States appears to bed headed toward recognition of the revolutionary government of Yemen.
Zooming is the word for the principal stock market averages in the last three weeks.

DURING the 1956 Olympic Games at Melbourne, the simmering hostility between, the Hungarians and the Rus sians erupted through the surface of the blue-green waters of the Olympic pool and streaked it a blood red. It was almost inevitable. On the very eve of the international show Soviet tanks had moved into Hungary to crush the rebellion against Communist oppression, and the flames of bitter nationalism had carried all the way to Australia.

Negotiators for The New York Times offered the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday a package proposal that included wage increases averaging the same as those that ended an eight-day strike at The Daily News last week.

Mr. and Mrs. Batchelder Ollinger of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Antonia Challen Ollinger, to Malcolm James Philp. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Philp of Irchester, Northamptonshire, England.
CLIFTON, N.J., Nov. 13--A squirrel switched off electrical current for 35,000 customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company today.
G. Carey Winfrey, a noted trailer of thoroughbred horses, died yesterday in Jamaica (Queens) Hospital. He lived at 109-10 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, and was 77 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13--James C. Petrillo, president of Local 10 of the American Federation of Musicians and former president of the federation, will face opposition for the first time since 1933 in next month's elections, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--The cost of the Cuban crisis was put officially today at about $100,000,000.

Events today: "Ernani," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Symphony of the Air, Alfred Wallenstein, conductor, Daniel Barenboim, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Elena Nikolaidi, mezzosoprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Kroll Quartet, 92d Street young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30.
NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Nov. 14--The Chinese Communist Embassy and consulates in India were reliably reported today to have been burning their files and documents.

Mrs. Wayne Pepper of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and G. Willing Pepper of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Jayne Pepper, to Montgomery Meigs Lewis. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Winslow Lewis of Penllyn, Pa., and Shelburne, Vt.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after seesawing gently in active trading. Key market indicators fell slightly, reflecting weakness in issues that have been recent favorites.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 (UPI)--Coach Bob Devaney, whose high-scoring Nebraska Cornhuskers have ended a long period of frustratuion for the state's football fans, today received an expensive inducement to stay with the Cornhuskers.

Sales and earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its whollyowned subsidiaries fell during the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday. Net income slipped to $19,667,000, or 67 cents a share, from $20,579,000, or 70 cents a share, in the like quarter last year. Sales plummeted to $97,711,000 from $124,002,000 in the 1961 quarter.
HAVANA, Nov. 13 (Reuters) --Five foreign correspondents were rearrested here last night and will be expelled and sent to Mexico on Friday, it was announced today.
The Teachers Union urged the Board of Education yesterday to request $200,000,000 more for the 1963-64 school budget. The current operating budget, as granted by the city, provides $563,923,490.

According to most estimates, advertising volume ten years from now should total about $25,000,000,000 a year, or twice the present level. The average urban consumer, who now is subjected to an average of about 1,600 advertising messages a day, may therefore be bombarded with over 3,000 such messages in the nineteen-seventies.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 13--The first United States trade center inside the Common Market was opened here today amid clear indications that American business would fight to maintain its lead as chief supplier of West Germany.

Nat Burns, the character actor who died Thursday at the age of 75, was buried yesterday in the Actors Fund plot of the Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, N.Y. His grave is opposite that of Fritzi Scheff, the operetta star with whom he had often appeared.

Religious, racial, economic and social factors played muted but important roles in last week's elections for Governor and Senator in New York.

Dr. Abraham J. Ginsberg, a retired specialist here in diseases of the ear, nose and throat and the inventor of the Diapulse machine, died yesterday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 73 years old and lived at 155 E. 56th Street.

Mrs. George W. van Siclen of New York will give a small dinner dance in the Terrace Room of the Plaza on Nov. 23, preceding the first Junior Assembly, in honor of her granddaughter, Miss Elise Irving Boeger, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Boeger Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.
Samuel Armstrong Scoville, an architect who had practiced here and in Connecticut, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had lived for the last year. He was 57 years old.

DETROIT, Nov. 14--A tightening of regulations on expense accounts under provisions of the Revenue Act of 1962 will spell an end to expense account living as a "way of life," according to Mortimer M. Caplin, Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity has been urged to force the elimination of segregated trade unions in the South.
OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Nov. 14--The Fire Island Voters Association asked Governor Rockefeller today to initiate preventive measures against a "new disaster situation" on the barrier beach.

PARIS, Nov. 14--The French Cabinet gave its approval today to a plan for French-British cooperation in the development and construction of a commercial airliner to fly at more than twice the speed of sound.

PARIS, Nov. 14--Yves Montand, a veteran of the Paris music halls who has won fame in Hollywood, New York, Tokyo, Tel Aviv and Moscow, returned to a Paris music hall last night. It was the singer and dancer's first appearance here in four years.
QUEBEC, Nov. 14--The Liberal Government of Premier Jean Lesage was returned to power today with a majority far bigger than it held in the last Legislature.
LONDON, Nov. 14--Prime Minister Macmillan demanded today a "trial of the truth" to determine whether accusations and insinuations of treason and immorality in the Admiralty had any foundation.

ONE of the most important men at a dog show is the veterinarian. Without him there would be no show. The by-laws of the American Kennel Club state that no premium list may be printed until the name of the veterinarian who will attend has been approved by the A.K.C.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (UPI)-- Bob Pulford poked his own rebound past Jacques Plante at 21 seconds of the final period for what proved to be the winning goal for the Toronto Maple Leafs in a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

Jimmy Caras of Upper Darby, Pa., and Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, two of the world's foremost players, gave the game of pocket billiards a lift toward new popularity in a plush setting at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Former President Eisenhower has come out in favor of a reduction in taxes, thus reversing the position he held when he was a resident of the White House. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14--Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the issues in the Cuban crisis had been "isolated" and "clarified." However, the United States representative indicated after a talk with U Thant, Acting Secretary General, that complicated negotiations lay-ahead.

"If you can't catch the attention at the start and hold it, there's no use going on, whether it's biography, drama, verse, whatever it is," said Marianne Moore, one of America's leading poets. "In a poem the excitement has to maintain itself."
Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that the Board of Education had set up roadblocks to its own school construction programs.
The New York Rangers scored five goals in the second period last night and whipped the Boston Bruins, 6--2, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
Reports that "Mother Courage," as staged by Jerome Robbins, would have its delayed Broadway premiere at the Martin Beck on March 4, 5 or 6 were confirmed yesterday by Cheryl Crawford, producer.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14--A Soviet Air Force officer dropped 15 miles from a balloon before opening his parachute, the Soviet press reported today.

NEWARK, Nov. 14--Two civilian Army Signal Corps employes and a manufacturer's representative were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to influence the award of a Government contract.
Plans for a five-deck, $1,500,000 parking garage-office building in the center of a major shopping area of Queens were announced yesterday by the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce.

A little news item from Lima, Peru, tells a potentially big story. It is about Indian peasants --8,000 of them--in the old Inca capital of Cuzco, high in the Andes, clashing with the police. They were expressing a protest, the specific motivation of which was less important than the general discontent that pervades the southern part of the Peruvian highlands.
Roger Ginsberg has quit golf's amateur ranks on a gamble. He's risking a $10,000 bankroll to make good on the professional tournament tour.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Department of Commerce announced today the executive staff of its reorganized domestic and foreign business services unit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)--Walter W. Heller, chief economic adviser to President Kennedy, suggested tonight that corporate taxes be reduced 10 per cent next year, or about $2,000,000,000.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 14 --The avoidance of even the simplest drugs by women during early pregnancy was urged by scientists at a meeting here today.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14-- The chances of an international treaty demilitarizing space appear good, a disarmament adviser said today.

The Schick Safety Razor Company tried yesterday to cancel a million-dollar advertising contract with the American Broadcasting Company because of the appearance of Alger Hiss on an A.B.C. television program.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 14-- The extent of the purge of the leadership of the Bulgarian Communist party was disclosed today with the announcement of the organization's new Politburo and Central Committee.
Mayor Wagner faces a major post-election political test when Democratic district leaders meet in Queens tomorrow and in Brooklyn on Monday to pick new county leaders.
LONDON (Reuters)--A big stride toward helping disabled persons live a normal and independent life was shown here recently in an exhibit called "Toward Housing the Disabled."

WHEN frigid weather strikes the northern climes, college football players often don tight-fitting knit skull caps to keep their wits warm. Such was the case at Hanover, N.H., last week. Coach Bob Blackman issued oakgreen knit hats to his players to wear on Monday and ...
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 14 --A decline in property values if Negroes moved into the Westport-Weston area was predicted by some in a survey made public today.
An attempt by railroads to achieve a modest improvement in operating revenues by increasing certain service charges to railroad shippers will receive a public hearing in Chicago on Dec. 4 and 5.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy told the 24,000 members of the police force yesterday that he expected every one of them to be trained and prepared for an "enemy attack."

Beverly Reid Thurman of 924 West End Avenue, a United Nations interpreter, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at Grand Central Hospital. He had collapsed in the swimming pool at the East 47th branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. His age was 53.
COURCHAMPS, France, Nov. 14--Pierre Poujade, who once led a tax rebellion, spoke in the village square today before a sparse audience.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The number of Americans on nonfarm payrolls rose in October to a record of 56,308,000, the Labor Department reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UPI)--Cassius Clay takes the biggest step in his brief boxing career tomorrow when he enters the ring against the experienced Archie Moore in a 12-round heavyweight elimination bout.

THE Symphony of the Air, which last season gave a seven-concert Beethoven cycle, last night began a sevenconcert Brahms cycle. Again the locale was Carnegie Hall and Alfred Wallenstein was back on the podium.

The Louisville Nashville Railroad returned to the bond market yesterday after an absence of eight years. The road borrowed $25,000,000 in a threecornered competitive sale of 25year collateral trust bonds. It was the first offering of bonds by any American railroad in four years.
Almost unnoticed, du Pont stock has made highs of sorts for the year in the last two days' trading.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation plans to acquire the assets of the General Controls Company of Glendale, Calif., automatic controls concern, both companies announced yesterday.
Two men charged with conspiring to steal antibiotic cultures used in the development of wonder drugs pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court.

Personal philosophies of the late Albert Einstein, the physicist, and Louis D. Brandeis, the jurist, as revealed by their writings and speeches, will be presented on two half-hour programs on "Look Up and Live." They will be televised Sunday at 10:30 and the next Sunday at the same hour over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)--Mrs. John Foster Dulles plans to donate a bronze bust of the former Secretary of State at the dedication Saturday of Dulles International Airport, the new Washington international air terminal.
LONDON, Nov. 14--The stock market was buoyant and active again today, although the demand was selective. Gains of as much as a shilling (14 cents) were dominant.

The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York tentatively agreed last night on a new two-year contract to cover 2,200 news and commercial employes. The agreement is subject to ratification by the Guild unit membership Monday.

Bernard S. Levine, a lawyer here, active in education for many years and a participant in many philanthropies, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 39-24 49th Street in Long Island City, Queens.

Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick yesterday released the list of players who will be available for drafting by major league executives when they gather in Rochester, N.Y., Nov. 26, for the annual minor league meetings.
TWELVE young Finnish women recently completed a tour of schools in the United States and Canada during which they demonstrated that gymnastics can be more than calisthenics or tumbling.
The pilot of the Flying Tiger airliner that ditched in the Atlantic Sept. 23 raised the possibility yesterday that a mistake by the flight engineer might have been a critical factor in the accident.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UPI)-- Bobby Hull, last year's National Hockey League scoring champion, broke his home ice scoring drought tonight with two goals to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. It was Detroit's second loss in 14 games this season.
A FORMER newspaperman turned diplomat, Carlos Manuel Lechuga Hevia of Cuba is an experienced diplomat and a moderate by Cuban standards.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- President Kennedy and his brother, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy both donate their Government salaries to charity, sources close to the two men said today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 14 (AP)--Coach Wayne Hardin of Navy said today that Southern California, the nation's No. 2 college football team, had been getting away with rule violations all season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. appeared today to have found a solution to a problem that many union leaders say has been a drag on organizing.

THE dishes enjoyed by African nationals, a spokesman for the African Cultural Group noted recently, tend to have a striking similarity. Typical ingredients include the oil of palm, tomatoes, onions, fresh or dried meat or fish, and the foods may be highly condimented with red pepper.
THE deal shown today was played at the Barclay Bridge Club in Jackson Heights, Queens, where duplicate games are large and numerous players are likely to be declarers at the same contract.

SPRING showings by Seventh Avenue designers and man- ufacturers are drawing to a close. Only a few--Scaasi, Burke-Amey, Galanos and Norell--have yet to unveil their collections. Their showings, traditionally scheduled after all the others, will not be held until early next month.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14 --The Rev. Raymond A. McGowan, a leading Roman Catholic clergyman and writer on labor and social legislation, died here yesterday in Mercy Manor, a home for retired Catholic laymen and priests. He was 70 years old.

The engaging collection of Herbert Hoover's replies to letters from children, published yesterday, is perhaps more revealing of the man than a volume of state papers. In the foreword, written as he approached his 88th birthday, he offers his credentials: "I can claim some experience with children. I was a kid once."

One wanted very much to enjoy Elena Nikolaidi's recital at Town Hall last night. The Greek mezzo-soprano, who has given much pleasure since her spectacular debut here in 1949, was back after an absence of four years.
An accident of seating and an almost never-invoked rule at the Parke-Bernet Galleries decided yesterday who should own a famous jewel, "The Idol's Eye," when two bidders were deadlocked at auction.

South of the Krong No River, Vietnam, Nov.14--A tired Vietnamese, after climbing his third mountain ridge of the day only to see another ahead, called this countryside "the land of one more mountain."
An electronically controlled device to provide emergency drug treatment to astronauts was envisioned yesterday by David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 7:

Chalk talk at Yankee Stadium yesterday sounded suspiciously like a fairy tale as Coach Al Sherman tried to impress his New York Giants with the importance of being earnest about Sunday's rematch with the Philadelphia Eagles.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 14 (UPI)--A Government witness testified today he had never been asked to conceal the ownership of a business in which James R. Hoffa, president of the teamsters union, allegedly held an interest.
Stock prices resumed their upward march yesterday, climbing sharply in heavy trading.

PARAPHRASING a maxim of Maroczy, difference of opinion is the soul of chess. Tabulating the many expert opinions on openings, however, is not enough for a conclusion: the pro and con must be determined over the board.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 14--In contrast to the optimism about future movie production in Hollywood is the silence on so many movie sound stages today.

A "top-to-bottom" inspection of the new 50-story Americana hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, was ordered last night after the Fire Department had issued four summonses for fire safety violations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 --A new grouping of nations under the provisional title of "The Confederation of the Free" was proposed tonight by Henry Cabot Lodge.
Bill Boland, enjoying a resurgence among the metropolitan area's better-known jockeys, rode the Mac Sweetie Stable's Lady Pampa to victory in the Mutiny Purse at Aqueduct yesterday.
The bomb, the gun and the knife were for centuries the normal means of "settling" political accounts in the Balkan peninsula.
With Maine potatoes leading the way, most commodities on the New York exchanges advanced yesterday for the second consecutive day.
Arthur O. Dietz, chairman of the executive committee of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, will retire on Dec. 15, the corporation announced yesterday. He will continue as a director.
The foyer of the Plaza's ballroom, complete with a fountain and tropical plants and flowers, set the mood last night for guests arriving for the Daiquiri Ball.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 14 (AP)--The president of a chain of furniture stores in Philadelphia and South Jersey was arrested tonight on a charge of defrauding a credit company of $658,000. The suspect is Charles R. Yocum Jr. of Riverside.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 14-- A Massapequa resident moved today to dismiss a $21,500 damage suit brought in Supreme Court by a Puerto Rican family who said they had been threatened with bodily harm if they moved into a new housing development.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 14--Sometimes toward the end of a 10 or 12 hour deer hunt, memory blurs in a numbed mind. Today I resolved to record a hunting day in the company of Bill Walthausen of Wilmington and Dave Baker of Larchmont by keeping detailed notes.
An increase of 752,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Administration appeared increasingly optimistic today that the Soviet Union and the United States would agree on a final resolution of the Cuban crisis this week.
The board of the Fruehauf Trailer Company announced a 30 cent extra dividend yesterday on the common stock. The manufacturer of truck trailers and accessories did not pay an extra last year.
The Rev. Dr. William Henry McMaster, president emeritus of Mount Union College in Alliance, Ohio, died yesterday in Coral Gables, Fla., at the age of 87.
NEW DELHI, Nov.14--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that the "good wishes" of the Soviet Union "are a great consolation to us and we hope we will have them in the future."

James E. Webb, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said last night that the Apollo project, a manned expedition on the moon, was on schedule and would be fulfilled before 1970.
ALGIERS, Nov. 14--The Algerian Government pushed its agrarian reform program last night and today by turning two farms, abandoned by the French, into cooperatives run by peasants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)--The 10 per cent Federal tax on rail, bus and boat fares will expire at midnight tomorrow night and a 10 per cent levy on air fares will be cut in half. As a result, travelers can expect to save nearly $150,000,000 a year.
Candidates for heavenly-- and earthly--recognition danced at the Angels Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Nov. 14--The San Bernardino County Superior Court took under advisement today the state's controversial ban on peyoteeating, after hearing both medical and legal arguments supporting the practice.

A merger of Norness Shipping Company, Inc., with the AngloAmerican Shipping Company, Ltd., was announced here and in London yesterday. The announcement was made by an international group of shipping companies headed by Erling D. Naess.
MONTREAL, Nov. 14 (AP) --Aviation industry representatives from three countries suggested today international regulations controlling the noise levels of jet aircraft.
AN enjoyable and lively 55 minutes was experienced on Channel 13 last night in a televised continuation of the controversy over Webster's Third New International Dictionary.
ATLANTA, Nov. 14--The Kennedy Administration has done nothing to protect Negroes' constitutional rights in the Albany, Ga., desegregation dispute, the Southern Regional Council charged today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--No one can dip into the Berlitz World Wide Phrase Book (Grosset Dunlap, $2.95) without marveling at how thoroughly the American has immersed himself in the world over the last generation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14-- The rapidly rising number of elderly persons and the flight of middle-income families from the big cities were cited today as major problems of urban renewal.

WOMEN, in their quest for beauty, may soon be caught in a web of electrical cords. The array of electrical beauty appliances for the home now includes home dryers, curling irons, massage machines, toothbrushes and shavers.
ROME, Nov. 14--The Ecumenical Council took its first substantive action today when it approved in principle a long draft decree on the Roman Catholic Church's public worship.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., Nov. 14 (AP)--National Park rangers recovered the bodies of two officers in the wreckage of a small Air Force plane on a snow-covered mountain today.

The United Federation of Teachers has appealed the dismissal of a city teacher who said he would not lead his pupils in a civil-defense shelter drill.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city must take "giant steps" to meet the problem of mounting hospital costs and the shortage of trained personnel in the face of an increase in patients.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Public Health Service reported today that fallout levels of radioactive iodine had exceeded peacetime radiation protection standards in two areas --Palmer, Alaska, and Salt Lake City, Utah--during the last year.
The Anaconda Company earned an indicated $10,235,000, or 96 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1962, sharply higher than the $5,595,000, or 52 cents a share, in the 1961 period.
Mississippi, Minnesota and Dartmouth continue to demonstrate that a solid defense does pay off in college football.

Year-end tax selling is a long-established routine in Wall Street. But the routine has a novel twist this year. Tax selling brings depressed stocks under additional pressure in the final months of the year, since the stocks that are sold are naturally the stocks in which the holder has paper losses.
Two New York investment banking houses are heading rival bidding groups that are attempting to acquire the stock of a California bank with deposits exceeding $500,000,000.
WHAT a beautiful and moving play is "The "Cherry Orchard"! How gratifying to have it available in town in a satisfying performance!

Joseph C. Page, president of the Sentinel Investigation Service, Inc., remained in the Queens detention pen yesterday as his lawyer began a fight to reduce his $100,000 bail in the construction watchmen case.

Colony House, a settlement opened 50 years ago in Brooklyn as a place for young working girls to meet, will mark its anniversary of service Sunday with the cutting of a birthday cake.

THE deal shown today was the most celebrated deal of this year's European championships, according to the magazine of the French Bridge Federation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon promised today that the Administration's tax program in 1963 would call for a "significant" net reduction in the nation's tax burden.

Amidst pathos, comedy and chaos, Civil Court Justice Maurice Wahl yesterday ordered the eviction of a 55-year-old retired Harlem teacher who had failed to comply with his order to get rid of 23 of her 25 cats.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 (AP)-- A Federal District judge ordered Postmaster General J. Edward Day tonight to show cause why he should not be stopped from printing, distributing and selling extra imperfect Dag Hammarskjold stamps.

Treasury and corporate-bond prices fell further yesterday under pressure of profit taking and dealer-inventory liquidation. The market for state and municipal obligations, however, showed signs of improvement.
The new $6,500,000 express station on the IRT Lexington Avenue subway at 59th Street was put into service yesterday morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--Mongolia accused Western "imperialists" today of blocking progress toward world disarmament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--The United Nations deadline for secessionist Katanga Province to resume negotiations with the central Government of the Congo passed today.
"Stifle Archie Roberts" is Penn's pre-game slogan for its 42d football meeting tomorrow with Columbia at Franklin Field in Philadelphia, according to Joe Stanczyk of the Penn coaching staff.

The following log of the burning, explosive-laden freighter captain George reflects the tenacious fight of the crew to save their ship. The messages were received by headquarters of the Third Coast Guard District.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 15-- United States and British arms have reached Indian troops in the northeast, a Defense Ministry spokesman said tonight.
Confidence in the long-range prospects of the domestic shipbuilding industry was expressed here yesterday by the head of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI)--Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman today ordered a reorganization of the Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service.

Once upon a time there was a politician who said what the country needed was a good 5cent cigar. Nowadays, politicians, government officials, economists and businessmen are saying that what the country needs is a good tax reduction.

THE Fordham football team was running through its repertory of plays on its campus field in final preparation for a game with Pitt's Rose Bowl champions. The murmur of traffic beyond the campus gates mingled with the crunch of cleats on turf.

HOUSTON, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Herman Brown, president of Brown Root, Inc., one of the world's largest construction companies, died tonight after collapsing at a dinner in a private club. Mr. Brown had undergone heart surgery in 1960. His age was 70.

SENDAI, Japan, Nov. 15 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers rallied for three runs in the eighth inning to defeat a squad of picked players from three Japanese teams, 4--3, today. They then left for Toyko and the final three games of their goodwill tour.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 15--Dr. Bertil Bjorklund, the Swedish immunologist who created a controversy last December with his hunt for a cancer vaccine, is now entangled in a new dispute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Christian A. Herter, Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration, will take a newly created job as the Government's chief planner and negotiator on foreign trade.
BERGUES, France, Nov. 15 --In this town in the northernmost corner of France, the question is, who will retire to resume his memoirs first -- Charles de Gaulle or Paul Reynaud.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Nov. 13--Henry Clay Irons, president of Irons Reynolds, Inc., general contractors in New York, died at his home here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (A.P)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has rejected "summarily" military pay recommendations submitted by an advisory group of retired senior military officers, the Army Navy Air Force Journal said today.
WOMEN who are heading south for vacations this winter will have a choice of brilliant color or blazing white in the cruise collection by Rudi Gernreich at Bonwit Teller.

DETROIT, Nov. 15--The American Motors Corporation announced today the distribution of $9,766,907 in employee stock credits and other benefits for the first year of its profit-sharing plan with the United Automobile Workers.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the constitutional rights of paroled persons were different from those of other citizens insofar as they applied to search and seizure.
The Federal Maritime Commission has notified the shipping industry that it will make a full-scale investigation of brokerage payments to freight forwarders by ship operators.
BERLIN, Nov. 15--The East German Communists rejected Western efforts today to adopt a plan that would permit members of families divided by the Berlin wall to visit each other for Christmas.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (UPI)-- Heavy selling lowered wheat futures today on the Board of Trade. Corn and oats fell slightly, while soybeans rose and rye was mixed.

GENEVA, Nov. 15--The United States announced today that it was postponing the entry into force of its simplified tariff that had been scheduled to become effective next Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- The Treasury today published its proposed regulations for sales of Government bonds by competitive bidding. It also published a sample bid invitation that gave some clues to official thinking about the first sale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 10 were 2 per cent above sales in the corressponding week last year. Four of the 12 districts reporting, however, showed declines for the period.

Doubts were cast yesterday on the theory that the ditching of an airliner in the Atlantic on Sept. 23 might have been caused partly by a "goof" by the flight engineer.
THREE bread-and-butter pieces made up the pro gram of the New York Philharmonic last night in Philharmonic Hall. They were made palatable by the quiet but expert work of Karl Bohm.

LONDON, Nov. 15--One of Britain's most distinguished writers urged Queen Elizabeth II today, to "seize every opportunity to share the interests of the common people, their sorrows and their laughter."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--Premier Fidel Castro warned today that Cuba would shoot down United States planes if the aerial reconnaissance over Cuba were continued.
UPHOLSTERY fabrics come alive in murals, "paintings" and even sculpture in an imaginative textile show that opened yesterday at Knoll Associates.
The city's major hotels will be searched for fire violations as a result of a small fire that broke out among Christmas decoration in the Americana hotel Wednesday night.

LONDON, Nov. 15--Leaders of the Nagas, the hill tribesmen who have been in rebellion against the Indian Government, offered today to cease their guerrilla operations if Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru would agree to hold a plebiscite on their independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- In at least one of several letters to President Kennedy, Premier Khrushchev has set "unacceptable conditions" for the removal of jet bombers from Cuba, sources here disclosed today.

The city's fourth and largest municipal garage was opened in Kew Gardens, Queens, yesterday and Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes expressed annoyance at the lack of amenities in the $1,837,110, four-level structure.
Twenty-five seamen abandoned a burning, explosivesladen freighter yesterday after a night-long struggle to save the ship. Seven were saved, but 18 vanished in the gale-swept Atlantic.
BOSTON, Nov. 15 (UPI)-- Don Drysdale of the Los Angeles Dodgers today won the Cy Young Award as the major leagues' pitcher of the year.

BOSTON, Nov. 15--Endicott Peabody, a Democrat, was confirmed today as Governor-elect of Massachusetts by a margin of 3,091 votes in the official tabulation of the Nov. 6 election. Gov. John A. Volpe, Republican seeking a second term, said immediately that he would ask for a recount.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (UPI) --Ronnie Ferraro, an apprentice jockey, broke out of a mild slump today by riding three winners at Pimlico.
YONKERS, Nov. 15--Yonkers Raceway will pay homage tomorrow night to the venerable Adios, perhaps the greatest sire --in quantity as well as quality --of standardbred pacers.

Net income of the Singer Manufacturing Company rose to $6,883,000 in the quarter ended Sept. 30 from $5,321,000 in the similar period a year ago. Share earnings were $1.55 compared with $1.20 in the 1961 quarter.
The Board of Education came under new criticism yesterday at a Board of Estimate hearing on the proposed 1963-64 capital budget.
The American Stock Exchange made known yesterday changes in ownership of officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 15 (UPI) --John Paul Jones, an obscure teaching pro, broke par by seven strokes today and took the first-round lead in the fourth annual Mobile Sertoma open golf tournament with a 65.

The chalk-player, that incurable breed of punter who lives and dies by the favorite, was saved from a dastardly fate when George H. Bostwick's Pocosaba won the $10,000 St. Bridget Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI)--A refugee Cuban physician, his head covered by a hood, told House investigators today he had performed surgery under armed guard because the Communist rulers of his country "don't trust anyone."
The annual theater benefit for the Virginia Day Nursery will be on Nov. 26 at "Beyond the Fringe" at the John Golden Theater.
The late John. H.H. Lyon, Professor Emeritus of English at Columbia, has left a bequest of $105,000 for students in four schools of the university.
President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer have concluded their review of the world situation with special reference to Berlin and Germany. Their most important immediate agreement ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI)--Thirteen reporters covering the State Department have formally protested a new rule requiring officials to write memorandums on their talks with mewsmen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Rail and truck loadings of freight declined last week. Truck loadings were partly affected by Election Day, which had no bearing on railroad loadings.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15-- Mayors of New Jersey's larger cities agreed today that their communities faced a bleak economic future, but they shared only one conclusion about a possible remedy: They need financial help.

HARRISON, N.Y., Nov. 15-- Henry Kimball Urion, a retired corporation lawyer and assistant to the president of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, died today in his home at 115 Muchmore Road. His age was 73.
Mayor Wagner named four Manhattan East Side streets last night as overflowing with "problem people." He proposed that the city try still harder to reach a solution of juvenile delinquency.

The dawn of a glorious era in professional hockey, in which Canadian spheres of influence would be shattered and even the New York Rangers would win a game or four, was predicted here yesterday by Muzz Patrick, the coach and general manager of the Blues.
LOS ANGELES, Nov 15-- Sonny Liston, the world heavyweight champion, said today he would defend his title "wherever the price is right."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--Forty African and Asian nations urged today that the Acting Secretary General, U Thant, take steps to establish "an effective United Nations presence in South-West Africa."
Commercial and industrial loans at major New York City commercial banks rose by $108,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

DRIVING between the city and the Adirondacks the other day, I counted thirteen deer on cars heading south. Thers were more than that, but by the time the count began I was beyond Kingston. Ths interesting thing was the size of the heads.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15-- About 8,000 truck drivers and helpers in four states began voting today on whether to remain in the Brotherhood of International Teamsters or align themselves with a rebel group known as the Voice of the Teamsters.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 --After studying Albert Camus in a Long Island classroom, 100 students climbed into two buses yesterday and continued their discussion of the French writer during a theatrical excursion that ended way off Broadway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) --Early Wynn, one game shy of the 300-victory mark, was unconditionally released today-- in effect--by the Chicago White Sox so he could search for a front-office job.
LONDON, Nov. 15--The demand for stocks continued on the stock market today, and rises dominated nearly every section.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15-- The Brazilian Government has decided to press for the transfer "without scandal" of a United States consul who is under attack from the nationalist Governor of Rio Grande do Sul state, Leonel Brizola.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- After months of conferences, Western planners are still at odds on how to counter Communist moves against West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Chancellor Adenauer suggested today that the United States take a harder line in future dealings with the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Nov. 15--The Foreign Office received word today that Greville Maynard Wynne, a British businessman arrested on charges of espionage in Budapest earlier this month, had been "extradited to the competent Soviet authorities."

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 --Anthony Provenzano, an international vice president of the Teamsters Union, who was indicted yesterday, charged today that the indictment was based on "distorted facts and timed to be announced shortly before a local union election."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission denied today a Soviet accusation that it was polluting the seas with radioactive wastes in violation of international law.
Shipments of rayon and acetate filament yarn and rayon staple in October by United States producers totaled 111,700,000 pounds, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported yesterday.
A State Supreme Court jury awarded $87,000 yesterday to a couple who charged that their baby had been permanently injured during birth in Doctors Hospital.

BONN, Nov. 15--Dr. Heinrich Krone, deputizing for Chancellor Adenauer, left the way open in talks with the Free Democratic party today for the departure of Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss from the Government after the Bavarian state elections Nov. 25.
The will of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left bequests ranging from sentimental tokens to substantial sums of money. They will go to a long list of relatives, friends and employes.
SE LA, India, Nov. 12 (AP) --"We'll do it--even if we have to use the knife," a senior Indian officer said today.

The directors of the Fairbanks Whitney Corporation voted yesterday to omit the fourth quarter dividend on its cumulative preferred stock. The three earlier 40 cent quarterly disbursements were paid on schedule during the year, the latest being on Sept. 30.

QUEBEC, Nov. 15--The decisive victory of the Liberal Government of Premier Jean Lesage in yesterday's election in Quebec Province has increased his national stature. He is now regarded as a possible future Prime Minister.

J.H. Batchelder is one man who has a deep affection for, subways. Whenever he gets the chance, he heads underground to prowl through subway stations studying the trains, the passengers--and most of all the advertisements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- The Air Force announced today that there would be a delay of at least three months in the first flight of the prototype of the RS-70.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 15 (UPI)--The Wimbledon champions, Bob Hewitt and Fred Stolle, were eliminated from the doubles in the South Australian tennis tournament today. They were beaten, 3--6, 2--6, 6--4, 6--4, 6-4, by Bob Howe and Martin Mulligan in the semi-final.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 15 --Medical scientists pondered today the question whether man is ready to "play God." Their consensus was that he is not.

Fifty-seventh Street, Fifth Avenue, Madison Avenue and other streets and avenues that from New York's art beat have been compressed in an unusual event, opening today, showing the leading art galleries in microcosm.
It is a year ago today that the Metropolitan Museum of Art became the proud possessor of the world's costliest painting, and the glow of the transaction is still undimmed.

The results of the Italian municipal elections this week indicated once again that the Fanfani Government is interpreting popular sentiment correctly. There was a general acceptance of the Left-of-Center orientation. The stage is being set for a new political drama that will concentrate on social reforms as well as economic development.

Jeanne-Marie Darre was heard here last season for the first time, as soloist with the Boston Symphony, in a highly praised debut. Last night she gave her first public American recital here, in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The General Development Corporation, a big Florida land development company, and the Hamilton Management Corporation of Denver, which manages a mutual fund with assets of more than $100,000,000, have held preliminary merger discussions.

AN excellent small exhibition, "Lettering by Hand," has been assembled at the Museum of Modern Art.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Charlie Hardnett made a free throw and set up a basket in the final 21 seconds of the game tonight in leading the Chicago Zephyrs to a 95-92 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks.

In the five years since his last New York recital, the young American pianist Kenneth Amada has come honorably close to winning almost every major American performing contest. Last night he performed a recital in Town Hall that was worth any number of prizes.
The Broadway opening of Peter Ustinov's new play, "Photo Finish," originally scheduled for next fall, has been advanced to Feb. 13.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- President and Mrs. Kennedy extended a second welcome to members of the Bolshoi Ballet today, this time at the White House.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16-- Paul Minehan of La Salle College led all the way today in winning the 16th annual Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Conference cross-country championship.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 (UPI)--The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed an earlier ruling today and said that The New York Times could be sued in Alabama.

ALAN TRUSCOTT, a member of the British international team that won the European championship last year and competed here for the world championship last spring, arrived here early this week to become a permanent resident.
ROME, Nov. 16--A controversial draft decree, or constitution, on theology will probably be scrapped early next week by the Ecumenical Council, according to reliable sources here.

ALGIERS, Nov. 16--A spokesman for Premier Ahmed Ben Bells said today that he had "no official comment" on reports that thousands of Moslem veterans of the French Army had been killed by vengeful nationalists since the end of the Algerian war last March.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16--The continuing exchange of private letters between Premier Khrushchev and President Kennedy is regarded here by many Soviet and Western officials as one of the most useful developments stemming from the Cuban crisis.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 (UPI)-- Soviet oil experts have drafted a program for expanding geological prospecting in a vast western Siberian region known to be rich in oil and gas resources, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, said today.
A truckload of State Liquor Authority records was handed over to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday as his investigation of the agency was intensified.
Fired by grim resolve go redeem galling defeats they suffered last Saturday, the football teams of Army and Pittsburgh will clash at Yankee Sta dium today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16-The United States said today that it saw hope that revised Soviet proposals on eliminating nuclear missiles or delivery vehicles might yield progress in the disarmament talks in Geneva.
BERLIN, Nov. 16--Jerome Kilty's stage adaptation of Thornton Wilder's book "The Idea of March" had a polite but cool reception tonight when it opened at the Renaissance Theater of West Berlin.
Cotton futures were 10 cents a bale up to 5 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Approximately 20,000 stamp collectors visited the Fourteenth National Postage Stamp Show, which opened yesterday at the 71st Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 34th Street. The show will continue today and tomorrow.
The Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange has "severely censured" the managing partner of a member firm that jumped the gun on subscribers to its market letter.
Howard Hughes moved another step closer yesterday to taking control of Northeast Airlines, Inc. Only one more step is required before he can formally acquire that financially troubled carrier.
YVETOT, France, Nov. 16-- The election campaign here boils down to an attempt by a young city slicker to get himself elected on a left-wing platform in a conservative Norman rural district.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16--A leader of the American Medical Association denied today that the organization was a "bastion of conservatism."

Brooklyn Tech will meet New Utrecht today in a Public School Athletic League football game that may provide Brooklyn with its greatest athletic denouement since the Dodgers unravelled their welcome mat by heading west.
Twenty years age next month the battleship South Dakota limped into port for repair of battle wounds received around Guadalcanal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Sixty-one union members with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra filed unfair-labor-practice charges today against their union local and its president, James C. Petrillo.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP)--Roy G. Fitzgerald, who served for five terms as Republican Representative from Ohio's Third District, died today after a long illness. He was 87 years old.
A leader in Puerto Rican affairs here was named yesterday to head the city's new Department of Relocation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Dr. Tobey Freedman, a specialist in problems of space medicine for North American Aviation, Inc., said in Los Angeles the other day that science will soon be ready to replace the present obsolete model of man.

Two American works received New York premieres last night at the concert by the American Arts Trio in Carnegie Recital Hall. The works were the Trio (Op. 29) by the Rev. Russell Woollen and the Serenade No. 3 (Op. 17) by Vincent Persichetti.

The Nationalist party Government of South Africa has inflicted, without formal charge or trial, an extremely cruel punishment on some of its opponents. In the most severe cases they have been ordered confined to their homes without visitors for five years. Their homes are thus turned into prisons.

DETROIT, Nov. 16--Both the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation announced this week that they planned to increase their production schedules. Their increases in output were disclosed as the high rate of new car sales continued for the industry generally.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16-- A Jewish educator said today that Jewish community support of private, or sectarian, schools was as "much part of the democratic idea as is our obligation to maintain a vigorous free public school system."
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 16--Powell Crichton of 4 Durham Road, a retired New York lawyer, died yesterday in New York Hospital in White Plains, He was 78 years old.

POSSIBLY the greatest demand for living accommo dations in the nation today exists at colleges and universities. The galloping rate of growth of institutions of higher learning has created an urgent need for new residence halls and apartments.
OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 16-- Chief United States Marshal James J.P. McShane was reported today to have been indicted on state charges arising from the University of Mississippi segregation riot.
After a five-week suspension, common stock of the Atlantic Research Corporation resumed trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
CARLSTADT, N.J., Nov. 16--Yogi Berra, athlete, author and American culture hero, emerged triumphant today in a new mantle of significance as captain of industry.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has begun a grand jury investigation of the State Liquor Authority and has subpoenaed its chairman. The city was enjoined temporarily yesterday from enforcing its new $1.25-an-hour minimum wage law, scheduled to take effect next Wednesday.
Committees for the first Consuls General Ball on Dec. 10 at the Americana have been formed. The event will benefit the Polyclinic Hospital and Medical School.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- More than 3,000 Peace Corps volunteers overseas who have already proved they "can take it" are being asked whether they want more.

United States shipping policies, regarded in many foreign quarters as discriminatory, unfair and unduly nationalistic, were defended vigorously last night by a leading Canadian shipbuilder.
The directors of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents on the common stock and a 50 cent extra.

A forthcoming Broadway show was without producers yesterday, but the void--expected to be a temporary one-- will not interfere with plans to open the play here next month.

The Fairbanks Whitney Corporation sustained a net loss of $1,472,000 in the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday. This compared with a profit of $224,000 in the comparable quarter last year. Quarterly sales rose to $35,245,000 from $34,815,000 last year.

Stanley Hoffman, who made his violin debut here in September, took part in a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night called Chamber Music Duos. He played some seldom heard duos with three other instrumentalists and a singer.

A hearing was opened yesterday into the claim of 1,100 former employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., that they retained pension rights with the company after the lines were taken over by the city.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 16 (AP)--Shareholders of the Studebaker Corporation, today approved the firm's biggest acquisition--a Minneapolis company that makes home appliances.
The 1,581,692-share offering of General Motors Corporation common stock will dominate next week's capital market. The shares will be sold through Morgan Stanley Co. on Tuesday.

A pair of early films by Michelangelo Antonioni and Akira Kurosawa, which were bypassed by American distributors the time they first appeared, have been imported by Daniel Talbot, owner of the New Yorker Theater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)--The sale of a million deliberately misprinted stamps was halted by the Post Office Department today under a restraining order obtained by a New Jersey man who has 50 of 400 known unintentional misprints.

Eighteen crewmen from the burning and abandoned Greek freighter Captain George were still unaccounted for in the wind-wracked Atlantic last night. An expanded search for the missing men was expected today as the storm subsided.

Chalk up another moral victory for the New York Knickerbockers--along with their fifth straight defeat. And if you're also keeping track of Madison Square Garden scoring records, credit a 73-point performance last night to Wilt Chamberlain of the San Francisco Warriors.

The United Church of Christ has doomed its Ladies Aid Society. On Dec. 1 the denomination will replace its separate women's and men's organizations with what it believes to be the first coeducational agency for lay members in the history of American Protestantism.
LONDON, Nov. 16--Industrial shares ended their best week in months on the stock market today. Prices held up well against profit taking.
The Northern States Power Company, Minneapolis, reported yesterday an increase in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended Sept. 30.

Two New Jersey businessmen, who lost $100,000 in a key-switch scheme, filed a $100,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- The index of primary wholesale market prices was unchanged at 100.7 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Nov. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--This is one of the bad times for American man. Thursday will be Thanksgiving. After that he will be fighting hopeless odds in the department stores. His last chance for a successful Christmas shopping season is before Thursday. Time is running out, yet he cannot act.

Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit ruled yesterday that Martin C. Epstein, 69-yearold chairman of the State Liquor Authority, was physically capable of appearing before the New York County grand jury that is investigating his agency.
FIFTEEN years ago today, a blue-eyed, brown-haired girl who looked like a porcelain figurine married a tall, blond naval lieutenant.

The first round of the French elections for the National Assembly was not only a startling victory for President de Gaulle; it was also a resounding defeat for the "parties of former times," as the general called them. The Third and Fourth Republics have, indeed, gone into history. The French have turned their backs on the past.
The Board of Estimate was urged yesterday to concentrate all of the city's capital funds next year on new school projects.

Sponsors have been announced for the theater party to the performance next Tuesday of "Lord Pengo," a benefit for the Menninger Foundation. The play with Charles Boyer in the title role opened at the Royale Theatre last night.
Cheryl Warner is a pert, 14year-old high school sophomore who likes pizza, long telephone conversations, high heels and going steady.
The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday for a prompt ruling on the constitutionality of the city's new $1.25-an-hour minimum wage law.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 19--Jasper McLevy, a Socialist who was Bridgeport's Mayor for 24 years, died this morning in his home. His age was 84.

BOSTON, Nov 19 (AP)--Everett Knowles Jr., 13 years old, sometimes gets bad pains in his right arm and fingers. But his winces bring smiles to his parents and doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 19-- The Westchester Board of Supervisors defeated by 32 to 7 today a proposal that criticized the "disproportionate growth" of high-density apartment houses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission spoke out today against advertisers who try to influence radio and television news broadcasts "through commercial reprisals."

BONN, Nov. 19--Chancellor Adenauer's coalition Government broke up today when the Free Democratic party authorized the resignation of the five party members in the Cabinet.
HONG KONG, Nov. 19--Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China has warned that United States aid to India in her frontier warfare wish the Chinese would enlarge the area of conflict.
E.L. Bruce Company, Inc., stock yesterday traded 47,000 shares and closed at 8 , off 6 5/8 from its last transaction June 13.
To correct "dirty play" in college football, Coach Jim Miller of Boston College yesterday suggested a rules change permitting rival coaches to confer with officials during a game.
ROME, Nov. 19--The Ecumencial Council was urged today to avoid and action that might aggravate the divisions within Christendom.

The Chinese Communist attack on India is assuming massive dimensions with far-reaching repercussions on the attitudes, ideologies and policies of many nations, East, West and neutralist. This is no longer an isolated border conflict about a McMahon Line or any line. This is, as Prime Minister Nehru affirms, a "brutal invasion," an "all-out war" that could engulf India and menace all Asia and the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)--The Administration policy of requiring officials of certain departments to report their talks with newsmen applies also to the White House, Pierre Salinger, press secretary, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that a District Court in Atlanta had erred in dismissing 35 of 44 counts in a mail-fraud indictment.
The low-cost housing business and the "exploitation" of home seeking people is the subject of an indictment by Robert Tebbel, called "The Slum Makers."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19--The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee voted without objection today to recommend that steps be taken to send a United Nations observer to South-West Africa.

PARIS, Nov. 19--Laszio Papp of Hungary, the only professional fist fighter from behind the Iron Curtain who is allowed to fight in the West, knocked out Hippolyte Annex with a right hook in the ninth round tonight.
NO fewer than 85 paintings and pieces of sculpture by 77 artists from 20 countries go on view today at the Museum of Modern Art in its annual exhibition of new acquisitions.

PARIS, Nov. 19--The extent of the victory of Gaullist candidates in the first round of legislative elections yesterday, shown by the final returns today, shook the structure of French political life to its foundations.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19--Premier Khrushchev announced today a sweeping reorganization of Soviet governmental administration and of the ruling Communist party to channel the country's efforts more effectively into development of industry and agriculture.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19--A six-month timetable for the first United States assault on Mount Everest and two of its sister peaks was revealed today by expedition leaders.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Nov. 19--The Nassau County Board of Supervisors said today it would approve the sheriff's request for more jailers and an addition to the county jail.
With the passing of Niels Bohr the world has lost not only one of the greatest scientists of this century but also one of the intellectual giants of all time.

A Dallas-based life insurance holding corporation has purchased 93 per cent of the stock of the First Western Bank and Trust Company from Western Bancorporation for $63,300,000. It has made an offer to acquire the remaining 7 per cent minority interest for an additional $6,200,000.
Stockholders of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company have been asked to approve a plan designed "to correct a Federal income tax inequity."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Three important measurements of economic activity showed improvement in October. The figures were published by the Commerce Department today.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19-- Argentina announced tonight that elections for a new President and an entire Congress would be held next June 16.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Domestic auto manufacturers will move steadily ahead this week with their plans to build more cars for this time of year than ever before.
THE new Brooklyn 'Democratie leader, Assembly man Stanley Steingut, has lived most of his life in a political environment.

A spokesman for the nation's airlines has challenged an economist's statement belittling the role of United States-flag international air transport in combating this country's balance of payments deficit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Nov. 20--Premier Fidel Castro informed the United Nations early today that he would not object if the Soviet Union removed the jet bombers it had sent to Cuba.
IF one were a sentimentalist, the temptation would be to say that the success of last night's "Rosenkavalier" at the Metropolitan Opera was the result of an emanation from one of the boxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)--Appraisal requests for dwelling units planned under the G.I. home loan program totaled 14,077 last month, the Veterans Administration reported today.

The directors of the Detroit Steel Company yesterday cut the quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share on the common stock from 25 cents paid in preceding quarters. It is payable Dec. 14 to holders of record Nov. 30.
PARAMUS, N. J., Nov. 19-- Plans for handling the Christmas-shopping traffic at the vast shopping centers at Routes 4 and 17 have been made by the police and business officials.

Philip Rose, the Broadway producer whose credits include "Raisin in the Sun," "Purlie Victorious" and, lately, "Bravo Giovanni," has acquired "The Heroine," a comedy by Frank Tarloff, which he plans to present this season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--President Kennedy's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy called today for "prompt and significant" reduction in personal and corporate income tax rates.
TWO traditional methods of roasting turkey are given below. The high-temperature method, which requires frequent basting, will result in a bird with a crisp, browned surface and juicy meat.

Because exhaustive tests have shown that Del Shofner does not catch footballs with his nose and that Don Chandier is a good "snudder" (meaning he is unhampered by snow and mud), the Giants are beginning to see a pot of money at the end of the gridiron.
REAL jewelry that does not have the oomph it had in grandmother's day need not languish in its cases. It may be restyled into an entirely new design. Many New York jewelers offer this service.
TRENTON Nov. 19--Two bills sponsored by Gov. Richard J. Hughes to end "unfair competition" in the state's milk industry were passed by the Assembly and sent to the State Senate tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told President Kennedy today that India urgently needed more arms aid from the United States. It was under stood that similar messages had been sent to the Governments of Britain and Canada.
LONDON, Nov. 19--Prices of industrial shares and British Government bonds fell sharply on the stock market today.
The Isbrandtsen Company was ordered yesterday to reinstate 124 ship engineers who lost their jobs in a transfer of 14 ships.

A private funeral service for John Shubert, who operated extensive Shubert theatrical interests, will be held at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow in the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Church on Madison Avenue at 81st Street. The burial will take place at Evergreen Cemetery in Morristown, N.J.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 19-- Robert Jordan and Ar thur Robinson of Philadelphia were leading after two rounds today in the American Contract Bridge League's trial matches to select the 1963 North American team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)--The nation's air traffic controllers have submitted a secret report to the Federal Aviation Agency warning that obsolete radar is a major menace to air safety, it was learned today.

In a sparkling effort that causd one official timer to check his watch, Vic Zwolak, a former marine, led Villanova to its first Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America cross-country championship yesterday.

The aggravating farm problem threatens, to get a whole lot worse. According to a study prepared for Congress' Joint Economic Committee, exports of American farm products to the European Common Market may show a decline of 30 per cent by 1970. And if Britain, which is the world's largest agricultural importer, enters the Common Market on terms that discriminate against our exports the loss could be even greater.

IN his long, doleful letter to Lord Alfred Douglas, written from Reading Gaol, Oscar Wilde lamented the fact that his personal tragedy lacked style. It did not have the grandeur he revered in Greek drama.

Macy's 36th annual Thanksgiving Day parade this Thursday morning will include 2,000 costumed marchers, 21 floats, 13 bands and 5 gigantic balloons, one of them so powerful that it will require 22 men to hold it down.

Vivien Leigh, who arrived from England last week, Plunged into a hectic training schedule yesterday for her first musical-comedy role.
WHEN the Cornelius Ross clay gathers in Scarsdale for this year's Thanksgiving dinner, they will enjoy a rare pleasure. They will feast on homemade bread.

S.N. BEHRMAN'S delight in the charm and skill of a supersalesman of art led him to write a lively and amusing series in The New Yorker some years ago called "The Days of Duveen." Unhappily, he has had no such luck with a fictional art dealer.

Major advances in making shoes--new production techniques, new materials and new ways of using older materials-- have brought about Federal action to keep the consumer informed as exactly as possible about what he is buying.

Cotton futures were unchanged to 35 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Sears, Roebuck Co. attained record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Oct. 31. Directors yesterday voted an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock and the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents, payable Jan. 2 to holders of record of Nov. 30.

A new feature has been added to the traditional Christmas fair of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, which will be held Nov. 28 and Nov. 29 at the Community House Auditorium, Park Avenue and 50th Street. The feature will be an art section that will sell the works of local artists.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange this month set a record of 6,785,894, the exchange reported yesterday.

NEW YORK University's Varsity Club has selected Ken Strong and Eddie Yost as the recipients of its alumni-of-the-year-in-sports awards. The presentations will be made at a dinner at the New York University.

"Me--an author!" said Molly Picon yesterday. It was a day for several firsts. It was Miss Picon's first cocktail party to celebrate the publication of her first book.

The New York Mets set their house in order yesterday for some energetic bargaining in the annual minor league player draft in Rochester next Monday. They cut six players from their roster and assigned them to their top minor league farm club in Buffalo.

MIAMI, Nov. 20--A bomb destroyed the automobile of Dr. Jos Mir Cardona, head of the exile Cuban Revolutionary Council, at 1:25 o'clock this morning. Nobody was injured.

UPTON, L.I., Nov. 20--A forest on the grounds of the Brookhaven National Laboratory here is being exposed to radiation 20 hours a day to determine the effects on plant and insect life.

Americans seeking sales in the thriving European market were advised yesterday to forget their usual tactic of concentrating on the housewife and switch their emphasis to the man of the house.

Mickey Mantle, beaten by narrow margins the last two years in controversial contests for the American League's annual most--valuable--player award, yesterday won one that doubtless came as a surprise even to him.
