ROME, Nov. 27 The second session of the Roman Catholic Church's Ecumenical Council Vatican II will begin Sept. 8, instead of May 12. The duration of the second session was not announced, but it is likely to continue through early December of 1963.
The perjury retrial of Mark Zborowski in Federal District Court is expected to reach the jury late today or tomorrow.

Derrick, the 6-year-old campaigner who runs in the silks of Isaac J. Collins, was a big help to the favorite player, at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the feature race of a mile against eight rivals, Derrick came through with a closing rally and beat Emil Dolce's Busy Prince by a nose.

Fordham University's basketball team went through a frustrating season last winter largely because it didn't have much control of the backboards, in any of its 24 games. This problem may be solved now that John Stevens, a 6-foot5-inch sophomore, is on the Ram varsity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)-- Plans for a foundation to continue the work of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in fields such as the United Nations, social development, human rights and health were discussed at a White House meeting today.
The privilege against selfincrimination, which another State Liquor Authority employe refused to waive yesterday, has roots in early Anglo-Saxon law.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 27 The New York Mets waded almost up to their eyebrows in negotiations today as their president, George M. Weiss, continued his heroic efforts to improve his National League cellar occupants for the bright new year ahead.
ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 27 This Rockland County hamlet, which came into being to meet the needs of one era, is disappearing to meet those of another.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 27 (AP) Smart Deb, Mrs. R.L. Reineman's swift but erratic daughter of Dedicate-Demree, was named the champion 2year-old filly of 1962 today by the 28 racing secretaries making up the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' board of selection.

Channing Financial Corporation, formerly known as Exchequer, Inc., said yesterday it was planning to make offers to acquire shares of Charming Corporation. Agricultural Insurance Company, Federal Life and Casualty Company, Secured Insurance Company and Wolverine Insurance Company on an exchange-of-shares basis.
MONTREAL, Nov. 27 (AP) Slow-starting Andy Bathgate, who shared the title last season, is beginning to make his presence felt in the National Hockey League scorine race.

The Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation has announced that it will build a plant at Gramercy, La., to produce phosphoric acid. Total investment in the facility will be about $2,000,000, the company said.

A former marine with a sense of decorum about the United States flag corrected a report yesterday that a flag was stolen Saturday from a pole at Midland Parkway and Hillside Avenue, in Jamaica, Queens.

NEWARK, Nov. 27 The authority of the New Jersey State Highway Department to consider an application by the ErieLackawanna Railroad Company to curtail its Hudson River passenger ferry service came under attack here today.
GUATEMALA, Nov 27 Scores of arrests, both civil and military, were being reported here today as the aftermath of the abortive Guatemalan Air Force uprising Sunday.
LONDON, Nov. 27 Industrial shares recovered from a dull start on the stock market today. Gains outnumbered losses.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 Many persons who have been totally deaf for years have functioning acoustic nerves and can be made to hear pure sounds in laboratory experiments, a California, neurosurgeon reported today.
The public cannot be expected to appreciate the value of public welfare work until it is given more information about the welfare field, a Federal official said here yesterday.
A bill introduced into the City Council yesterday would impose penalties on advertisers for "deceptive advertising practices."

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Nov. 27-- The Supreme Court increased today the prison sentence of Dr. Israel Beer, the Israeli military historian who was convicted of espionage last January. Five years were added to his original sentence of 10 years.
ALBANY, Nov. 27-- A land appropriation case that has been on the calendar of the State Court of Claims for nearly two years was settled today.

Those brave space-age stocks that staged a spectacular rise in 1961, and just as spectacular a drop in May-June 1962, have come to life again on the Big Board, quietly but persistently. For the last month the blue chip stocks those of the large companies like American Telephone and Telegraph and General Electric have been capturing much of the interest.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation in its second fiscal quarter, which ended Oct. 31, had higher sales but slightly lower earnings than those of a year ago. Results for the six months ended with October, however, were ahead of last year's, according to the report issued yesterday.
Trading on New York commodity exchanges increased yesterday with advances in potato and cocoa futures and a decline in world sugar prices.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 The space agency, under pres-, sure of budgetary and technical problems, has been forced to postpone the first manned orbital flight of the two-man Gemini spacecraft until 1964. The flight had been planned for late 1963.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) So many protests have been received by the Internal Revenue Service over its new expense account rules that the service has reserved two days instead of one for a public hearing.

A 33 per cent increase in earnings and a 31 per cent gain in sales for the first quarter ended Oct. 27 were reported yesterday by Eli Rousso, president of Russ Togs, Inc., a manufacturer of women's and girls' apparel.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Hof heimer 2d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clay Hofheimer, to Jay David A. Barr. He is the son of Mrs. Phillip Barr and the late Mr. Barr.

Events tonight: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Erich Leinsdorf, conductor, Geza Anda, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, Judith Raskin, soprano, Sandra Warfield, contralto. Richard Cassilly, tenor, McHenry Boatwright, bassbaritone, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 An extensive state-by-state study made public today by the National Planning Association shows that every state in the country can look forward to greater prosperity, some more than others.
The Continental Can Company will raise its prices to Eastern customers 1 per cent for all types of cans, effective Jan. 1.
APELDOORN, the Netherlands, Wednesday, Nov. 28 Princess Wilhelmina, who as Queen of the Netherlands became a symbol of resistance to Nazi aggression, died early today. She was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 The Pentagon established a new mapping unit in the Defense Intelligence Agency today. The action underscored the continuing centralization of military intelligence work despite past misgivings of many military officials.
A landlord accused by his tenants of halting all services in his tenement to force them to move was fined $500 yesterday in the housing part of Criminal Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI)-- A House committee learned today that the Government was subsidizing part of the cost of teaching Swahili, photography and painting to Federal employes and anyone else in the Washington area willing to pay a modest tuition fee.
Shrugging off Monday's modest declines, stock prices advanced on a broad front yesterday.

AT this season when entertaning at home is getting into full swing, hostesses might consider a simple buffet supper as a pleasant way of concluding a cocktail party. Careful planning, especially in the choice of dishes to be served, plus a little advance preparation can assure that the meal will not tax the weary hostess.

A rule has been laid down by the state prohibiting licensed real estate brokers or applicants from using a trade or corporate name so similar to that of another broker that confusion to the public might result.

After three weeks in Cuba and a final fond embrace by Premier Castro, First Deputy Premier Mikoyan is back in the United States and due to see President Kennedy today. The amount of advertising directed specifically at children has shown a formidable increase lately, not only on television but also in other media.
Some flaws have been revealed in the Federal Government's program for assisting manufacturers of cotton fabrics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 The Premier of the Somali Republic, Dr. Abdirashid Ali Shermarke, met with President Kennedy today for several hours. The occasion marked this country's growing interest in East African affairs.
Cotton futures were 25 cents a bale up to 50 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 Navy has officially questioned the legality of a play that Army's football team has been usine during the season.
The Federal Government has reserved funds for the construction of only 1,500 low-rent public housing units in New York City next year.
Business failures in the nation fell sharply to 253 in the week ended last Thursday from 291 in the preceding week, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 27 The time-honored distinction between amateur cricket players, known as "gentlemen," and the professionals, called "players," may soon end.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 27 A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the proposed merger of American Airlines and Eastern Air Lines be disapproved. He said that the merger would create a monopoly.
Two former New York City policemen interrupted their trial in Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to plead guilty to charges of coercion. They had been on trial for attempted extortion.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 Gov. Edmund G. Brown gave California today the tilte of most populous state.

PARIS, Nov. 27 A report by the 20-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that "budgetary action" was essential to restore full employment and economic growth in the United States, but warned that this could be hampered "because public opinion mistrusts deficit financing."

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Nov. 27-- The Canada goose, a magnificent gray bird that may weigh as much as 14 pounds, settles into the gentle farmlands and waters along Chesapeake Bay each fall. The big honkers come in by the thousands to make the countryside echo with their distinctive double-note calls.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 California, is completing its 1962 crush of grapes amid the sounds of tumbling records.
STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP)-- Jack Curtice was dismissed today as football coach at Stanford.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 27 (AP) Karl Heinz Losch of West Germany won the men's world roller skating championship for the firth time tonight in competition against 12 other skaters from seven other countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 President Kennedy and Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, will confer here Thursday afternoon, the White House announced today.
World merchant shipping continued its growth during the year that ended June 30, though at a less rapid rate than in former annual periods.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Wednesday, Nov. 28 Picket lines were established outside this missile test center early today as the International Association of Machinists began a strike against the Lockheed Aircraft Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 Howard H. Hessler, director of administration and management committee member of the Philadelphia Gas Works, died Sunday. He was 69 years old and lived in Wynnewood.
BONN, Nov. 27 Chancellor Adenauer was put on notice today by his own party, the Christian Democrats, that it wants him to retire in mid-1963.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 Automobile dealers sold 222,022 domestically built new cars in the second 10 days of November compared with 223,344 units in mid-October, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

A five-and-a-half-story building containing 69 apartments at 2819 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by William Kapelman to an investing client of the Philip Fogel Company, the broker in the sale. The building and its plot of 110 by 108 feet were sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $280,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 Representatives of rebel forces seeking to drive the Portuguese out of Angola called today for an economic and military boycott of Portugal by the United States and other Western powers.

RAWALPINDI Pakistan, Nov. 27 Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Minister for Industries, warned the National Assembly today against hasty denunciation of Pakistan's Western allies or impetuous moves for ties with the Communist bloc.

VIENNA, Nov. 27 (Reuters) Bela Biszku, a Hungarian Deputy Premier, and Finance Minister Rezso Nyers were relieved of their Government posts during a meeting of the Council of Ministers today, the Hungarian press agency M.T.I reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 A group of Federal Aviation Agency experts in reducing airport noise told a New York delegation today of the difficulties involved in suppressing aircraft noise and also what the Federal Government was doing to help solve the problem.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 27 Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu complained today that Americans not only were dancing illegally in South Vietnam but they also had recently invited officials of the security police to a reception and danced in front of them.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 (AP) Nat Fleischer told a legislative committee today incompetent officials were a main cause of mishaps in the ring.

Gary Wood, Cornell University's junior quarterback, yesterday was named Ivy League back of the week for the third time this season.

To help parents select books for children, the Association for Childhood Education International has issued its 1962 edition of "A Bibliography of Books for Children."

Shares of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation closed yesterday at 114 on the New York Stock Exchange. The day before they closed at 115 3/8. By all rules of arithmetic, Telephone should be off 1 1/8. A glance at the stock columns, however, will show it was only off 1/8.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 27 (AP) A Communist guerrilla battalion struck at the heart of South Vietnam's "operation sunrise" combat hamlet project early today and inflicted severe casualties before disappearing into the surroundine rubber plantations.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) The line-up for the fourth Liberty Bowl game on Dec. 15 was completed today. It will be Oregon State against Villanova, both led by lefthanded quarterbacks.
LONDON, Nov. 27 The musical "Vanity Fair," which opened at the Queen's Theater tonight, is a disaster. It lacks cohesion, style, wit and charm.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 27 (UPI) The local offices of Bonneville Limited, a Utah producer of potash, said today a special stockholders meeting will be held in New York Dec. 11 at which time shareholders will vote on proposed sale of the company's assets.
The ninth annual international speed week will open at Nassau, the Bahamas, on Sunday with a race for late-model stock cars, Grand Touring cars and prototypes.
LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 27 (Reuters) A warning by the head of the British Ford Company, Sir Patrick Hen
A data communications system enabling a person to control a computer thousands of miles away, using existing commercial communication facilities, was demonstrated yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 27 President de Gaulle reappointed Georges Pompidou Premier today. It was the first political consequence of the Gaullist victory in the recent legislative elections.
LE HAVRE, France, Nov. 27 One of France's mast beloved figures, Rene Coty, former President of the Republic, was buried today in his native city, a city cloaked heavily in mourning.
A man walked into the Atlantic Bank of New York at 123 William Street in lower Manhattan shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday and handed a woman teller a note demanding thousand-dollar bills.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) Miss Suzanne Clift was ordered committed for a period of mental observation today after a plea of not guilty was entered for her in the murder of her boy friend.

PERTH, Australia, Nov. 27 (UPI) England's oarsmen ended a year of frustration today when they swept down the Canning River to win three gold, one silver and two bronze medals in the six rowing events at the Empire and Commonwealth Games.
LONDON, Nov. 27 The British Navy, which once policed the world, is now "barely equal even to the task of the brushfire type of local warfare," a British naval expert said today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (AP) The Soviet Foreign Ministry informed the British Embassy here today that a British businessman, Greville Maynard Wynne, had pleaded guilty to a charge of espionage.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 27 (Reuters) The ruling conservative United Bahamian party retained control of the island's legislature today as final returns were tallied from elections yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 The United Mine Workers welfare and pension fund has been compelled to reduce benefits and remove from the rolls soft-coal miners whose employers have not made payments due it.
SEATTLE, Nov. 27 (UPI) Boeing rolled out today the first three-engine airliner built in the United States since the Ford tri-motor.
The British pound weakened somewhat in foreign exchange dealings yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 27 The Government announced tonight that it had decided to assist those refugees from Tristan da Cunha who desired to return to their South Atlantic island.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 27 Play continued today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament, with the second qualifying rounds of the men's and women's team contests this afternoon and the final round of the mixed pair contest tonight.

Beckman Instruments, Inc., Fullerton, Calif., producers of precision instruments, plans to acquire Vector Manufacturing Company, Inc., Southampton, Pa. in an exchange of stock valued at more than $7,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (AP)-- Increasing his lead as the country's top rider, Ronnie Ferraro, an apprentice, won three races at Pimlico today, including a victory aboard Edsan Stable's Escapat in the La Corredora Purse. Ferraro now has won 319 races.

MALVERNE, L.I., Nov. 27 Many of the friends Leo Egan made in 35 years as a newspaper reporter in New York, Albany and Washington joined his family today at a funeral service for him in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

A United States Government economist has labeled as "an outstanding fact" the absence of a net decline in foreign-held dollar balances in the face of increased sales of United States gold to foreigners.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 27 A method of producing chemicals, some perhaps new, by bombardment with a low-energy atomic beam was reported by researchers today.

Nine-year-old Sally Zanger has a pet cat, a dog and a canary, and now she has offered the New York City Purchase Department $32 for a Sardinian burro, which will be sold at auction at 11 A.M. tomorrow.
Wilmot E. Fanning, chairman of the Bensonhurst National Bank of Brooklyn in New York and its first president, died Monday in the Bensonhurst Nursing Home, Brooklyn. He as 93 years old.

THE future of LeRoy Collins as president of the National Association of Broadcasters is the subject of rising controversy following his outspoken disapproval of tobacco advertising designed to encourage young people to smoke cigarettes.

Show business in all its ramifications has attracted Capitol Records, Yesterday it became known that the organization had turned over $3,000,000 to the successful musical comedy producing firm of Cy Feuer Ernest Martin to be used in a revolving fund. Of the eight shows produced by them, seven have been classified as hits.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 27 A citizens committee was being recruited here today to inquire into the riot that broke out after the Thanksgiving Day football game between the city's largest Roman Catholic and public high schools.

Seventy thousand homes that are part of community antenna systems in 22 cities in the United States and Canada will receive the closedcircuit television show for the benefit of the National Cultural Center in Washington tomorrow night.
The bond market continued its recent pattern of mixed and listless trading yrsterday.
ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) Vatican sources denied tonight rumors that Pope John XXIII would undergo surgery.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27 (AP) Dividends from a highly profitable trucking venture went to pay income taxes and purchase securities for James R. Hoffa, Government witnesses said today. Mr. Hoffa is president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
IF you have wondered what Broadway has needed all along to dispel gloom and spread joy, "Never Too Late" has the answer, It's Paul Ford as the romantic lead.
PHILHARMONIC HALL had a new type of exposure last night its first violin recital. Michael Rabin was the artist who gave it.
PARIS, Nov. 27 (Reuters)-- The police said today that they had arrested a marine deserter suspected of having prepared a new attempt on the life of President de Gaulle.

The 12th annual Friends of the Philharmonic luncheon the organization's main fundraising event, was held yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The group is working to raise $250,000 for the orchestra's current season.
Stocks rose, with most major groups showing more advances than declines in active trading. Low-price electronic issues were very active and higher; volume, 5,500,000 shares.
ROME, Nov. 27 The Government measure to nationalize electric power production and distribution passed its third and final parliamentary vote tonight by a large majority.
"Cleopatra," the most expensive feature undertaking in film history, has been set by 20th Century-Fox to open in June here and in 100 other American and Canadian cities.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 27 Luther Martin 3d of Schoolhouse Lane, retired vice president and production manager of the Wilks-Martin-Wilks Company, chemical manufacturers in New York, died today at his home. He was 89 years old.

James A. Higgins, a former State Senator and Commissioner of Accounts during the administration of Mayor James J. Walker, died Monday at University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 75 Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.

The New York Knickerbockers, dropping deeper into the pastern Division cellar of the National Basketball Association, bowed to the Cincinnati Royals, 139-128, in the feature game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

The merger of the Meadow Brook National Bank and the Bank of Huntington was approved yesterday by the United States Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon. Both banks are on Long Island.

Three men found guilty of kidnapping and robbing a New York businessman and his wife last New Year's Eve were sentenced yesterday in Supreme Court to serve from 20 years to life in prison.

The National Football League announced Sites and dates yesterday for playoff games in the event of ties in either conference.

A theater party will be held fat the evening performance of the musical "Little Me" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Dec. 12 for the benefit of the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan have decided to meet in the Bahamas Dec. 19 and 20 for a general review of world problems.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 27 The Rev. Gowan H. Williams, rector of Holy Trinity, Protestant Episcopal Church, died today at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn. He lived at the rectory at 54 Brooklyn Avenue, and was 42 years old.
The Italian Navy's 11,000ton guided missile cruiser Giuseppe Garibaldi steamed into New York Harbor yesterday for a 10-day visit. She tied up at Pier 84, Hudson River, at 44th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) A joint birthday party for the Kennedy children was held today and President Kennedy slipped away from official duties to drop in on the fun.

Mr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Monderer of Toronto have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felicity Monderer, to Julian Howard Beale. He is the son of Sir Howard Beale, Australian Ambassador to the United States, and Lady Beale of Washington and Sydney, Australia.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, presented the Maria Moors Cabot Prizes to four journalists at a convocation in Low Memorial Library on the Columbia campus last night.

Drivers for many city departments struck yesterday for higher wages, and Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy discharged five civilian employes under his jurisdiction for taking part in the walkout.

The election of John W. Callaghan and Joseph Ludin as members of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers was announced yesterday. The association is the self-regulating organization of the over-the-counter securities market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 India was reported today to have shifted at least half the troops she had stationed on the frontiers of Pakistan to northern border regions to help fight the Chinese Communists.
The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday that it was raising the interest yields on its special issues of short-term notes.
The appointment of Mrs. Arline Short Anholt as chairman of the women's division of the Salavtion Army's 1963 appeal in the metropolitan area was announced yesterday.

Paperboard production in the country totaled 331,113 tons in the week ended Nov. 24, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
The United States Department of Agriculture proposed yesterday a national sugar quota for 1963 of 9,800,000 short tons. This would be 200,000 tons fewer than authorized this year.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 27 The Glen Cove home of Roy Campanella, the former Brooklyn Dodger catcher, was sold in public auction here today at a foreclosure sale.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the city's policewomen have the right to compete in examinations for promotion to sergeant.

The art collection of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lehman was opened to the public in its entirety for the first time last night. One hundred persons paid $50 to see paintings and drawings from the 14th century to the present in the Lehman mansion at 7 West 54th Street.

In this "year of the quarterback" in college football, Terry Wayne Baker of Oregon State University, generally acknowledged to be the season's top performer at that position, yesterday received the supreme personal accolade available to a varsity gridiron hero.

WHEELING, W.Va., Nov. 27 (AP) The number of horses killed in a fire that damaged a stable at Wheeling Downs race track last night was revised downward today to 10. Earlier 25 horses had been reported killed.

Few people are entirely satisfied when they look into a mirror; few are much more pleased when they are forced to admit that they have not behaved as well as they should or accomplished as much as they ought.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (UPI) The St. Louis Hawks, with a 37-point spree in the final period, downed the Syracuse Nationals, 120-105, tonight, in a National Basketball Association contest.

The guiding factor in the failure of the air force uprising in Guatemala was as simple as anything can be in Latin America. President Ydigoras Fuentes is a general. His ten-man cabinet is composed of nine career army officers and one civilian the Foreign Minister. The army remained loyal. It is a mystery how the air force officers could have expected to succeed without army support.
The price of perchlorethylene, an important chemical and solvent used in dry cleaning, will be increased half a cent a pound on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

Mrs. Gosta Oscarsson of Katonah, N.Y., and Peter G. Wyckoff of Norwalk, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Allethy Diana Wyckoff, to John Devine Cobb Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cobb of Washington.
ATLANTA, Nov. 27 (AP) Church union at any price is no better than peace at any price, the president of the United Church of Christ said today.
The Texas Water Development Board sold $15,000,000 of general obligation bonds, due from 1964 to 1997, at competitive bidding yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 Just as Army has been strengthened by the return of Capt. John Ellerson at end and John Johnson, defensive corner back, Wavy too will be at its physical peak for the 63d football game between the service academies Saturday.

A resumption of the East and Gulf Coast dock strike on Dec. 23 appeared likely yesterday after leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association rejected the "final" contract proposal made by shipowning and stevedoring companies.

Al Snyder of Holy Cross and Tim Callard of Princeton were among the eight senior football players named yesterday as the 1962 recipients of the scholarathlete awards made annually by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.
Directors of Merck Co., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals, raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday and also voted an extra dividend to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) A 25-member panel of consultants told President Kennedy today the Federal Government should vastly increase the amount it spent on vocational education.

The North German Radio Orchestra of Hamburg, conducted by Hans Schmidt-Isserstedt, will open a four-week tour of the United States on Jan. 6, at the Mosque Theater in Newark, and play the next evening in Carnegie Hall.
The Police Safety Bureau said yesterday that 1,134 persons were hurt in automobile accidents last week. This is an increase of 130 over the total hurt in the same week last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) Almost as many engineers immigrated to the United States in the last decade as were turned out by the nation's engineering schools last year. gineering schools in 1961.
George C. Huntington, a vice president and general manager of the Television Bureau of Advertising, Inc., elected executive vice president; Jacob A. Evans and Jack O'Mara elected vice presidents.
BONN, Nov. 27 Poland is expected to ask West Germany for a long-term trade agreement during negotiations starting in Warsaw tomorrow, it was reported today.
PERTH, Australia, Nov. 27 (AP) Australian swimming officials continued to snub Dawn Fraser, the world's top woman free-style swimmer, today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) Richard Scammon, director of the Census Bureau, upheld today bureau estimates that California would not pass New York until within the first three months of 1963.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 The United States and Belgium threatened secessionist Katanga Province today with "severe economic measures" if there was no significant progress tosward unification of the Congo in a "very short" time.
Pledging Conference for Extra Budgetary Funds Received pledges totaling $2,070,998 from 28 nations for the 1963 program of the High Commissioner for Refugees.

Communist China's truce proposals in the Sino-Indian border war present the Indian Government with an increasingly difficult decision. Nonaligned nations have now joined the Communists in urging India to take up the Chinese offer, while the contrary views of those in and outside India who oppose the proposition have noticeably hardened.

LAST night's concert in Carnegie Recital Hall was a sentimental as well as a musical occasion. It marked the return to this country of Yoichi Hiraoka, a xylophonist whom millions heard during the nineteen-thirties when he broadcast daily over WJZ for the National Broadcasting Company.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27-- A new, modern port has been developed on the Island of Sakhalin off the east coast of Siberia, according to the Soviet press.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Nov. 27-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall promised tonight to convert the Great Swamp into a "national showcase for wildlife education and interpretation."
The wholesale commodity index dropped to 80.2 Monday, from 80.5 Friday.
A tentative agreement between The New York Mirror and the Newspaper Guild of New York was announced yesterday.
A temporary restraining order was issued in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday against a stock brokerage firm at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 27 (UPI) The International Tin Council opened its meeting here today with delegates from 20 tin-producing and consumer nations attending.
During the 19th century Bismarck recognized that both Britain and France were eagerly expanding overseas empires in Africa and Asia.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 27 (AP) An attorney for James E. Mills, Birmingham PostHerald editor, challenged today the legality of a state law under which he is charged with electioneering and soliciting votes on election day.

David Blum and his Esterhazy Orchestra, giving their second concert of the season in Town, Hall, capped a most pleasant program with Haydn's genially idiotic Symphony No. 60 in C ("II Distratto") and sent the large audience away in good spirits.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) The Kratz family took over at the Pimlico race track today.

Ernst Toch, the Austrianborn composer, who now lives in California, will celebrate his 75th birthday on Dec. 7. Mr. Toch will be honored at a luncheon here on Dec. 16 by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.
The Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., announced yesterday the appointment of H. Wilkinson to the new position of deputy chairman.

The Standard Oil Company of California has entered into a contract to acquire all the California oil and gas properties of Producing Properties, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Directors of California Standard also voted to pay a stock dividend of 5 per cent on the common stock on Feb. 8 to holders of record of Dec. 20.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 The United States announced today that its first plutoniumfueled power reactor had achieved a self-sustaining chain reaction.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) A series of top management changes including a new president have been announced by J. Patrick Lannan, chairman of the Susquehanna Corporation.
Some 1963-64 capital budget changes recommended last week by Budget Director William F. Shea, were rejected yesterday by the City Planning Commission in a sharply worded report.
A New York County grand jury accused a man and woman of rent gouging yesterday in two rent-controlled apartments in a building at 618 West 114th Street.

Opponents of a proposed housing project on Coney Island warned the City Planning Commission yesterday that failure to preserve the proposed site for a parking lot would be harmful to the Aquarium and the rest of the resort area.

The stores in the Sheridan Atlantic Hotel, at Broadway and 34th Street, which formerly were occupied as one unit by Crawford Clothes, have been leased as separate units to four tenants. Crawford had occupied the entire Broadway store frontage of the hotel, between 33d and 34th Streets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Premier Abdirashid Ali Shermarke of the Somali Republic asked the United States today for military aid and an increase in economic assistance.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 28 (UPI) President Kennedy's sister, Mrs. Peter Lawford, was ordered by a judge today to visit injured children in a hospital and inspect wrecked automobiles as a penalty for driving with out a valid operator's license.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating proposed yesterday the appointment of a single Western allied commander in Berlin for the rapid countering of future Soviet moves there.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy discharged eight more civilian employes of his department yesterday for taking part in a strike of city drivers.

BRADENTON, Fla., Nov. 28 (UPI) Bob Charles, a New Zealand pro, continued his mastery of the DeSoto Lakes Golf and Country Club course today by shooting a three-under-par 68 in the opening round of the $10,000 national lefthanders golf tournament. In the pro-amateur event yesterday Charles carded a 69.
BEACHWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28 Mrs. Mary Smallridge Price, wife of Frank O. Price, a retired professor of architecture of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, died today in her home here.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, which last year played Beethoven's Ninth Symphony at the United Nations as a memorial to Dag Hammarskjold, last night played it at Carnegie Hall in the second of the four special concerts it is giving there under the sponsorship of the hall itself.
CAPTREE, L.I., Nov. 28 The last piece of structural steel was bolted into place today on the main span of the $9,000,000 bridge across the Fire Island Inlet.
Brooklyn College placed the cornerstone yesterday for a $1,500,000 student center.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Public counsel for the Maritime Administration asked the agency today to disapprove the application by a West Coast lumber concern for authority to use foreign flag ships to transport lumber over a domestic steamship route.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 28 The Icelandic Communist party ousted all Stalinists from its leadership at an all-night session that ended at 7 A.M. today.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28 Bruno Henry Walter of 428 3d Street, who retired in 1937 as manager of the order department of the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company, died yesterday at Paul Kimball Hospital here. His age was 82.
LONDON, Nov. 28--Price movements were small and irregular on the stock market today. Gains dominated the industrials.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 Regardless of a record that shows only four victories in nine games for the midshipmen, there is no lack of Navy enthusiasm, on or off the campus, over Saturday's football meeting with Army at Philadelphia.
Electric power production in the country totaled 16,109,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Nov. 24, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

The Republican campaign to re-elect Governor Rockefeller was one of the best-financed in the state's history; the Democratic financial effort behind Robert M. Morgenthau was one of the weakest in many years.
Military use of commercial air transportation to world trouble spots will reach a record this year, a spokesman for the Military Air Transport Service said yesterday.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Nov. 28 Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball, vice chancellor and controller emeritus of New York University, died Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital here after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived at Buckberg Mountain, Tomkins Cove.
Several million television viewers were doubtless surprised by the "Tonight" show Tuesday, when Maximilian Schell quietly moved to the piano keyboard and played a Chopin concerto excerpt.

BRADENTON, Fla., Nov. 28 Dr. George Wiley Sherburn, a former chairman of the Department of English at Harvard University and an authority on 17th-century and 18-century English literature, died today in his home at 3915 Ninth Avenue West. His age was 78.

Sir Patrick Dean, Britain's competent spokesman at the United Nations, has, in formal and authoritative manner, demonstrated statistically the often-related point that the greatest imperialist power in the world today is not Britain, not the United States, not France, not Belgium, not the Netherlands, but that breast-beating champion of the underdog, Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The Consumer Price Index declined slightly in October for the first time since last December.
It was no secret that Coach Lou Rossini and others close to the New York University basketball program expected a position high in the national ranking for the 1962-63 Violet court squad.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons broke two club records as they gained a 143-101 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
World sugar and cocoa futures led most New York commodities in an advance yesterday.
TRENTON, Nov. 28 The United States Civil Service Commission rejected two motions today by a state official to dismiss charges that he violated the Hatch Act.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28 (UPI) All but 13 employes returned to work today at three General Electric Company plants in this area after walking out yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI) Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. saw his curly coated polled Hereford bulls and heifers win 11 ribbons, including a first place, in breeding class judging at the International Livestock Exposition today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Good-natured and accus tomed to unpopular work that is David Elliott Bell.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 President Kennedy named Budget Director David E. Bell today as foreign-aid administrator.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., Nov. 28 A perfect day of wa terfowl gunning is an experi- ence shooters treasure and enjoy long after the guns have been racked and the birds eaten.
THE two games below from the recent Varna Olym pics show violent contrasts in style and effect. And there are good reasons for this.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Itkin of Flushing, Queens, and Putnam Valley, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Itkin, to Allen Schwartz of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schwartz of Louisville, Ky.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (UPI) E. Ross Buckley, a Republican candidate for Mayor in the recent municipal election here, filed suit in Federal Court today claiming damages from The New York Times for an article published during the Roman Catholic school desegregation crisis earlier this year.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 28 The Patent Trader, a semiweekly newspaper here, has bought Mount Kisco radio station WVIP.
Federal agents seized more than 35,000 tons of cocoa beans in Staten Island and Philadelphia warehouses yesterday, charging that the beans had become infested with insects.
Cotton futures rose 20 cents to $2.55 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. New crop months showed the most strength.

Mrs. Preston Davie, honorary chairman of the Manhattan Women's Division of the New York Heart Association, was hostess at a luncheon at her home at 71 East 71st Street yesterday which officially opened the annual fund-raising drive.

The steel business in Europe will be about the same in 1963 as in 1962, which means that demand will be somewhat weak, the head of one of the world's major special steel producers predicted here yesterday.
Negotiations for the sale of the New York Titan American Football League franchise continued here yesterday, but there were no indications as to when a deal would be made.
A use of electronics to improve the rhythm method of conception control was described by a physician here yesterday at the Human Factors Society meeting at the Barbiizon-Plaza Hotel.
The unnamed person with "a high sense of integrity" in S.E.C. Chairman William L. Cary's speech at the I.B.A. convention yesterday was Louis E. Walker.
The head of the Moreland Act Commission to Investigate Welfare said yesterday that its report would be ready for the Governor by the end of December.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 The United States is considering asking the United Nations aid program for Palestinian refugees be extended only one or two years instead of the usual three.

Gerry Jedd, a dramatic actress who appeared here in Off Broadway attractions as well as in the London production of "Two for the Seesaw," died yesterday after suffering a stroke Tuesday night while performing in "Brecht on Brecht." She was 37 years old and lived at 605 East 14th Street.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 28 (UPI) Teams of soldiers sorted twisted chunks of metal on a blackened hilltop today, hoping to find the flight recorder of the Varig Airlines jet plane that crashed yesterday minutes before it was to land here. All 97 persons aboard were killed.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday in heavy trading. Volume on the New York and American Stock Exchanges waa the heaviest since the height of the Cuban crisis a month ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28(AP) The Administration's pro posals for a tax cut next war were decried today by Repre sentative H.R. Gross as fiscal folly unless Government spending was also reduced.
Caroline Swann, producer of Harold Pinter's two one-act plays. "The Dumbwaiter," and "The Collection," now thriving off Broadway, is moving ahead with several Broadway projects.
The Canadian dollar strengthened in foreign exchange dealings here yesterday on increased commercial demand.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 Yemeni republicans here said today they would welcome an on-site investigation of the revolutionary Government's position in Yemen, as asked by their royalist rivals.

A painting by Jean Honore Fragonard. "La Jeunne Fille au Collier de Peries" was sold last night for $100,000 to E.J. Rousuck, a New York art dealer, at auction in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. It was from the collection of Charles Lederer.
WARSAW, Nov. 28 Wang Ping-nan, the Ambassador of Communist China, returned unexpectedly to Poland today.
LAURENS, S.C., Nov. 28 (AP) Dr. J. Erskine McDaniel, retired educator and former member of the United States Foreign Service, died yesterday in Laurens county hospital. He was 72 years old.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (UPI) A Christmas Eve wedding is planned by Lady Keeling and Patrick Hodgson, prominent Buffalo lawyer, who today announced their engagement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 21:
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 The right of the nation's railroads to make sweeping changes in work rules was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
BONN, Nov. 28 Chancellor Adenauer gave in to mounting pressure today and agreed to accept the demand of the Free Democrats that Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss be excluded from a new government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 Eight Nobel laureates in the San Francisco Bay area will receive 1962 Israel Commendation Awards here Saturday night.
YONKERS, Nov. 28 Less than two weeks ago, a provisional driver named Dick Brooks guided Gard Scott, a Class C-3 pacer all over the track at Yonkers Raceway.
Two members of the Tactical Patrol Force who were indicted on a charge of police brutality against a citizen were arrested yesterday and suspended from the force.

The National Association of Manufacturers charged yesterday that the Government had aided the International Association of Machinists by asserting it would be the company's fault if the union struck Lockheed.
The National Broadcasting Company will show a series of Hollywood feature films on Monday evenings (7:30 to 9:30 P.M.) beginning Feb. 4.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) The Post Office Department will add a five-digit number to everyone's address after July 1. The new number will be called the zip code.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 28--The Dutch went into mourning today for Princess Wilhelmina, who died quietly in her sleep early this morning at her palace at Het Loo.
Sweet, indeed, are the uses of adversity in the National Football League especially if you happen to be a head coach and the adversity in question befalls somehody else's club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The State Department laid down a policy today permitting the International Atomic Energy Agency and its control system to be bypassed in the sale of a large atomic power plant to India.
A 2,400-seat, multimillion-dollar theater will be built at the 1964 New York World's Fair, Robert Moses announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28 A formal warning about the dangers in the use of "minddistorting drugs" was issued to undergraduates of Harvard College yesterday.

The New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday filed a motion in Federal Court to switch the bankruptcy proceeding of Delay Stores, Inc., from a voluntary Chapter XI petition to an involuntary Chapter X petition.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 A financial and political mission to the United States by Dr. Francisco Santiago Dantas adviser to President Jo o Goulart, has been postponed, probably until early next year.

The Inter-American Development Bank, in its first attempt to raise funds in United States capital markets, will sell $75,000,000 of 20-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate headed by Lazard Freres Co., Lehman Brothers and Blyth Co., Inc.

MRS. DOROTHY HARDY of East Meadow, L.I., a leading professional handler invited to speak on the question, "Do judges judge dogs or people?" at the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club meeting yesterday, analyzed the many types of dog judges she had encountered and then answered ...

The last of the stakes races for 2-year-olds on the local racing calendar turned out to be the medium through which Steve DiMauro gained his first New York stakes triumph yesterday. A former jockey who now trains for Thomas Eazor of Pittsburgh, DiMauro sent Rocky Link into the $29,700 Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct in the best of competitive shape.
GENEVA, Nov. 28 Neutral Sweden attempted today to end the impasse between the Soviet Union and the United States over a treaty to forbid nuclear testing.
MOSCOW, Nov. 28 An informed source reported tonight that Premier Khrushchev himself had sanctioned the new de-Stalinization trend in Soviet literature.
The Green Bay Packers, who were beaten for the first time this season by Detroit on Thanksgiving Day, have been replaced as team leaders in both total offense and defense.
RARELY does a theater ring with the magnif icence of language that can be mined from Herman Melville's pages and entrusted to the resounding tongues of actors.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 28 (UPI) The South Carolina, Supreme Court reversed today the breach of peace convictions of 42 Negro students who were arrested in one of the first waves of sit-in domonstrations two years ago.

Gustav Abrahamson, realty investor and builder, has completed a motel with 56 rooms on the Manasquan River in Point Pleasant, N.J. He has obtained a first mortgagecommitment of $750,000 on the motel for three years at 6 per cent interest. It was arranged by Henry Baker, a New York broker.

Gilbert Tilles, realty investor and developer, has bought 10 acres on New York Avenue in Huntington, L.I., for construction of 100,000 square feet of additional store space at the adjoining Huntington Shopping Center.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) The Defense Department named 36 Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force pilots today to receive Distinguished Flying Crosses for their reconnaissance flights during the Cuban crisis.
Joseph P. Kennedy, the father of the President, tended to business affairs at his office here yesterday and prepared to go to Florida for the winter.
A new addition to the growing list of industry shows, the first International Communications Fair, opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum.
Leaders of the Zionist movement said here last night that only the strengthening of Zionism could assure the survival of every phase of Jewish religious and cultural life.
ALBANY, Nov. 28 Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino predicted today that a redistricting bill for the New York Civil Court would be enacted at the coming session of the Legislature.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla. Nov. 28 Following are excerpts from a speech here today by William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before the convention of the Investment Bankers Association:

LONDON, Nov. 28 Miss Barbara Fell, a senior Government information officer, was charged today with violating the Official Secrets Act by lending confidential Foreign Office documents to a member of the Yugoslav Embassy.

Robert Shaldjian, who recently leased 10,000 square feet of space in the Sperry Rand Building, Avenue of the Americas and 51st Street, to the International Harvester Company in conjunction with W. Bingham Cox of the James H. Burns Company, is an assistant vice president of Albert B. Ashorth, Inc. Mr. Shaldjian was incorrectly listed in these columns as a broker with Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 28--The Government of Premier Cyrille Adoula survived a vote of no confidence in Parliament today.

ANY American woman who ever visited Paris on a budget will sigh with envy at the thought of Jacqueline Garry, who regularly spends millions of francs (and close to $1,000,000) buying French fashions, food and furniture.

Events today: "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 7:15 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Sir John Barbirolli, conductor, Gina Bachauer, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Ernst Ulmer, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Matthew Raimondi, violinist, and Yehudi Wyner, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30.
Prospects for changing the state's Condon-Wadlin Act which forbids strikes by public employes and provides strong penalties for violators, appeared strengthened yester

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 2 (AP) Vanderbilt University hired a new football coach today with implied instructions to start the Commodores winning more games in rugged Southeastern Conference competition.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Bisland Duval have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Elizabeth Duval to Charles Getchell Van Gorder Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Gorder of Cottonwood, Ariz.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP) Bill Zakoor rode Sam H. Rogers Jr.'s Cyclopavia to a seven-length victory today in the $28,075 La Petite Stakes at Garden State Park.

PARIS, Nov. 28 President de Gaulle commuted today to life imprisonment the death sentences imposed on former Gen. Edmond Jouhaud and Andr Canal, leaders of the terrorist Secret Army Organization in Algeria and France.

The National Broadcasting Company and the American Broadcasting Company formally dissociated themselves yesterday from the views of LeRoy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, on the subject of cigarette advertising on radio and television.
TRENTON, Nov. 28 (AP) A state legislative commission reported today that some people make a profit from illness by getting duplicate hospitalization insurance.

MANILA, Nov. 28 (AP) The Government of the Philippines has authorized the importation of 1,100,000 kilos (about 2,600,000 pounds) of Virginia-leaf tobacco by a Philippines company, which has agreed to purchase 9,900,000 kilos of Philippine tobacco.
Maurice Jay Racusin, a reporter on The New York Herald Tribune and a predecessor, The New York Tribune, for 44 years, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 28 The South Vietnamese Government's strike into the Communist sanctuary called Zone D appears to be the most unsuccessful of the major operations to date.

GARY, Ind., Nov. 28 (UPI) L.B. Worthington, president of the United States Steel Corporation announced today that continuous heat-treating facilities will be installed at the new 160/210-inch plate mill at Gary. It will take 13 months to do the work.
PERTH, Australia, Nov. 28 (UPI) In another recordbreaking spree on the fifth days of the Empire and Common- wealth Games, swimmers erased two world and five Games marks today.
PARIS, Nov. 28 The French Olympic Committee, by a 19-to-5 vote, last night chose Lyons over Paris as France's candidate to stage the 1968 Olympic Games.

THE Bolshoi Ballet's return to New York last night brought not one but two shows to Madison Square Garden. The dance company from Moscow was the center of attention while it was on stage, but during intermissions most eyes in the audience were fixed on Loge 36.

PARIS, Nov. 28 The governing Ministerial Council of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development adopted a resolution today stressing the "interdependence" of trade and aid for the poorer countries and giving the organization a new role in this special aspect of the trade field.
A railroad crane toppled off a 40-foot-high IND elevated track onto a street in Coney Island yesterday, killing three men.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) President Kennedy will visit Nevada during his forthcoming Western tour of military and atomic energy facilities, the White House announced today.
Bonds called for redemption before maturity in November totaled $152,724,000, a 66 per cent increase over redemptions in the month a year ago and a 37.1 per cent rise above October figures.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Nov. 28 The Westchester County Penitentiary here was inspected today by the 23 members of a county grand jury, investigating charges that W. Scott Davis of Yonkers, a Negro lawyer, has been abused at the penitentiary because of his race.

DALLAS, Nov. 28 (AP) The Southern Association of Colleges and Schools put Mississippi's state colleges and universities on probation today with a warning that accreditation might be lifted at any time.
SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 28 The Rev. Dr. Francis Carr Stifler, former secretary for public relations of the American Bible Society, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Roswell H. Whitman, a career foreign service officer whose last post was Minister of Economic Affairs at the embassy in Tokyo, died Tuesday night at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 The Defense Department is ordering precautions in all the military services against the possibility that emotionally unstable persons may somehow get near nuclear weapons and set them off.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Indian authorities confirmed reports today that New Delhi had shifted large forces from the frontiers of Pakistan to northern border regions to face the Chinese Communists.

The Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich and the Merry-Go-Round, two organizations of Greenwich, Conn., will benefit from the fifth annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar to be held today, tomorrow and Saturday at the State Armory in Greenwich.
LONDON, Nov. 28 Tyrone Guthrie's modern-dress production of Ben Jonson's "The Alchemist," which opened at the Old Vic Theatre tonight, is a triumph of the director's art.

THE mysteries of marbleizing and antiquing furniture are being unlocked this week on the fourth floor of W J Sloane's. Thomas Gautier is demonstrating through Saturday how to finish at home traditional unpainted furniture. A different finishing method is recommended for each of the two Italian lines that Sloane's has imported.
A new subway entrance at the 66th Street station of the IRT Broadway-Seventh Avenue line will be opened today. It leads into the lobby of Philharmonic Hall of Lincoln Center.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 28 (AP)--Never Bend, who won seven of 10 races and a record total of $402,969 in his first year of racing, was named the champion 2-year-old colt of 1962 today by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' Board of Selection.
A psychiatrist testified yesterday in Federal District Court that Jack Soble's mental condition had improved to the point where he was now a competent witness.
New York County Democrats were divided yesterday over a choice for a nominee for Election Commissioner from Manhattan and a program of voting reform.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 28 Coach Paul Dietzel of Army's football team is ignoring Navy's charge that the cadet style of kickoff return might be illegal.

The chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee said yesterday that the group would seek modification of the rent control law. The committee represents the real estate boards in the five boroughs and property owners.
An increase of 593,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell warned motion picture houses in the Times Square area yesterday that their licenses would be revoked if they did not clean up sidewalk displays of "lurid and flamboyant" advertising.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 Infectious hepatitis sometimes causes most of the damage to the liver before the patient even knows he is sick, an expert on this disease told the meeting of the American Medical Association that ended here today.
In an arrangement to speed Christmas shopping trips for Staten Islanders, the Port Richmond Board of Trade will subsidize express bus service by the Transit Authority.

WARSAW, Nov. 28 Poland and West Germany began trade negotiations today with a hint of a thaw in the frigid political relations of the two Governments. Bonn, for the first time, sent to Warsaw a Foreign Ministry official, Helmut Allard, to conduct the talks on a new trade agreement.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) Eddie Crouse of Glen Allen, Va., was named the winner today of the 1962 national driving title in the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, modified division.

A CURIOUS selection closed last night's Boston Sym phony concert at Philharmonic Hall. Erich Leinsdorf conducted the orchestra in Arnold Schoenberg's orchestration of the Brahms G minor Piano Quartet. It is a strange inconsistency that Schoenberg, the great avant-gardist, felt

TRENTON, Nov. 28 Two men drank four ounces of liquor each while having a chicken dinner today and then submitted to a Drunkometer test to show that a proposed new law would not affect the "social" drinker.
Leo J. Linder, president of the New York City chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, died early yesterday in his home at 670 West End Avenue. He was 62 years old.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 28 (AP) Stan Niewierowski, a former North Carolina State College basketball player, testified today that he and a teammate, Anton Muehlbauer, had received $3,250 in the mail for holding down the score against Duke University on Jan. 7, 1961.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Despite a persistent barrage of Communist opposition, the Indonesian Government has asked the United States for Peace Corps volunteers.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 28 The minor leaguers, on the eve of bringing their annual convention to a close tomorrow, found themselves with a fresh headache tonight.
The bond market turned in another indecisive performance yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that all registered investment companies would be required as of Jan. 1 to keep more detailed records. The move would apply to both open and closed-end investment companies and small business investment Companies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 A draft resolution urging the independence of Oman was approved today by the General Assembly's Special Political Committee.

WOODMERE, L.I., Nov. 28 Nat Fischell, Eastern division sales manager of the Foster Grant Company, Inc., of New York and Leominster, Mass., manufacturers of sun glasses and other plastic products, died here today in his home at 515 Green Place. His age was 50.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., attained record sales and earnings in the three, nine and 12 months ended Nov. 3, according to yesterday's report of Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, and Ralph Lazarus, president. The company's 12 department-store divisions include Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus.

Arlen Properties, Inc., realty investors and developers, have announced plans for a 35-acre shopping center in Port Chester, N.Y., part of which will be a two-story store to be occupied by E.J. Korvette, Inc., national department store chain.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, spoke softly to the Investment Bankers Association here today, but he left no doubt in anyone's mind that he carried a big stick and was ready to cut a bigger one if he decided it was needed.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 28 W. Averell Harriman, United States Assistant Secretary of State, arrived today to seek Pakistani support to meet a Chinese Communist threat to South Asia.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 28 (UPI) The State Supreme Court heard arguments and took under advisement today the question of who won Minnesota's gubernatorial election.
Twenty-three holders of liquor licenses turned over their records for the last five years to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday in the investigation of the State Liquor Authority.
ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP)--A state appellate court held today that the Korean conflict was a war, even though the Government never officially declared it to be so.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 28--Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson suffered two major defeats today when the Board of Supervisors rejected his proposed budget for 1963 and unanimously overrode his veto on a sewage disposal plan.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 28 Three national masters' championships were decided today in the fifth day of the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here.
The Board of Education was advised yesterday to go slow in making sweeping changes in the administrative structure of the school system.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday reported the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) The Amateur Athletic Union opened its 75th national convention today with secret sessions at which delegates were informed of progress made toward forming a track and field coalition with the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
MIAMI, Nov. 28 Albert Pflueger, a well-known fish taxidermist and sportsman, was found dead in his home here today. He had apparently fallen down a flight of stairs.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 28 (Reuters) The three Laotian factions have agreed to form a unified national army of 30,000 men.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, said today that the Soviet Union's new economic control agency would make "every worker in every job" a watchman over the implementation of party and government directives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 President Kennedy moved today to end the strike by the International Association of Machinists against the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Com-mencement address at graduation exercises from Santa Claus school:

BILOXI, Miss., Nov. 28 (UPI) United States District Judge Harold Cox of Jackson has ordered James P. McShane, United States chief marshal, to appear here Dec. 11 to answer questions in connection with a damage suit, brought by a student at the University of Mississippi, it was learned today.
The scholarship fund of the Bank Street College of Education will benefit from a theater party at next Wednesday evening's performance of "Beyond the Fringe" at the Golden Theater.

The Consolidated Edison Company confirmed last night that it had withdrawn its request to the Public Service Commission to eliminate redistribution of electricity by building owners to sub-tenants, as opposed to prime tenants.
PARIS, Nov. 28 European stock exchanges have shown the strongest rise in the past week since the temporary technical recovery following Black Monday at the end of May.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI)--Wheat and soybean futures declined today on the Board of Trade. Rye prices advanced, and corn and oats were mixed in a narrow range.

The sixth and final autumn benefit for the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will be on Saturday. The event will be a fair called "Holiday in New York Gala" and will be at the beneficiary's headquarters at 30 Third Avenue, between Atlantic Avenue and State Street, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

The Pennsylvania Railroad upheld yesterday one of its favorite traditions and declared a 25 cents a share dividend. The action was taken even though the railroad expects to report a substantial operating loss this year.

MEXICO has a cuisine of tremendous variety, and devotees of Mexican food are just about the most enthusiastic of all. One of the most dedicated is Barbara de Zouche Palmer, a recent resident of New York and now a frequent visitor from her home in Washington.
The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered a trial yesterday to determine whether the city had acted illegally in contracting to purchase voting machines without competitive bidding.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 The Soviet Union agreed today to the election of U Thant to a full term as Secretary General.

Kentucky borrowed $25,000,000 on highway bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 3.0717 per cent. The bonds were sold to the Northern Trust Company and associated managing bankers on a bid of 100.12468.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Dr. Edward Teller said today that the peaceful use of atomic explosives had "the potentiality of becoming the first really important and thoroughly economic use of atomic energy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) Representative Wayne Hays said today that a former Ambassador th Spain cost the United States a quarter of a million dollars by refusing to live in a new Embassy residence because "it was too modern."

PEKING, Nov. 28 (Reuters) Marshal Chen Yi, the Communist Chinese Foreign Minister, said today that "all underhand schemes of hostility and subversion against the Albanian People's Republic are doomed to failure."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 29 (AP)--Communist North Korea charged today that the United Nations Command tried to cover up a "shameful murder" by accusing the Communists of killing an American soldier at a United Nations observer post in the demilitarized zone Nov. 20.
The Richmond County Country Club, which had been resisting attempts by the city to acquire its 123-acre golf course, has agreed to accept $4,000,000 for the property.

A group of youths cruising on the West Side last night in an old car opened fire on a dozen boys and girls who had just left a club meeting in a church. Two were injured slightly. Their assailants fled.

TOOWOOMBA, Australia, Nov. 28 (Reuters) An unbeaten innings of 128 in 120 minutes by Peter Parfitt helped the Marylebone Cricket Club beat Queensland Country by seven wickets in their one-day cricket match today.

JERUSALEM, Israel, Nov. 28 (UPI) Shalom Shtarkes pleaded not guilty in Jerusalem today on a charge of having abducted his 10-year-old nephew. Yosef Schumacher, who was found earlier this year in Brooklyn after a two-year search.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 28 (UPI) A county judge opened the way today for a ruling by a higher court on whether James E. Mills, editor of The Birmingham Post-Herald, had violated state laws by publishing an editorial on election day.

PARIS, Nov. 28 John Hay Whitney, editor and publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, received the vermeil medal of the City of Paris today to mark the 75th year of publication of the European edition of the newspaper.
A maritime labor arbitrator has censured a deck-officer union for striking the atomic liner Savannah.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Cuba lost some of her leading economic aides in yesterday's crash of a Brazilian airliner in Peru.
ROME, Nov. 28 Pope John XXIII was ill today and reports persisted despite informal denials that he might undergo surgery soon.
Jerry Finkelstein, New York City public relations man turned corporation executive, has resigned as chairman of All-State Properties, Inc., a real estate development company he joined in May, 1961.
HONG KONG, Nov. 28--Communist China is carrying on a determined diplomatic offensive to gain the support of Asian and African states in its frontier dispute with India.
Roy Sarles Durstine, a founder of the advertising agency now known as Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 410 East 57th Street.
MIAMI, Nov. 28 (AP) The North-South football game director said today that two Florida A. and M. players would be asked to play on the South team in the Dec. 22 Orange Bowl charity contest.
The International Silver Company yesterday declared a special year-end stock dividend of 4 per cent on the common stock, payable Dec. 28 to record Dec. 7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 The 2 to 1 division in the Federal Constitutional Court in New York this week over the legality of the boundaries fixed by the state Legislature for Manhattan's four Congressional districts is only the latest evidence of the confusion the Supreme Court can create when it declares a new public policy as "the law of the land," assigns its enforcement to the courts below, but supplies them with no tangible guide-lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) Government witnesses testified today that the tax payers faced a $450,956,100 "paper loss" on the tungsten stockpile, and that some companies received large windfall profits on tungsten sales.
Although a great many coloring books have recently been designed to amuse adults, there still are coloring books for children. Among the newest of these are two from Doubleday Co.
The Newspaper Guild of New York and The New York Post resumed negotiations last night after a breakdown "in bargaining on a new two-year contract had threatened a strike.
VALLEY STREAM, L.L., Nov. 28 Trading stamps have replaced gold stars for excellence in the third grade at the Brooklyn Avenue school.
LYNDHURST, N.J., Nov. 28 Former Mayor Carmine Savino Sr. died of cancer early this morning in his home at 801 Ridge Road here. He was 88 years old.

"Advertising for pain-killing remedies is often noisy, repetitious and offensive. It operates on the false assumption that you have to hammer the customer over the head in order to sell him a headache pill."

The IBM World Trade Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday the election of two new directors. They are Joseph F. Cullman 3d and Grant G. Simmons Jr.

Karel J.V. Nikijuluw, a native of Amboina island, in the Moluccas, Indonesia, who had been here for 12 years, trying to establish the claim of the South Moluccas to indepenpence, died on Saturday in his residence at 310 East 44th Street. His age was 57.

An investment banking group headed jointly by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc. and Blyth Co. was awarded $7,500,000 of Southern Electric Generating Company 30-year first mortgage bonds at competitive bidding yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 28 The walls of St. Peter's Basilica echoed today to the beat of tom-toms the rhythm of African chants and the staccato clapping o hands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) Senator Clifford P. Case criticized today what he called a double standard of ethics permitting members of Congress to have financial interest in stocks and law firms while forbidding appointive officials to have similar holdings.

United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had revised its prices and classifications for secondary sheet steel products. These are sheet items with defects that disqualify them for prime rating.
The thoroughbred racing season in this state will end today after 220 racing days.

The Delta Prize of $5,000 will not be awarded for this year because, in the opinion of the judges, no manuscript submitted achieved the over-all standards of literary excellence required. Therefore, the 1963 award will be $10,000, half of which will be an outright grant and the remainder an advance against royalties. The judges
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 An Arab spokesman said today that any effort to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the Palestine refugee problem was doomed to failure.

Dom Joao and Dona Fatima of Orleans-Braganca, guests of honor at the Imperial Ball in the Plaza last night, were saluted with songs and dances from their native Brazil, and by a specially created sauce on Seafood Braganga (over pilaff of rice).
AFTER "Harold" there are two of us whose ears are humming. The other is Anthony Perkins.

THE big regatta of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association this season will be on either the Shrewsbury River or Budd Lake in Northern New Jersey. It is scheduled for Jan. 12-13, but more likely, it will take place on Jan. 26-27, or Feb. 9-10, or Feb. 23-24, or March 2-3--if the...
ST. PAUL, Nov. 29 The Minnesota Canvassing Board declared Gov. Elmer L. Andersen, a Republican, re-elected today by a 142-vote margin.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UPI) Wheat futures declined today on the Board of Trade. Corn and oats advanced, and soybean and rye futures were mixed.
DETROIT, Nov. 29 (UPI) Car production this week is expected to reach a new weekly high of 170,645 units, Automotive News said today.
It may not be long before City College, one of New York's pioneers in collegiate basketball, starts meeting more major local opponents again.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (UPI) Camille Henry scored two goals on the New York Rangers rejuvenated front lines tonight as the Rangers handed the Detroit Red Wings their worst drubbing of the season, 5 0, in a National Hockey League contest.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) Manufacturers reported new orders at a record clip in October but sales slid 1 per cent from their September peak, the Commerce Department said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 President Kennedy and a galaxy of stage and political stars played to a full house of $100a-plate diners here tonight, but scarcely anyone understood a thing that was going on.
The president of Republic Steel Corporation yesterday urged an immediate "investment-spurring" Federal income tax cut and suggested a sales tax to offset the reduced revenue from the income levy.
Edward Cornell Zabriskie, who retired in 1944 as principal of Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place, died yesterday in his home at 222 Central Park South. His age was 89.
Bank clearings in the nation fell 21 per cent to $27,473,021,000 in the week ended Wednesday after reaching a high for the year in the preceding week.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 New Jersey Labor Commissioner Raymond F. Male took the witness stand today in an attempt to refute charges that he had violated the Federal Hatch Act by engaging in political activity.

The best way to bring about modification of a defective law is to enforce it. Thus, ironically, Police Commissioner Murphy's unique and instant discharge of a number of civilians in his department who joined the city drivers' strike may prove to be the catalyst that finally impels an immovable Legislature to revision of the Condon-Wadlin Law.
A coloring book that lampoons Premier Khrushchev has been banned from Army post exchanges in the New York area on the ground that it "lacked propriety."
Directors of the Royal National Bank of New York and directors of Gotham Bank are scheduled to meet today to approve the merger of the two institutions.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25 The Soviet Union is exploring the layers of rock beneath its forests, steppes, lakes and deserts to an extent never before undertaken by any nation.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 Critics here praised today the British revival of "The School for Scandal," which had its American premiere at the Shubert Theater last night.
Miss Adrienne Claire Trebilcock and Lawrence Gove Evans plan to be married in June.
Maynard C. Wheeler, president of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, appeared in three courts here yesterday to fight extradition to Texas for trial on antitrust charges.
WHEN Y.A. Tittle joined the Giants, he offered mild objection to the fact that Ray Wietecha, the center, set up the huddle eight yards back of the ball instead of 12.

SIR JOHN BARBIROLLI took over the podium of the New York Philharmonic last night, starting a twoweek stint. He led off with the world premiere of Darius Milhaud's "Ouverture Philharmonique," a work commissioned by the Philharmonic for its opening season in Lincoln Center and, also, in celebration of the composer's 70th year.
A circus came to town last night, not colossal in size but as full of mirth and excitement as a circus ought to be.
A Federal mediator reported yesterday that 'some progress has been made and a work stoppage has been averted" in negotiations between the Newspaper Guild of New York and The New York Post.
