HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 29 (AP) Charles Schnee, who won an Academy Award in 1952 for his screenplay "The Bad and the Beautiful," died of a heart attack taday at the age of 46.

A multitude of rumors and published reports created such a stream of sell orders in the common stock of General Plywood Corporation that trading in the issue had to be halted three times yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 Recurrent allegations of United States military assistance to Portuguese territorial governments in Africa were emphatically denied today by the United States.

Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, who made news in Rome while starring in 20th Century-Fox's $35,000,000 "Cleopatra," are being considered for leads in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The V.I.P.'s," an original screenplay by Terence Rattigan. M-G-M plans to begin production at the company's Elstree Studios in London early in January.

ROME, Nov. 29 The beatification of Mother Elizabeth Ann Seton, founder of the Sisters of Charity in America, appeared imminent today when the Vatican's Congregation of Rites took under review two miracles attributed to her.
Six Westchester County communities face the prospect of a bus strike tomorrow after company and union negotiators remained wide apart yesterday in contract renewal talks.
Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam ordered a trial yesterday to determine whether certain amendments to the Hospital Code were constitutional.
YONKERS, Nov. 29 As inevitably as most players run out of money, the 1962 harness racing season will run out of time tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
The "Mona Lisa" will probably come to the United States next February. Negotiations for a loan of the painting are in progress in Paris and Washington.
Premier Abdirashid Ali Shermarke of the Somali Republic received the key to New York City last night from Mayor Wagner.
Mark Zborowski was convicted in Federal District Court yesterday for the second time on a perjury charge.

The city's Department of Purchase, which usually deals in things like vitrified clay sewer pipe and asphalt paving mixture for cold patching, had an interval of mild hilarity yesterday when it auctioned off 34 surplus zoo animals for $793.50.

MANY inventories in Colonial America of the 17th century list but a single silver spoon. Silver objects were then prized possessions and, in the absence of banks, indicated financial standing and social status for the wealthy. For the less moneyed, they often represented security.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) The new president of the Investment Bankers Association of America said today the investment banking business had made some mistakes and "grown too fast."

Harold W. Powers, a Boston candy manufacturer, took over yesterday as the new president of the Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc. He led a group of dissident stockholders in a successful proxy fight last month which removed Leonard D. Griffiths from the presidency.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) Eight airlines that help each other during strikes said today their aid agreement was legal and helped stabilize the industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov.29 (UPI) President Kennedy will fly by helicopter to the Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia Saturday, it was announced today.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP) A univversity president hailed today new laboratories made possible by the Kennedy Foundation as a key to solving mental retardation problems already affecting more than 5,000,000 Americans.
"A handshake agreement" on the merger of Walston Co., Inc. and Cruttenden, Podesta Miller was announced yesterday. The two brokerage houses plan to operate under the Walston name effective Jan.1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The nuclear rocket project, promoted by its developers as the way to take man to the planets, is facing a budgetary crisis.
A new type of concert artist made an appearance last night at the Museum of Modern Art a virtuoso of the tape recorder.
LONDON, Nov. 29 The stock market turned dull today. Most leading stocks fell a few pennies.
President and Mrs. Kennedy headed a cast of 100 last night in a closed-circuit show televised from five cities for the benefit of the National Cultural Center in Washington.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 Richard T. Gosser, a vice president of the United Automobile Workers, was relieved of union responsibilities today as a result of his indictment yesterday on a charge of tampering with Internal Revenue Service files.
The city school system could obtain $24,000,000 more in state aid annually if it raised the pupil attendance rate to the level recommended by the State Education Department.
BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 29 Scientists gathered here today to mark the anniversary of a program born 75 years ago in a drab attic room of the old Marine Hospital on Staten Island.
United States imports in October were slightly higher than in the 1961 month, the Census Bureau reported in Washington yesterday.

The central Government will by September present and support in Parliament, until it is placed in effect, a draft constitution that will establish a Federal Government for the Congo. To this end, the central Government has requested the United Nations to make available to it the services of international experts in federal constitutional law.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29 Wayne Hardin "shot the breeze" with Army's football coach, Paul Dietzel, in an amiable telephone conversation today before he sent Navy through its final workout for the service game in Philadelphia Saturday.

Paul Schoffler was to have returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night to sing the role of Hans Sachs in the company's fifth performance of "Die Meistersinger." However, the German baritone became ill late in the afternoon, and Otto Edelmann stepped in. Mr. Edelmann had last sung the role here in 1958.
WEST PALM BEACH Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) Rod Funseth of Spokane, Wash., and Butch Baird of Galveston, Tex., shot 68's today for the first-round lead in the $20,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament.
PARIS, Nov. 29 At the Vieux-Colombier Theater, the three Paul Claudel plays known as the Coufontaine Trilogy are being performed for the first time together in repertory.
PARIS, Nov. 29 (Reuters) Three hundred and fifty girls made their formal entry into society tonight at a glittering International Debutantes Ball, the highlight of the winter social season of Paris.

Walter J. Mara will make his final climb up the patrol judge's ladder for the ninth race on today's program at Aqueduct. Then he will go into voluntary retirement. He will reach his 65th birthday tomorrow, but that's not the reason he's quitting. The mandatory age for retirement with the New York Racing Association is 70.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 29 India and Pakistan announced today an agreement to negotiate their bitter dispute over possession of the state of Kashmir.
The top officials at Time, Inc. have come up with an interesting theory about the future of the magazine business.

A STRANGER to economic necessity from birth, free to pursue any whim, William Averell Harriman has perplexed the less affluent by his apparently insatiable appetite for work. He has filled most of his adult years with public service, and, at 71, he is still at work. A favorite interna-

Ernest Ulmer, Nebraskaborn pianist who made his debut here 12 years ago, gave his fourth New York recital last night at Town Hall. His relatively brief program had as its longest selections the Beethoven Sonata in D (Op. 10, No. 3), and Ernest Bloch's Sonata (1935).

PERTH, Australia, Nov. 29 (AP) Brian Kilby, a slightly built runner from Coventry, England, won the marathon today in capping a surge of track and field successes for British athletes in the Empire and Commonwealth Games.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 29 (AP) The Bavarian Ministry of Justice announced today that its chief prosecutor in Wurzburg, Dr. Karl Kolb, had been suspended pending investigation of a war crimes complaint against him.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 29 (AP)--Negroes attempted today to desegregate the State Capitol cafeteria and a courtroom where an integration leader went on trial.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office hinted yesterday that it would soon be ready to present evidence to a grand jury in its investigation of the State Liquor Authority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) Arthur Sylvester, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, contended today that the Pentagon's record of the last 22 months did not support the view by an organization of editors that the release of legitimate news had been curtailed.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29 Army's football squad left tonight for its traditional clash with Navy Saturday after an unusual ceremony. In the final practice session at Michie Stadium this afternoon, 13 seniors were called upon individually to tackle Roger Staubach of Navy in effigy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Department-store sales in the week ended Nov. 24 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.

Ground was broken yesterday for the Chinese Pavilion at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. The four-story, 78-foot-high structure will occupy a 25,000-square-foot site near the Unisphere, the symbol of the fair.
Bond prices were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday.

Henry Edward Abt, president of Brand Names Foundation, Inc., 292 Madison Avenue, died yesterday of a heart attack at St. Barnabas Hospital in Minneapolis, while on a business trip. His age was 58. He lived at 10 East 38th Street and in Ithaca, N.Y.
PARIS, Nov. 29 The Legion of Honor, one of France's bestknown status symbols, is going to become harder to get.

Plans for the formation of a Metropolitan Thoroughbred Breeders Association are to be discussed at a luncheon meet ing at Alfani's Restaurant in Huntington, L.I., Dec. 8. The breeding of race horses is in creasing on Long Island; the new group aims at furthering the interest of breeders on the island and throughout New York State.
LEVITTOWN, Pa., Nov. 29 Ira G. Goldman, vice president and general counsel of Levitt Sons, Inc., builders of this community, died of a heart attack today in his home here. He was 55 years old.
ABOARD THE R.M.S. SYLVANIA, AT SEA. IF Noah had dispatched a fulmar or shearwater from the Ark he would never have received back the plucked olive leaf. They do not take much interest in trees.
PARIS, Nov. 29 The practically moribund European Monetary agreement will be renewed for another year with one change, it has been decided here.
A 66-year-old Detroit grandmother and New York's Henry Street Settlement received the 14th Lane Bryant Annual Awards yesterday for outstanding voluntary contributions to the American community.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 29 The American Contract Bridge League's 36th annual national tournament continued today with the two preliminary sessions of the openteam contest, one of the two principal events of the eightday tournament.
BAD GODESBERG, Germany, Nov. 29 Anti-Communist Yugoslav exiles smashed their way into the building of the Yugoslav trade mission here today, hurling bombs and setting rooms afire.

Some educators believe that the best way to bring up children is to "adjust" them to all the ways of the adult world, no matter how undesirable some of those ways may be. It should therefore not come as too much of a surprise that a school in Long Island has authorized an arrangement with a supermarket under which third-graders get trading stamps for every A on their report cards.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 29 Miss Sidna Brower, editor of The Mississippian, campus newspaper of the University of Mississippi, was denounced today by a student committee for her editorials on the desegregation rioting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Defense Department contradicted today a published report that significant changes would be made in the Administration's program to reorganize and cut back the Army National Guard and Reserves.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 "Good seed doesn't cost, it pays."

The May Department Stores Company, which operates 51 downtown and branch stores in large metropolitan areas, from Baltimore to Los Angeles, yesterday reported increased earnings for the three, nine and 12 months ended Oct. 31. Thirdquarter sales declined from a year ago, but were higher for the nine-month and 12-month periods, according to Morton D. May, president.
BONN, Nov. 29 The way was suddenly opened tonight for a speedy solution of the month-old Government crisis.

BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 29 Striking workers of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation returned to their jobs today at Government request, ending a two-day walkout. But they said the dispute that caused the strike was far from over.
The Eagles of Boston College and the Hurricanes of Miami probably will be the opponents in New York's Gotham Bowl game at Yankee Stadium Dec. 15 if they win their games tomorrow.
Stock prices rose slightly yesterday in heavy trading. The advance had a more sluggish tone than the gains of other recent sessions.
United Air Lines has promoted George E. Keck to executive vice president general manager.

DIANA VREELAND, former fashion editor of Harper's Bazaar who now is associate editor of Vogue magazine, will succeed Jessica Daves as Vogue's editor-in-chief on Jan. 1. The announcement, long expected in the world of fashion, was made yesterday by I.S.V.Patcevitch, president and chairman of the board of Conde Nast Publications, Inc.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 29 (AP) Erik Scavenius, Premier and Foreign Secretary of Denmark during World War II, died here today at the age of 85.
LIMA, Peru, Nov. 29 (UPI) The Government said today it still had not been able to complete the identification of the 97 victims of a Varig Airlines jet crash earlier this week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Rail and truckloadings, both affected by the Thanksgiving Day holiday, showed sizable decreases from the preceding week.

The D.P. Winne Company, a paper and twine concern that was organized 100 years ago, has leased 2,500 square feet of space in the new 25-story office building at 211 East 43d Street. The company will move in January from 30 Church Street. Gil Robinov and Barry Smith, associate vice presidents of Williams Co., were the brokers.

The Filipino Communities Executive Council, Inc., will give a dance tonight in the Windsor Ballroom of the Commodore. Proceeds will be donated to the fund for the proposed Children's Museum and Library in the Philippines.

The Security Council and General Assembly of the United Nations are scheduled to meet today to elect U Thant of Burma as the new Secretary General. The United States and Soviet Russia have already agreed on this choice and the election is now regarded as a foregone conclusion. Mr. Thant will serve until 1966.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra opened its 51st season its last under the baton of Enrique Jorda at the War Memorial Opera House last night.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP) The verbal war for control of track and field in the United States flared anew tonight. The new United States Track and Field Federation charged that a coalition plan approved by key Amateur Athletic Union officials reneged on the original agreement.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 29 Baseball's top-ranking minor leagues today solved the vexing problem that had threatened to rock the structure of organized baseball.

During most of his career with the New York Giants, Phil (Chief) King has worked alone on the sidelines with downcast eyes, trying not to call attention to himself. As a crippled and therefore expendable halfback, he lived in perpetual fear that his tenuous connection with the club would be severed without so much as a by your leave.
Britain's Ambassador to the United States, Sir David Ormsby Gore, said yesterday that his nation probably would not enter the Common Market before the end of next year.
Lumber production in the country totaled 206,789,000 board feet in the week ended Nov. 24, according to reports received yesterday from regional lumber associations.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 29 Cambodia has accepted Ceylon's invitation to participate in a conference here on the Chinese-Indian dispute, the External Affairs Ministry said today. Indonesia and Cambodia have already agreed to attend.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 The abolition or modification of the law making the death penalty mandatory in cases of premeditated murder was urged by all but one witness at a legislative hearing today.
The wholesale commodity index fell to 80.2 Wednesday from 80.5 Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (UPI) Red Kress, a baseball coach with the New York Mets, died after a heart attack in his home here today. He was 55 years old.
NEWARK, Nov. 29 Two suspects in a $102,176 bank holdup Nov. 16 in Perth Amboy, N.J., have been arrested in Las Vegas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here today.
A first step toward providing quicker bus service to and from the city's business and shop ping centers during rush hours was taken yesterday by the Transit Authority and the Department of Traffic.

LONDON, Nov. 29 Miss Valerie Anne McAlpine, daughter of Mrs. Desmond BrookeHitching and A.J. McAlpine of London was married here this afternoon to Julio Texada Noyes, son of Mrs. Julius Wentworth Noyes of New York, Sharon, Conn., and Madrid, and the late Mr. Noyes.
A heavy, smoke-filled haze was pinned down over much of the metropolitan area early yesterday morning by a mass of warm air. The air mass prevented polluted air from rising.
Bail of $75,000 was fixed yesterday in the case of a 27-yearold attache to the Cuban mission to the United Nations who is being held on sabotage conspiracy charges.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) The International Brotherhood of Teamsters struck Cleveland's two major daily newspapers tonight in a contract dispute.
'Tis the season to be jolly for the nation's billion dollar greeting card industry.

The number of serious crimes committed in New York City increased at a rate considerably higher than in the rest of the nation in the first nine months of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday.
ADEER will snort, a bear will grunt, a wolf will howl, an elk will bugle but none can create as depressing and horrendous a noise as a hunter's snore.

WITH ballet and modern dance studios opening in in creasing numbers across the nation, mothers should take pause before enrolling their children in classes. First, say the experts, be sure the child is up to the rigors of dancing and, secondly, be certain that the school is a reputable one.

The rise of automation in American industry makes the role of education more important than ever, Charles H. Percy, chairman of Bell Howell Company, Chicago camera and business machine manufacturer, said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 A representative of U Thant, Acting Secretary General, warned Moise Tshombe today that Katanga would be subjected to increasing economic
LONDON, Nov. 29 The Chancellor of the Exchequer today ordered the Bank of England to release the last of the special deposits being held as a curb against inflation.

A former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation asserted in a radio broadcast last night that he had been dismissed for writing to members of Congress about the bureau's personnel policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 29 Two leaders of American Reform Judaism said today that the constant movement of American Jews from small-and middle-size towns to large cities had posed serious problems about the future of Reform Judaism.

THOUSANDS of impromptu radio hobbyists, whose ac tivities have contributed to the growth of a multi-milliondollar branch of the electronics industry, face a major governmental curb on their use of the airwaves for chitchat.
LONDON, Nov. 29 N.C. Hunter, who wrote "Waters of the Moon" and "Day by the Sea," gives us another piece of poor man's Chekhov in "The Tulip Tree," which opened tonight at the Haymarket Theater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 President Kennedy and Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, met for three hours and 15 minutes today in an apparently inconclusive conference on Cuba and some other cold-war issues.
Cocoa and world sugar futures made sharp advances yesterday in contrast to quiet and mixed dealings in most other commodities traded here.

LONDON, Nov. 29 The engagement of Princess Alexandra of Kent, cousin of Queen Elizabeth and 12th in the line of succession to the throne, to Angus James Bruce Ogilvy, second son of the Earl of Airlie and the Countess of Airlie, was announced today.
Small metal tabs to validate the present New York State motor vehicle license plates for 1963 will be issued beginning Monday.

A report on "Hungary Under Soviet Rule" asserted yesterday that the Hungarian people remained stanch supporters of Western democracy but might become resigned to Communist rule if the United States did not press the cause of Hungary's freedom.
BOSTON Nov. 29 (AP) State Representative-elect Charles Iannello, who won reelection to the Legislature while serving a one-year sentence for larceny, will be freed on parole Saturday.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 28 Crown Prince Faisal, Premier of Saudi Arabia, has rejected President Kennedy's proposals for settlement of the conflict in Yemen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) The United States has turned over 20 surplus minesweepers to the Mexican Government, but both Governments have refused to say whether the vessels will be used against United States shrimp fishermen.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 The Soviet Union reminded the Western powers today that it still regarded settlement of the Berlin issue as an urgent matter. Moscow made the point
A drive to improve houses in a section of Coney Island, was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

Directors of Ametek, Inc., yesterday authorized the declaration of an extra dividend of 25 cents along with the regular quarterly of 40 cents a share. They are both payable Dec. 21 to common stockholders of record Dec. 10.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 29 A three-judge Federal court ruled today that the Constitution guaranteed all citizens "substantially equal representation" in both houses of a state legislature.
ALGIERS, Nov. 29 The Government banned today the small but active Communist party of Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 If the success of American-British diplomacy in persuading the Governments of India and Pakistan to try to resolve their differences over Kashmir at a common conference table results in a settlement of this inflammable issue, it will be new evidence of the wisdom of Shakespeare's line that "Sweet are the

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) President Kennedy called on the nation today to observe Dec. 10-17 as Human Rights Week and reflect on "the blessings of liberty for our country and the equal and inalienable rights" of all citizens.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 29 Fifty-five Cuban refugees arrived here today to receive homes, jobs and social opportunities from the Hudson River Presbytery.

SUVA, Fiji, Nov. 29 (Reuters) The 9,159-ton Norwegian freighter Ragna Ringdal, with 45 persons aboard, went aground last night on a reef about 225 miles southeast of here, Harbormaster E.L. James reported today.
The Commomwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the ten and 12 months ended Oct. 31.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 29--The State Tax Policy Commission will recommend next month the adoption of a New Jersey sales tax, but will suggest a statewide personal income tax among the alternatives.

The Century Industries Company, Inc., a New York financing and factoring concern, announced yesterday that it had run into "difficulties" with a "major factored ac count," which might "eliminate all corporate earnings for this year."

MADRID, Nov. 29 American businessmen have announced their intention during the last few days to invest "many millions of dollars" in Spain's newly liberalized economy, a top Government official said today.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 Critics of the new Hong Kong carpet in the Assembly found a new point today. They said it looked too Oriental.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 29 "Barbizon Revisited," which opened today at the Toledo Museum of Art, is the first major exhibition since 1889 of the famous school of French 19th-century landscape painting. The display affords a welcome opportunity for reappraising Barbizon art and artists, once very popular with European and American collectors but of late years fallen out of fashion.
Business loans at major New York City banks declined in the week ended last Wednesday by $47,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 India joined with the West today in a vote that had the effect of barring Communist China from an international atomic energy conference to be held in 1964.
Inspector George G. Gallagher, commander of Manhattan's Sixth Detective District, suffered a fatal heart attack last night immediately after speaking at a testimonial dinner for a fellow policeman.

The Gulf Oil Company announced yesterday that it had named G.L. Benjamin vice president of the newly established Gulf Oil Trading Company. The company's prime objective will be to expand Gulf's international marine bunkering market.
Burgess Meredith's next Broadway assignment will be to direct "Murderer Among Us," George White's adaptation of a play by Yves Jamiaque.

The Boston Fund has reported net assets of $278,980,669, equal to $8.55 a share, as of Oct. 31. This compared with $229,766,444, or $20.33 a share, on fewer shares, one year earlier. The share value in 1961 is prior to a two-for-one stock split last May 31.
The British pound strengthened in foreign exchange dealings yesterday.

A fresh show of independence by reform Democrats in the Bronx and Manhattan was displayed yesterday in the face of Mayor Wagner's effort to improve the Democratic party image by getting all progressive elements to work as a team.
Wall-to-wall carpeting has been installed on an experimental basis in a third-grade classroom in Public School 84, on West 92d Street near Columbus Avenue.
Cotton futures were 75 cents a bale up to $1.30 down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The far months were the weakest.

The projected meeting between Pakistani and Indian officials to re-examine the dispute over Kashmir is an immensely encouraging development. It raises the hope that this nagging, 15year-old feud that threatens the security and the political and economic viability of both states will now be settled.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 30 (AP) Premier Khrushchev told Communist China today that the Soviet people are united in the "struggle against the plots of the imperialist thermonuclear war provocateurs."
Two hundred union officials decided yesterday to call on their members to picket City Hall Monday in support of striking city drivers.

The election of Morgan J. Cramer as chief executive officer of the P. Lorillard Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Cramer, who succeeds Lewis Gruber as chief executive, continues as president, a post he has held since July 13, 1961. Mr. Gruber, who has passed the customary Lorillard retirement age, will continue as chairman of the board.
TOKYO, Nov. 29--The Socialist party, the second largest in Japan, ended today a three-day political convention bitterly divided over a new recipe for political success.

VIETIANE, Laos, Nov. 29 (AP) Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, said today he had ordered an investigation into reports that his own neutralist forces and not the pro-Communist Pathet Lao shot down an American plane flying food to the Plaine des Jarres Tuesday. Two American pilots were killed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The wistful plea of a 7-year-old California boy for his Government to "setaside some land where we could play" touched a sympathetic official nerve today.
Two stamps symbolic of space and the expanding universe were exhibited to United Nations diplomats and many stamp collectors yesterday afternoon in advance of their release Tuesday.

SUPERMARKETS are not backing any favorite meat cuts this weekend. Instead they are playing a field that embraces beef roasts, leg of lamb and lamb chops, pork loins and leg and rump of veal. However, the best meat values are still found among broiling and frying chickens at about 39 cents a pound.
Representatives of six veteran, fraternal and religious organizations met yesterday to protest the use of tax-supported educational buildings by speakers with questionable backgrounds.
At the Baptist Temple in Brooklyn, yesterday will be remembered as the day the deacon tumbled off the roof. It cost the deacon a scare and the church a stained glass window.
ROME, Nov. 29 Pope John XXIII is understood to be suffering from a gastric ulcer that has brought about a state of "intense anemia."
DETROIT, Nov. 29 James R. Hoffa, head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is reported to have discharged his long-time legal counsel and friend, George S. Fitzgerald.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Nov. 29 Indians cannot plead religious freedom as a ground for eating a vision-producing cactus plant banned by state law, the Superior Court ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Air Force missile crews were put on a "maximum" alert in the Cuban crisis, the Pentagon disclosed today.
Negotiations between the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association on a new contract to supplant one that expired Sept. 30 were broken off again yesterday.
The names of Governor Rockefeller's daughter and her husband, a minister, were dropped from the 1963 Social Register, which came out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) Based on comparative market prices, the United States Government has a loss of $131,3000,000 on its sto kpile purchases of titanium. But it may be albe to salvage something through use of the metal in aircraft and space vehicles.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 A partly disabled young Hong Kong Chinese clerk received an award today that will enable him to study watchmaking in New York for two years.

HONGKONG, Nov. 29 Reliable reports received here that Communist China has closed two more Soviet consulates were interpreted by political analysts today as further evidence of the deteriorating relations between Peking and Moscow.

Blue Mill Tavern, 50 Commerce Street, CHelsea 3-7114. The commendable things about this Greenwich Village restaurant are the neighborhood, which is colorful, the service which is generally good, and the modest prices of the food, which is undistinguished but palatable. The restaurant is neat
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) President Kennedy today named Ambassadors to Algeria and Peru. Both are career foreign service officers.
NEWARK, Nov. 29 Sea-Land Service, Inc., today announced plans for a $5,000,000, threestory office building as part of its $22,000,000 containership terminal in Elizabeth Port.
The American Jewish Congress honored the memory of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 The Security Council will meet tomorrow morning and the General Assembly in the afternoon in an effort to push through in one day the re-election of U Thant as Secretary General.
Rabbi Aaron Kotler, a leading Jewish scholar and an authority on the Torah, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old.

Gideon did it with lamps in 1245 B.C., and Admiral Nelson did it with whispers in 1805. This morning the Brigade of Midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy are displaying their concept of psychological warfare with a full-page newspaper advertisement.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which will discontinue the hour-long "Fair Exchange", on Dec. 28, said yesterday the situation comedy would return to television later this season as a half-hour weekly series. The show reportedly thus gains the distinction of the first to be canceled and renewed in the same season.

An agreement by major league baseball officials and player representatives to hold only one All-Star Game a season instead of two was reached yesterday when the players were assured of a layer share of the proceeds.
LONDON, Nov. 29 Britain and France signed an agreement here today for the joint construction of a supersonic airliner. The plane is scheduled to be in service by 1970.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 A defecting Communist Chinese security officer told Senate investigators today that the Peking Government feared a mainland uprising spurred by a possible troop attack from Taiwan.

The Parents Guild of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church is arranging a theater party to the matinee of the motion picture "Jumbo" and the Christmas Show at the Radio City Music Hall on Dec. 14. Mrs. Douglas Yates is chairman for the event, which will benefit the Episcopal Academy of New York.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 29 (UPI) Robert P. Strub, the president of the Los Angeles Turf Club, today was elected president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations.

JUST as a London theatrical success may be a Broad way flop, so textile designs that are acclaimed in England may be shunted aside by American manufacturers. Such was the experience of Nicola Wood, a young English textile designer who is now in New York on a Fulbright grant.
Background music, to which 55,000,000 Americans now listen at some time of day, does appear to improve individual performance of simple, monotonous tasks.
Mayor Wagner announced the appointment of Meyer Kailo yesterday as Deputy Commissioner of the new Department of Relocation. Herman Badillo is the Commissioner.
The annual bazaar for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Wilhelm Weinberg Nursery School will be held tomorrow at the Washington Houses Community Center, 1775 Third Avenue.
Five firemen were injured last night during a one-alarm fire in the basement coal bin of a five-story tenement in the Bronx.

Just like a drill sergeant starting basic training with recruits, Coach Ken Norton of Manhattan College's basketball team is probably wondering whether he's going to have troops who can handle the enemy or men who merely can wear uniforms.
About 50 persons picked the main office of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday to protest any cutback in project housing guards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)--The Government will defray part of the hotel and travel bills of businessmen who come here next week to argue about proposed regulations on tax deductions for travel, entertainment and gifts.
Serious obstacles have developed in the United States' close relationship with Japan, a specialist in Asian affairs warned here yesterday.

LEONIA, N.J., Nov. 30-- Thirty families who believe they are being unfairly treated in the handling of damage claims growing out of construction of the Bergen-Passaic Expressway have started a series of roadblocks to slow down work.

Needing only one victory to clinch the Eastern Conference championship of the National Football League, the New York Giants will complete preparations at Yankee Stadium this morning for their game with the Bears in Chicago tomorrow.
The Administration is urgently considering what budgetary steps it might take to put its moon-landing program on a topspeed schedule.
PENNEY FARMS, Fla., Nov. 30--Dr. Paul Wilberforce Harrison, retired American medical missionary to Arabia, died here today at the age of 79.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) --President Kennedy chose Dr. John Prior Lewis, economist from Bloomington, Ind., today to fill a vacancy on his threemember Council of Economic Advisers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee recommended today a subsidy of $50,000 for the world organization's International School here in the current year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP)--A Democratic Congressman said tonight that President Kennedy had taken firm control of the management of Government news in a manner that was "unique in peacetime."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- President Kennedy accepted today an invitation to go to Costa Rica in February or March to join in talks among the Presidents of the Central American republics.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30--The underground rebellion in the Russian arts against the ideological strictures of Socialist realism has begun to come into the open.
Robert Moses, long a driving force behind power, parks and parkways in New York State, said yesterday that he was giving up all five of his state posts after a disagreement with Governor Rockefeller.

Major league field managers and general managers strove manfully to break the log jam in the trading mart yesterday as baseball's big-time operators brought their show to New York for a two-day stand in the Hotel Roosevelt. They met with only a modicum of success.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Two days of high-level SovietUnited States talks were completed here today without any immediate sign of a change in East-West relations.

Exactly 56 weeks ago today I assumed what was to me an unfamiliar role, as Acting Secretary General of the United Nations. Today the General Assembly has done me the further honor of appointing me to serve out the normal term of five years as Secretary General of the United Nations, beginning with my assumption of the office as Acting Secretary General on 3 November 1961.
GENEVA, Nov. 30--India urged the nuclear powers today to accept a yearly quota of inspections and thus renew progress toward a treaty forbidding nuclear tests.

Gilbert M. Serber, director of Columbia University's office of new construction since last December, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 334 West 86th Street.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 30-- A grand jury investigation of the reported abuse of a Negro prisoner in the Westchester County Penitentiary at Eastvie was completed today without any indictment ordered.
Dr. A. Allen Goldbloom, a retired physician, died Thursday at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston. He was 65 years old.

Buena Vista Township, Mich., sold $2,200,000 of sanitary sewer system bonds, due from 1965 to 1992, at competitive bidding yesterday to an investment banking group headed by First of Michigan Corporation.
Richard Krakeur has acquired a new comedy by Joel Hammil entitled "The Tender Heel." Mr. Krakeur will produce the play with Miranda D'ancona and is planning to bring it to Broadway next spring.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Two swans instead of one are now believed to have been involved in the crash that killed 17 persons aboard a United Air Lines plane near Ellicott City, Md., last Friday.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 30--A snag appeared tonight in the new agreement between India and Pakistan to negotiate on the dispute over the possession of Kashmir.
The Swedish American Line announced here yesterday that it would ask for bids on the construction of a new passenger liner.
ROME, Nov. 30--Pope John XXIII, who is suffering from a gastric complaint believed to be an ulcer, had a good night and woke at dawn considerably refreshed.

The Kennedy-Khrushchev agreement on Cuba has evidently not been advanced much by the talks between the President, Secretary Rusk and Deputy Premier Mikoyan. Even though the Russians have not made good on all their promises at the height of the crisis, the nuclear missiles and jet bombers have gone, or are on the way out.
Cocoa futures continued to advance yesterday while most other commodities traded on exchanges here were mixed in slow dealings.
ANNIVERSARIES at two long-established galleries specializing in American art are celebrated in the variety of this week's exhibitions.
Some words of caution have been offered by the Chase Manhattan Bank at a time when economic talk has been mainly optimistic.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 30 (AP)--The president of the Reynolds Metals Company advised businessmen today to move into world markets "with the same boldness and skill they demonstrate in new domestic markets."
THE HERITAGE RANGE, Marie Byrd Land, Antarctica, Nov. 17--A 10-man team of geologists and graduate students was here today to begin a study of this heretofore unexplored mountain range.

At her best, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf is a great artist and singer, but it was not until she was into the second half of her recital in Carnegie Hall last night that she reached the form expected of her.

Charles Einfeld, one of the best-known promotional executives in the motion pictures, will leave 20th Century-Fox, where he has served as vice president in charge of advertising and publicity since December, 1948.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30--The General Assembly unanimously elected U Thant today as Secretary General of the United Nations until Nov. 3, 1966.

BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 30 (Reuters)--Australia fought its way out of serious trouble to roll up 321 runs for seven wickets after England's bowling had stymied the early batsmen on the opening day of the first cricket test match.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Federal officials emphasized today the role of conciliation in the first regulations issued to carry out President Kennedy's housing order.

Geza Anda, the Hungarian pianist, gave a spectacular account of his talents in Philharmonic Hall last night, when he appeared as soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a performance of the second concerto of Bartok. It was one of those marvelous rare occasions in which a great piece ...
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 30--New Jersey counties will soon get their first opportunity to alter their forms of government.

WATCH HILL, R.I, Nov. 30 (UPI)--A body washed ashore at Napatree Point, R.I., was identified today as Thomas Ewing 3d, a 33-year-old New York lawyer who disappeared with a friend aboard the yacht Kria Nov. 10.
TORONTO, Nov. 30--With apprehensive eyes on the weather, football fans from all over Canada swarmed into this teeming city today to whoop it up in advance of tomorrow's Grey Cup game.

Directors of Texaco, Inc., declared yesterday an extra dividend of 10 cents on the common stock, payable Dec. 28 to record Dec. 7. The 45 cent quarterly dividend previously declared will be paid on Dec. 10.
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc. had a net operating loss of $6,461,119 for the fiscal year ended July 28, 1962.

Dr. Marjorie M. Nelson, a widely recognized research scientist in nutritional biochemistry and birth defects at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco and Berkeley, died of cancer Wednesday. She was 52 years old and lived in Berkeley.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30--Pressure is mounting in the Soviet press for prompt adoption of a law granting greater freedom of action to factory managers within the framework of a planned economy.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30-- Football presents its prize spectacle here tomorrow in the 63d meeting of Army and Navy before an expected gathering of 100,000.
A memorial service for Dr. J. Leighton Stuart, the founder of Yenching University in Peking, was held yesterday in the Interchurch Chapel at 475 Riverside Drive.
This time of year families usually rummage through the attic, closet and cellar in search of last year's Christmas ornaments. Usually, too, a few new replacements are indicated.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which includes Stern's and Gertz, in New York in its chain of department stores, showed increased sales in the three, nine and 12 months ended Oct. 31. Earnings were lower than those of last year except for the 12-month period.

PARIS, Nov. 30--Algeria and France began here today their first high-level talks since they signed agreements last March ending their war and providing for the independence of the North African territory.
A four-engine airliner carrying 51 persons crashed and burned while landing in heavy fog last night at Idlewild Airport.
A bystander who was wounded during a police chase Nov. 16 lost a court fight yesterday to prevent the Police Department from getting the bullet that struck him.

Tomorrow is Commitment Day in the Methodist Church, the day parishioners traditionally have signed pledges not to drink. So members of the church will ask themselves: "What does drinking mean to you?"

A North American Multihull Sailing Association to be the parent body for catamarans and trimarans was formed last night in the Bayside Yacht Club. The action was taken at a meeting of the Eastern Multihull Sailing Association, which became one of the members.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Senator Kenneth B. Keating predicted today that the Republicans would be "forever a minority party" if they adopted segregationist policies in an effort to carry the South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)--The tedious task of ballot recounting has still left undecided the gubernatorial races in Massachusetts, Minnesota and Maine. Still being settled, too, was the United States Senate contest in South Dakota between George S. McGovern, a Democrat, and Joe H. Bottum, a Republican.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy dismissed a civilian patrol wagon driver yesterday for striking. It was the 14th dismissal from the Police Department since civilian drivers struck municipal departments Tuesday.

Officials in charge of Greater Pittsburgh Airport have delayed the opening of a $12,000,000 jet runway there pending a Federal Aviation Agency reply to a request for financial help against damage suits brought by airport neighbors.

Frank Martin Porter, president of the American Petroleum Institute, died yesterday afternoon of an apparent heart attack at the Sheraton-East Hotel, Park Avenue and 51st Street, where he resided while in the city. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Chester Carrothers, the ill-informed man, was here on one of his infrequent visits this week and, as usual, spent an afternoon browsing through the antiques of Americana stored in the Smithsonian Institution.

Association of genuine non-Communists with genuine Communists never wears well. It is therefore not surprising that in Laos Premier Prince Souvanna Phouma and his neutralists are having more and more trouble getting along with the Communist-led Pathet Lao faction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- President Kennedy proclaimed tighter restrictions on imports of oil today.

TRENTON, Nov. 30--State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills said today the state was investigating a $3,500,000 mortgage transaction under which the owners of Yonkers Raceway appear to have sought ownership of Freehold Raceway.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday an arbitration award granting the Fire Department's uniformed officers salary increases ranging above $300 a year under a two-year contract.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)--Prices farmers received for crops and livestock were unchanged in the month ended Nov. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today. This left farm prices 2 per cent above those of a year earlier.

High winds and heavy seas harassed shipping in the North and South Atlantic yesterday. In the north, the West German tramp vessel Erwin Schroeder developed a dangerous list after her cargo of copper concentrate shifted.

AS a creator of public works Robert Moses has left the signature of his genius upon the state from Manhattan's Battery to the Canadian line. It is written in concrete and steel, as well as in landscaped sand and trees.
The police sought last night to keep Idlewild Airport from being tied up by curious motorists visiting the scene of the air crash. They barred all but emergency traffic from entering the area.
Hunger for great choral music, much of which is religiously inspired, was Robert Shaw's major impression of his recent tour of the Soviet Union with the Shaw Chorale.
ROME, Nov. 30--The Ecumenical Council completed discussion of a draft decree on Christian unity today.
TRENTON, Nov. 30--Gov. Richard J. Hughes, in a surprise reversal of policy, offered the Legislature today bills that would permit a temporary resumption of state controls over milk prices.

A three-year contract covering 21,000 employes and providing wage increases and other benefits worth more than 64 cents an hour was negotiated yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company and the Utility Workers Union of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--A Massachusetts company says equipment it patented this week can produce metallic powder a thousand times smaller than had been possible. The particles are less than one-millionth of an inch in diameter.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30--The Soviet Union announced tonight that it was recalling Mikhail G. Pervukhin from the post as Ambassador in East Germany. He is to be replaced by Pyotr A. Abrasimov, who has been both a diplomat and a regional Communist party official.
Governor Rockefeller promised yesterday to protect bar owners and liquor dealers from any "economic reprisals" for their testimony in the investigation of the State Liquor Authority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-tenth per cent, to 100.4 per cent of its 1957-59 base, during the week ended Nov. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Wednesday evening's performance of "Harold" at the Cort Theater will be a benefit for the scholarship fund of the Barlow School in Amenia, N.Y.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 30--It became apparent today that the Indians would not comply with Chinese demand that they withdraw from certain positions they hold, beginning tomorrow.

YONKERS, Nov. 30--Money did not go out of style tonight at Yonkers Raceway. It only seemed that way, as 34,475 buffs, taking last-gasp aim at the local mutuel machines, helped ring down the curtain on the 1962 harness-racing scene by betting a world-record total of $3,191,020.
SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 30 (UPI)--Gov. Edwin L. Mechem resigned today and had himself appointed the state's first Republican United States Senator in nearly 30 years.
THE first illustration in Harold Nicolson's "Kings, Courts and Monarchy" shows an Australian aboriginal chief singing a tribal song. He is dressed for awfully warm weather.
ALMOST all conceivable (and some not so conceivable) forms of food find their way to New York. Yet many a delicacy seems to forfeit much of its esthetic appeal when purchased at a city store.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 30 --Remains of stone fireplaces and level floors of soldiers' huts that date to the Revolution have been found in Morristown National Historical Park.

WHETHER a woman is 16 or 60, a new hairdo can make the sun shine on a gloomy day. It was an especially bright aft ernoon one day this week when six women had their hair pro fessionally cut and set. The women were all over 60 years of age and few of them go regularly to a beauty salon.

To a stranger it was the Case of the Disappearing D cor, but to those in the know at the Toy Ball in the Terrace Room of the Plaza last night it was all in behalf of the Retarded Infants Services, Inc.

Scrolls and $50 Government bonds were awarded last night to the five winners in the 25th annual competition for distinguished journalism held by the New York Newspaper Women's Club. The awards were presented at the club's annual Front Page Dinner Dance, held at the Astor Hotel.

PARIS, Nov. 30--An issue long quiet in the United States has re-emerged in the thinking and conversation of financial officials in Western Europe. It is the question of the legal ceiling of four and one quarter per cent on the interest rate that can be carried by long-term United States Government bonds.
ALBANY, Nov. 30--Law enforcement officials strongly urged the Legislature today to restore to grand juries the power to issue reports on investigations that do not result in indictments.

Capt. Edward J. Bechtold, who was pilot of the Eastern Air Lines DC-7B that crashed last night at Idlewild Airport, served as a member of the Air Line Pilots Association Air Traffic Control Committee.
Frightened survivors of the Idlewild plane crash described early today how flames shot up from the wrecked craft as they ran from the scene.
A mysterious avalanche of supposedly rare silver dollars with dates close to the turn of the century is causing their quoted values to drop to small fractions of their recent valuations.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is experimenting on a variation on the prevalent theme of sidekick crime-chasers in television--a mother and son team of detectives.
School officials are planning to submit an operating budget for next year that will approach $650,000,000, exclusive of possible salary increases for teachers.

Senator Clifford Case of New Jersey proposes to introduce into the new 88th Congress several reforms which he rightly believes to be overdue. How to prevent filibusters from shackling the work of the Senate is one problem. Another is to define more sharply the authority of the various Congressional committees in order to keep them from battling each other for jurisdiction. A third proposed reform deals with the perennial question of "conflict of interest."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Senator Jacob K. Javits's political advisers are convinced that the New York Republican improved his showing among the State's Negro voters in last month's election.
WASHINGTION, Dec. 2 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today he feared the European Common Market might cut off all imports of American farm products.

A funeral serviee yesterday for Rabbi Aaron Kotler, the eminent Orthodox Jewish scholar and spiritual leader, drew a crowd of mourners that police estimated at 25,000 to the Lower East Side.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Dec. 2 Seigniory Rink, with C.W. Neild as skip, won the 23d annual International Friendly Curling Games today, topping 27 other rinks with a total margin of 28 points in three victories. The president of the Zionist Organization of America yesterday assailed recent proposals on the refugee problem in the Middle East as a threat to Israel's security.
BONN, Dec. 2 A coalition between West Germany's two major parties has been suggested as a possible solution of the Government crisis.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 2 The American Contract Bridge League's 36th annual fall tournament finally ended tonight. To some contestants, who had played at least one and more often two sessions of three or four hours each every day since Nov. 18, it must have seemed interminable.

The missionary work of the Anglican Church among the aborigines and islanders off Australia was described here yesterday by the Right Rev. John Matthews, Bishop of Carpentaria, Australia.

SEVERAL times a wreck, some of the city's sleekest limou sines pause briefly before a small, nondescript establishment on 92d Street near Third Avenue. Passengers alight from the automobiles, enter a shop above which there is no sign, then depart as quickly as they came.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 2? Senator Mike Mansfield, the Majority Leader in the Senate, left here today after giving the most reserved statement about the situation in Vietnam delivered by a departing American official in a long time.
Michael Langham, the British director busily auditioning actors for "Andorra," said yesterday that too many American actors "are confined to a constricting naturalism."

Herman Badillo, Commissioner of the city's newly created Department of Relocation, said yesterday he hoped for more powers and an enlarged scope for his agency.

Offhand the average man would have thought that New York and Addis Ababa had little in common. But it turns out that they have a kinship of mutual sorrow after all. The Ethiopian capital, with a population of about a half million, is reported to have no street signs.

A California businessman, who sells exotic foods to gourmets by mail, has doubled his company's volume in the last two years by enlisting some of the nation's wealthiest women as unofficial salesmen.

The American Association for the United Nations has reaffirmed its view that "the need to do it through the U.N. is greater than ever because oldfashioned diplomacy for settling major problems is becoming increasingly ineffective if not obsolescent."

Thomas H. Wenning, theater critic of Newsweek who was recently elected president of the New York Drama Critics Circle, died Saturday night in Park East Hospital, after a short illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 222 East 72d Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks rifled three shots past Gump Worsley and two more through the substitute goalie, Marcel Pelletier, to beat the New York Rangers, 5 1, tonight and take sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League.
An assessment of a low-grade thoriuni deposit in the White Mountains of New Hampshire has doubled previous estimates of the size of this nation's total reserve of nuclear fuel.

ROME, Dec. 2 A ceremony today commemorating the 20th anniversary of the first controlled nuclear chain reaction underscored the vast influence the Italian Scientist Enrico Fermi and his work has had on modern science.

The National Maritime Union and the Atlantic Area Command of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service will hold a second bargaining session today for an agreement to cover 3,000 non-officer seamen aboard 39 Vessels.

Cincinnati, Duke, West Virginia and Loyola of Chicago all lived up to their pre-season basketball notices Saturday night. But the stunning upsets suffered by Kentucky and St. Bonaventure hint that it will be a long winter for high-ranking college teams.

Four ten-foot-tall stacks of books were displayed over the weekend in the main lobby of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. They were placed there to demonstrate the extent of the institution's yearly program of acquisitions.

Three candidates for Nordic berths on the 1964 American Olympic skiing squad left by plane for Europe yesterday to compete in a series of meets starting at Obersdorf, Germany, on Dec. 28. They Were accompanied by Arthur Tokle, former national ski-jumping champion, who is coaching the unit.
