A group of industrialists warned yesterday that high electricity rates for industry in New York City were "building an economic wall around our city that may halt any future plant expansion and keep vital new industry out."
COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 3 (AP) The State Supreme Court for the second time in a week has reversed convictions of Negro youths involved in 1960 racial demonstrations at Sumter.
Thousands of sign-carrying, baboon-bearing pickets paraded around City Hall yesterday in what had been planned as a demonstration of organized labor's support for striking city drivers.
TRENTON, Dec. 3 (AP) "Raritan Valley U.S.A.," a Raritan Township housing development, was given at least a patial green light by the New Jersey Supreme Court today.
SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica, Nov. 20 Twenty feet under the polar icecap and a mere 800 yards from the South Pole, two scientists are growing marigolds in a crowded workroom.
Eddie Yost and Ken Strong received the second annual New York University alumni-of-the-year-in-sports awards last night.
Several weeks ago a microphone was placed before the two soloists John Corigliano and Laszlo Varga at a New York Philharmonic concert in Philharmonic Hall.
The Negro's status in the American economy is going through a period of flux and transition, with fairly bright prospects for the middle class, Robert C. Weaver declared here last night.

ALGIERS, Dec. 3 Hundreds of Algerian soldiers took up positions around Government buildings today as the police arrested an undisclosed number of Moslem and European opponents of the Ben Bella regime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today that the Interstate Commerce Commission had erred in approving a new truck line to supplement services of truckers who refused some Nebraska shipments because of "hot cargo" agreements.

ROME, Dec. 3 The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said today that Pope John XXIII was "on his way to a complete recovery" and that he would be in St. Peter's Basilica Saturday to close the first session of the Ecumenical Council

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Henry Winston, former organizational secretary for the Communist party, can sue the Government for a million dollars in damages.
An 18-year-old youth convicted of first-degree murder for throwing a brick from a rooftop that killed a bystander was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The National Science Foundation, a Government agency, last week stopped the American Institute of Biological Sciences from spending any funds for 24 hours.
NO one can place a charge of "chicken" against Maxi milian Schell, the handsome actor who won himself an Oscar with his performance in "Judgment at Nuremberg."
The Commercial Solvents Corporation is expanding its protective coating business through the purchase of McWhorter Chemicals, Inc., for more than $1,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.
Edward N. Costikyan, New York County Democratic leader, called yesterday for "full-time commitment" to the job from the Election Commissioner to be chosen by Manhattan Democrats on Thursday.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 3 The Government announced today that Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana would not be allowed into Uganda because of a statement he was reported to have made that Africans were not ready for self-government.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI paid tribute to a fellow conductor last night at Carnegie Hall. Not only did he lead Ernest Ansermet's orchestrations of Debussy's "Six Epigraphes Antiques," but he went out of his way to praise them.

A recent dispatch to this newspaper mentions the release from prison last month of Michael Shipkov, a Bulgarian employed as a translator at the American Legation in Sofia after the war. In 1949 he was secretly arrested and tortured into "confession" and then instructed to go back to the legation to spy on the Americans.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 3 (AP) An apartment-house owner dropped charges today against seven members of the Congress of Racial Equality who engaged in a sit-in and picketing demonstration Saturday to protest his alleged refusal to rent to two African students.
In the spirit of fair play, the undergraduates of Downing College, Cambridge University, have invited Sir Charles Snow to deliver this year's Richmond Lecture.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 2 B. Jay Becker of New York and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., won the masters' open pair championship last night as the American Contract Bridge League's 36th annual fall tournament ended after 15 days of play.

The national indoor tennis championships will continue to be held in New York if a satisfactory rental price can be reached with the State of New York for the use of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue.
DETROIT, Dec. 3, (AP) Car production goes into the last month of 1962 firmly maintaining a pace far in front of last year's.
The Bankers Trust Company, which began operations in a two-room office a little less than 50 years ago, opened officially yesterday its new 30-story building at 280 Park Avenue.
The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., will benefit from the Pearl Gala, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 18.
The New York Philharmonic will inaugurate a series of concerts at Philharmonic Hall in the spring to be known as "Promenades." The series will approximate the plan of "Pops" concerts in Boston.

The confusion and discord now prevailing in world Communism were vividly illustrated by two events yesterday: in Rome the chief Chinese delegate to the Italian Communist party congress denounced Yugoslav President Tito as "a servant of American imperialism . . . a 100 per cent traitor to the cause of world Communism," and the head of a clique which has "brought ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) Here is a breakdown for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut of the Army Reserve Reorganization Plan announced today by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.
The formation of a committee dedicated to the creation of a waterfront park at Breezy Point on the Rockaway Peninsula was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Senator Allen Joseph Ellender's outspokenness could cost him one of the most burning ambitions of his life. No one, however, is willing to risk any bets yet that he will not succeed in carrying out his expressed desire to visit every ...

Deliverers for nine major newspapers here reported yesterday that they had received and rejected a new contract proposal from publisher negotiators, with a strike deadline coming up at midnight Friday.
Thirty-foot flames and explosions from an office building's rooftop air-conditioning unit tied up traffic in the Times Square area yesterday and attracted thousands of homebound spectators.
Sales of Dresser Industries, Inc. in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 rose to $245,000,000 from $235,700,000 in the previous
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4?The Peace Corps will fall short of its goal of having 5,000 volunteers in training or overseas by the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Public and private assurances by the White House indicated today that Adlai E. Stevenson would keep his post as chief United States delegate to the United Nations for as long a period as anyone could foresee.
Willy Loman, the central character in Arthur Miller's drama, "Death of a Salesman," used to say that a salesman had to be "well liked" in order to do his job.
A powerful voice was added yesterday to the chorus of those seeking to strengthen the effectiveness of the nation's foreign aid program.
The Bronx High School of Science will begin the observance of its 25th anniversary with a program tonight in the school auditorium.
LONDON, Dec. 4 Dense fog combined with frost to bring chaos on England's roads and railroads today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Kennedy Administration was said to be deeply disturbed today about the effects of statements made in Africa by Senator Ellender.
The Government order for the deportation of Frank Costello was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) The National Football League used its 1962 draft meeting to build for the future.

Henry Baker and Louis Roamer have bought for investment the seven-story store and apartment building at 814-16 10th Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of 54th Street. The property, which is 41 by 100 feet, is assessed at $63,000.

VIENNA, Dec 4 Czechoslovakia's President, Antonin Novotny, accused Albanian Communist leaders and, by extension, the Chinese Communists, today of having aided "American imperialism" through their criticisms of Soviet policy during the Cuban crisis.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4 Argentina's Economics Minister, Alvaro C. Alsogaray, bowed to military pressure tonight and announced his resignation.
The Federal Government has made no agreement to use space in the proposed $270,000,000 World Trade Center here, according to court papers filed yesterday by opponents of the project.
Brooklyn Borough President Abe Stark reported yesterday that the city drivers' strike had prevented repair work on three sewer breakdowns, creating a danger to health and safety.
A shipyard in Orange, Tex., was the apparent low bidder among six yards to build new 294-foot ferryboats for the city's Staten Island service.
Why should a runway that is closed because a runway gauge measures inadequate visibility be opened after that gauge fails and measurements are taken from a tower a mile and a half away?
A 69 year-old Brooklyn grandfather died in a fire in his home yesterday after he saved his own son and returned to try to rescue his two granddaughters. A roomer rescued the two girls.

No tax cut of more than $2,500,000,000 will be justified next year in the light of the potential Federal budget deficit and the signs of continuing advance in the national economy, according to the former chief economist of the Eisenhower Administration.
Conspicious gallantry was shown by the New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden last night en route to another booby prize.
The Invetors Stock Fund, Inc., of Minneapolis showed a decline in total net assets to $883,245,534 from $978,730,731 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Nine of the nation's 10 most densely populated cities are within 10 miles of New York City.
Stock prices surged upward in heavy trading yesterday, wiping out the declines of the preceding two sessions.

DUBLIN, Dec. 4 Irish International Airlines, one of the few airlines in Europe not running a deficit, has set its revenue goal for 1963 at approximately $36,000,000, of which $27,000,000 is to be earned abroad.

AFTER more than two weeks in which this de partment has necessarily been devoted to tournament bridge hands, while the national tournament was being played at Phoenix, rubber bridge players may reasonably expect the appearance of some hands bearing on their particular interest.
Strong support for Federally chartered mutual savings banks was voiced yesterday at the mid-year meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 4 (UPI) The University of Alabama has closed its books on new applicants for the spring semester, in effect barring prospective Negro students from admission to the still segregated school.

Activity quickened in the bond market yesterday. Treasury issues settled in price on new dealer markdowns and limited bank selling. The corporate market gave a good reception to the session's single new issue, and municipals moved out of syndicate in good volume on price concessions.
Next to Manager Casey Stengel, no one is more aware of the Mets' needs than George M. Weiss.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) The space agency took a small step today toward possible construction of a laboratory on the moon.

The R.R. Bowker Company, publishers of books for the professions for 90 years, has leased two floors in 1180 Avenue of the Americas, a 23-story office building being completed at 46th Street and Sixth Avenue. The lease, which involves 23,000 square feet of space, was arranged by Jerry L. Cohen and Ian G.M. Brownlie, vice presidents of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 4 (UPI) Mexico gained the Davis Cup tennis challenge round for the first time today when Rafael Osuna and Antonio Palafox won their doubles match for a 3-0 lead over India in the five-match series.

Stockholders owning nearly 5 per cent of the outstanding stock of Motec Industries, Inc., are opposing the company's plans to become a corporate shell following the sale of its assets to the White Motor Company.

Yesterday a copy of the first issue of the 1865 first edition of Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland" ended a series of traveling adventures in the auction room, and although in less than pristine condition, easily managed to fetch $16,000.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 4 (AP) The Syracuse Police Department was characterized at a public hearing today as infested with graft, inefficiency and poor leadership.

THE Albeneri Trio gave a program last night at Town Hall that included the New York premiere of Victor Babin's Trio. The work, which was published six years ago, was flanked by Beethoven's Trio in G major (Op. 1, No. 2) and Brahms's Trio in B major (Op. 8.)
Columbia's rebuilt basketball team coasted to a 67-42 victory over City College last night in its opener at University Hall.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 4 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that the Indian Government expected delivery of "a few" MIG-21 jet fighter planes from the Soviet Union by the end of the year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 The United States criticized today a resolution on sovereignty over natural resources approved by a committee last night. The measure was said to be "contrary to international law."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The White House is quietly canvassing the job opportunities available to some of the Democrats who were defeated in the elections last month.

STILLWATER, Okla., Dec. 4, (AP) Oklahoma State University officials dismissed Cliff Speegle today as football coach but said he would be offered another job under the same terms as his present $15,000-a-year contract.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 4 Senator Allen J. Ellender was refused permission to get off his plane here today. Tanganyika followed Uganda's lead in declaring the Southern segregationist unwelcome.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 4 A Westchester grand jury told County Judge Robert J. Trainor today that it found "no substantiation" of charges that W. Scott Davis, a Negro lawyer, had been abused in the county penitentiary at Eastview.
PARIS, Dec. 4 The axe has fallen on Paris's Grand Guignol. Experimental plays and poetry readings will replace the gore and horror melodrama for which the theatre was famous.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday it had hit a jackpot in the first four months of the current fiscal year with an increase in passenger revenues more than eight times what it had anticipated.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 The chairman of the Thruway Authority threatened today to ask for broader powers over billboards if advertisers persisted in placing signs just outside the agency's jurisdiction.

As you are aware, it has been my custom each year to transmit to the Governor of the state in advance of the regularly scheduled legislative session in January such proposals affecting the citystate financial relationship which may have a bearing on the Governor's own budget and on his own annual message to the Legislature.
TRENTON, Dec. 4 Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he would appeal to the State Senate to reconvene next week to act on his highway-safety program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Pentagon began today its longplanned and still controversial reorganization and cutback of the Army National Guard and Reserve forces.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Japanese and United States Cabinets officials exchanged complaints today about trade restrictions in their countries, then turned to much broader considerations.
MOUND CITY, S.D., Dec. 4 About 200 farmers and farmers' wives milled about the stores, offices and bars of this tiny prairie town's main street today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Interstate Commerce Commission backed away today from a controversy over larger parcel post packages.
Smoldering dissatisfaction over the architecture on Columbia University's growing campus burst into the open yesterday with the publication of the magazine Columbia College Today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) President Kennedy greeted 12 students from 11 different countries today and told them he hoped they would develop here "the qualities which will enable you to become leaders of your countries."
MADRID, Dec. 4 (UPI) Generalissimo Francisco Franco was 70 years old today. There were no birthday celebrations and the event went almost unnoticed except for brief newspaper articles.

PARIS, Dec. 4 Relations between Washington and Paris, listless and depressed during most of this year, have taken a notable upswing since the Caribbean crisis. The immediate cause of improvement was General de Gaulle's firm assurance that France could be counted on to support the United States unreservedly should the Cuban confrontation produce war.

ALGIERS, Dec. 4 Premier Ahmed Ben Bella asked today for prompt economic aid from abroad to help ease Algeria's "unbelievable problems." He warned the National Assembly that austerity was needed to help overcome these difficulties:
Dr. Lev Landau, the famous Soviet physicist who "died" and was restored to life four times, has recovered his intelligence, it was reported yesterday.
HARTFORD, Dec. 4 (AP) The Department of Justice today asked the Federal court here to enjoin 11 companies from violating anti-trust laws in the sale of brass mill products.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 4 President Mohammad Ayub Khan appears to be staking his leadership of Pakistan on the forthcoming negotiations with India on the Kashmir problem.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 Premier Khrushchev welcomed President Tito today with an expression of confidence that their contacts would bring their countries closer together.
RUDOLF SERKIN gave his annual piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall, and the house was filled with an audience just a shade different from the kind that so often attend piano recitals.

Two airlines are joining trans-Pacific steamship companies in an experiment to combine services in carrying cargo from the Far East to points east of the Rocky Mountains. The aim is to speed shipments and reduce shipping costs.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 4 (UPI) Nebraska, which posted an 8-2 record in its first year under Coach Bob Devaney, eagerly accepted a bid today to meet Miami in the Gotham Bowl at New York on Dec. 15.
The polonaise, the oberek, the masur and the krakowiak will be danced at the Polonaise Ball, which will be held at the Sheraton-East on Saturday as a benefit for Polish Mutual Assistance, Inc.

Hugh Griffith, a major stage, screen and television actor, is returning to Broadway after an absence since his memorable performance in "Look Homeward, Angel," winner of the 1958 Pulitzer Prize and the Drama Critics Circle award.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 The Soviet Union gave the United States a shipping schedule today designed to prove execution of pledges to remove Soviet jet bombers from Cuba by Dec. 20.
Football paid its highest tribute last night to an authentic football great who went on to attain high distinction in public life.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 4 A meeting of African neutralist chiefs of state set for Marrakech this month has been called off at the request of the United Arab Republic, officials announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 4 Industrial shares declined on the stock market today. Although losses were small and seldom exceeded a shilling (14 cents), they dominated nearly every group.

The Obernkirchen Children's Choir made its first New York appearance in three years last night when it sang the first of two Christmas concerts at Philharmonic Hall. Edith Moeller conducted the program of classical, folk and Chrismas songs, with James Benner at the piano.
Protests were voiced yesterday against the proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway by residents of the area, officials and civic leaders.
The nave of the Riverside Church last, night was the scene of the first performance here of "Novellis Novellis," a pageant-opera by John La Montaine about the Annunciation.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 (AP) A school bus driver in Kazakhstan in Central Asia, has been accused of the premeditated murder of 14 children in a collision with a train, the newspaper Kazakhstan Pravda reports. It says some of his townspeople suspect he is a religious fanatic.

PARIS, Dec. 4 France has agreed to make a series of loans to Algeria by Dec, 31. This is one of the most concrete results of four days of talks here between French minasters and an Algerian delegation headed by Foreign Minister Mohammed Khemisti, which returned to Algiers tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) The Sonny Listons moved into their new home today. It is a three-story mansion surrounded by a wrought-iron fence and set in what was the South Side's millionaire row 35 year's ago.
Mayor Wagner has asked Governor Rockefeller to help the city obtain $267,000,000 more in state aid for the fiscal year starting next July 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) Government auditors said today that the Bethlehem Shipyard at Quincy, Mass., had overcharged the Government $1,370,000 on construction of two nuclear-powered warships.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 A mixed, mildly prosperous picture of next year's economy was presented today by 10 business leaders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The rate of growth of the Soviet economy has slowed down considerably in the last four years, experts on the Soviet Union have told the Senate-House Economic Committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) A Federal Court jury awarded James Monroe $13,000 damages today after having found five Chicago policemen guilty of violating Mr. Monroe's civil rights during a murder investigation.
IT was strictly coincidence, of course. Among those formally inducted into the college football Hall of Fame in elabo rate ceremonies at the Waldorf-Astoria last night was Cal Hubbard.

The Brown Shoe Company is holding preliminary talks on possible acquisition of the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company, subsidiary of A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., according to a spokesman for the St. Louis shoe manufacturer. Edwin L. Parker, president of Spalding, confirmed the "exploratory discusions," but declined to elaborate further.

American-made fashions stand a "good-to-excellent" chance of penetrating the European Common Market, a United Stated Department of Commerce official told a meeting of leading dress manufacturers here yesterday.
Active but indecisive trading in world sugar and a decline in cocoa provided the chief points of interest on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 The need to establish a world authority to administer rules for use of space was raised today in the General Assembly's Political Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) President Kennedy called 10 radio executives to the White House today to thank them for their stations' broadcasts to Cuba during the crisis that followed the Soviet missile buildup.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would ease its proposed regulations limiting businessmen's tax deductions for travel, entertainment and gifts.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 4 Nassau's ninth annual international sports car race meeting has attracted another large group of the world's topranked drivers.

TOKYO, Dec. 4 There is a story told in Tokyo about a lecturer in the United States who would hold up a five-dollar bill and offer it to the first person in the audience who could call out the name of the Premier of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The White House added to day a 36-hour visit at Palm Springs, Calif., to President Kennedy's trip to the West this weekend to look over military and atomic energy installations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) A doctor said today that an old autopsy report indicated that Eng, one of the "original" Siamese twins, died of fright a few hours after the death of his brother, Chang.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's decision to build a new $250,000,000 mill in northern Indiana will provide the strongest challenge yet to the United States Steel Corporation's role as America's one great nationwide producer of steel.

OXFORD, Miss, Dec. 4 The court-ordered reinstatement of a student expelled after demonstrations against James H. Meredith has confronted University of Mississippi officials with a problem they regard as no less grave than integration.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 4 (AP) A lawyer said today he had once told James R. Hoffa the Taft-Hartley Act did not necessarily prohibit a union official from having joint business interests with an employer.
WASHINGTON. WIVES of Japanese Cabinet members witnessed Monday the running of the world's fastest galloping clotheshorse the "typical" American woman.
A record capital budget of $1,084,755,351 for the eighteen months beginning Jan. 1 was approved unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Dec. 4 The extended thoroughbred season in this state will come to a close tomorrow at Garden State Park with the Au Revoir Stakes as the feature.

Werner P. Gullander, new president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday on the eve of the organization's 67th annual meeting that he believed the nation stood on the threshold of new economic expansion if it was ready to take advantage of its opportunities.
ROME, Dec. 4 Communist China replied strongly today to criticism of its policies voiced at the 10th congress of the Italian Communist party.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 Premier Hermes Lima defied Brazil's Leftist unions today and discharged Minister of Labor Joao Pinheiro.

LISBON, Dec. 4 Six new ministers took the oath of office today amid speculation that the Government shuffle might herald a slightly more liberal course in metropolitan Portugal and tighter control of overseas territories.
Ramco Enterprises, Inc., a New York holding company, disclosed yesterday that it was one of the principals involved in the purchase of control of Cartier, Inc., the Fifth Avenue jewelry concern.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) Grain futures fell today on the Board of Trade on selling that reflected concern over a possible dock strike later this month.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25 The Soviet Union is building a 20-acre radio "eye" to gaze into the farthest reaches of space.

RATHER than discuss clothes or other members of their sex, many women prefer to talk about money. In recent years, the stock market has become a popular topic of conversation over luncheon, bridge and dinner tables.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) The Amateur Athletic Union's action in declaring a large group of athletes ineligible for competing in unsanctioned meets met with resounding criticism today from track officials across the country.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office disclosed yesterday that it was trying to find out how a "clip joint with three undercover owners" had received a license to operate and sell liquor.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 France declared today that the United Nations was no "superstate" and served notice that she would continue her refusal to pay assessments for the United Nations force in the Congo.
BONN, Dec. 2 Allied military officers who have watched the slow development of the West German armed forces have concluded that their fighting capability "takes a back seat to no others."
The United States Steel Corporation announced last night that mill base prices for hot and cold rolled carbon steel sheets at its Fairless, Pa., works were being cut $1 a ton, effective today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 4 Four Arab states stepped up attacks on Israel today with speeches comparing Zionism with Nazism and accusing Israel of aggrression.
At the outset of these hearings, it may be helpful to review the background of the new statute limiting deductions for travel, entertainment and gift expenses ("T E").
FORT LEE, N.J., Dec. 4 Superior Court Judge Morris Pashman put aside all argument, stipulations and briefs today to take a walk in the woods atop the Palisades here.
A bill that would mandate year-round daylight saving time in New York State was prefiled yesterday by the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles and Traffic Safety.
Richard Boone, who will check his gun and travel to a rival network, and Clifford Odets are the central figures in an ambitious dramatic series scheduled for next season.

Behind its intricate wroughtiron balconies and its look of lost elegance, the Chelsea Hotel has long stood as a fortress against progress, an old New York landmark that has changed little since O. Henry dwelled there and wrote, "I would like to live a lifetime on each street in New York. Every house has a drama in it."
The election of Joseph C. Wilson as a director of the Rank Organisation, Ltd., of London was announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4 Three men and 30 sticks of dynamite were seized in a raid in Hicksville today. Nassau authorities announced they had broken a conspiracy to shake down barber shops and bomb those that held out.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 4 (Reuters) Ministers from the six European Common Market countries decided tonight to speed the negotiations on Britain's application for membership.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Dec. 4 (UPI) Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas, Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Gov. Grant Sawyer of Nevada supported Gov. Albert D. Rosellini of Washington today in opposing reorganization of the National Guard.

A 9-year-old girl was thrown or pushed from the roof of a 14-story building yesterday in the Farragut Houses development in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn. An autopsy indicated that she had been raped and was alive when she left the roof.

THE REV. JOHN NEWTON, an eighteenth-century English clergyman who wrote the famous hymn, "How Sweet the Name of Jesus Sounds," was not always an example of Christian piety. In his youth he was a foul-mouthed, emotionally unstable and violent sailor who became a shipmaster in the Guinea trade.
A Negro mother and father asserted yesterday that they would go to jail rather than send their children to a "segregated" public school.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission again today for authority to abandon its Lake Placid branch line.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 4 J. Barstow Smull, former president of the United States Shipping Board Emergency Fleet Corporation and the New York Produce Exchange, died today at Hilaire Farms Nursing Home, Huntington Station. He was 88 years old.
Directors of the Beatrice Foods Company yesterday proposed a four-for-three split of its common stock, subject to approval of shareholders at a meeting in Chicago on Feb. 21.

CHATSWORTH, the Derbyshire home of the Dukes of Devonshire since the 17th century, ranks among the supreme English country houses for grandeur, historical interest, and for its works of art, one of the greatest collections still in private hands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) Two former Havana educators testified today that they had fled Cuba after Premier Fidel Castro had confiscated private schools and forced teachers to indoctrinate pupils in Communism.
The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority announced yesterday it had approved the sale of $22,00,000 of school lease revenue bonds. Bids will be opened on Jan. 9, 1963.

Malcolm A. MacIntyre, president of Eastern Air Lines, challenged yesterday a statement issued Monday by five airline presidents who said they were "fed up" with Eastern's "continuous refrain" that the airline industry was in critical financial condition.

Since March 15 when the Spanish Government liberalized the regulations governing the purchase of shares in Spanish companies, Wall Street has shown more interest in the growth potential of Spanish companies.
EARLY in the second act of "The Night Is Black Bottles," which opened at the Cricket Theater last night, Ruby, the bartender, says, "It's gonna be a long night." It was, Ruby.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The men who work most closely with airplanes agreed today that they had gone about as far as they could in reducing the noise of jet and propeller planes.
A trend toward films with adult themes at the Radio City Music Hall has been underscored with the booking there next March of Paramount's "A Girl Named Tamiko."
Steadily increasing United States imports of Japanese cultured pearls has led the Japanese Government to take the unusual step of honoring an American trade association for its efforts in this field.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 The International Coffee Agreement may go into operation on a provisional basis before the stipulated terms have been fulfilled.
Cotton futures were 30 cents a bale up to 25 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Eachange.

HARTFORD, Dec. 4 Abraham A. Ribicoff, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, spent $223,545 and received contributions of $223,729 in his successful campaign for nomination and election to the United States Senate.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 4 By investing in the college educations of two mothers formerly on relief rolls, the Union County Welfare Board reported today, the county is saving more than $5,000 a year.
Brooklyn's nomadic collegiate basketball teams Long Island University, St. Francis, Brooklyn Polytechnic and Pratt Institute are still without a court to call their own.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Supreme Court took a startled look today at the Rhode Island Commission to Encourage Morality in Youth.
Meyer E. Zinman, teacher and shorthand expert, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home, 215 West 91st Street. He was 72 years old.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 An effort by the Levittown, L.I., Board of Education to require reading or recitation of documents with religious references was challenged on constitutional grounds today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Robert C. Weaver said today that the new Federal order against discrimination in housing might be broadened to cover housing financed by "conventional" mortgages.
THE comment heard most among deer hunters runs like this: "If you're where the deer are, you'll get one, for it's all a matter of luck."

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 Robert J. Casey, noted newspaperman and author, died today in St. Francis Hospital in suburban Evanston. His age was 72. He had been admitted to the hospital Nov. 24 after suffering a stroke.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy did some Christmas shopping here yesterday and visited two art galleries to look at art and furniture collections.
ROME, Dec 4 The Ecumenical Council offered its "continued prayers" today for the health of Pope John XXIII.

LONDON, Dec. 4 The recent discovery by British servicemen that they can escape the service and return to civilian life by running for Parliament is making a farce out of a forthcoming Yorkshire by-election.

The inconsistent New York Rangers, mired in fifth place in the National Hockey League, have Camille Henry to thank for more than a few of their successes. While Coach Muzz Patrick has been the object of such Madison Square Garden chants as "Muzz Must Go" on bad nights for the Blues, Henry has consistently drawn cheers.

GENEVA, Dec. 4 The Soviet Union told the United States and Britain today that as long as they insisted upon onsite inspection to check suspicion of atomic explosions, there would "never be any agreement" to end nuclear testing.
LONDON, Dec. 4 The Treasury reported today that Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves had risen by 22,000,000 ($61,600,000) during November.
BONN, Dec. 4 Chancellor Adenauer met with three Socialist leaders today in what quickly became the first round of negotiations for a new coalition Government.

Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, is the principal victim of an article in the current Saturday Evening Post purporting to tell what went on in the executive committee of the National Security Council at the height of the Cuban crisis six weeks ago.
MOUND CITY, S.D., Dec. 5 Efforts to settle a bitter dispute between farmers and the Federal Government collapsed today.
The Seneca Indians, who are about to be flooded out of their homes on the Allegany Reservation, will be granted Federal funds to build 60 single-family homes.
Distillers Corp.-Seagram, Ltd. and subsidiaries yesterday reported higher sales and earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York sold $60,000,000 of 30-year bonds yesterday.

The bond market labored heavily yesterday but failed to make much progress. Treasury issues were up slightly in price as activity improved somewhat. The corporate market stalled under the weight of a $60,000,000 Consolidated Edison 30-year mortgage bond offering. State and municipal obligations continued to accumulate in syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)--Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, emphatically denied today reports that Soviet reconnaissance planes had flown over the southeastern part of the United States. So did Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Air Force Chief of Staff.
A drop of 5,476,000 barrels in the country's stocks of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes, was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute for the week ended Friday.

The head of Local 808 of the Teamsters Union charged yesterday that the International Ladies Garment Workers Union had done nothing about an asserted "sweetheart" deal between its Local 102 and an employer.
The letter on this page today from Ethan A. Hitchcock invites further discussion of an issue sure to be hotly debated at the 1963 Legislature.
The head of the European Economic Community told American businessmen yesterday that it offered not a barrier, but a challenge, to them to increase their trade within an expanding ...
MOSCOW, Dec. 5--The Soviet Union announced today the first regional appointments under a plan to reorganize the Communist party hierarchy into industrial and agricultural divisions.
RALPH VOTAPEK, winner of the Van Cliburn Inter national Piano Competition, gave a Carnegie Hall recital last night and proved to be the very model of a modern junior executive among pianists.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 5 The Walworth Company, a valve manufacturing concern, announced today it had shifted its headquarters from 750 Third Avenue in New York to a new building adjacent to its plant here.

STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 5 William Hawley Davis, editor of the Stanford University Press for its first two decades and professor emeritus of English, died today in Palo Alto-Stanford Hospital. He was 82 years old.
Cotton futures rose 15 cents to $2.05 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5 (AP) Cincinnati held Miami of Ohio scoreless for nearly seven minutes in the first while taking a 16-point lead tonight and went on to score a 58-36 victory. George Wilson had 25 points for the winners.

A few decades ago, when a nickel could still buy a ride on the subway, a highlight of the basketball season for City College and Brooklyn College students was the annual trip on the Flatbush Avenue division of the Interborough Rapid Transit system. The line serviced both campuses.

BONN, Dec. 5--The Parliamentary Deputies of the Opposition Social Democrats empowered their leaders today to continue negotiating for a coalition government under Chancellor Adenauer. But the Deputies tied their decision to conditions that made the success of the negotiations highly improbable.
Jack Brause, realty investor and developer, has bought the five-story hotel at 154 Bleecker Street, southeast corner of Thompson Street. The seller was a client of Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks scored twice in the last eight minutes tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 5-4, and maintain their 2-point hold on first place in the National Hockey League.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Dec. 5 Rocky Link of the Golden Triangle Stable made the getaway day at Garden State Park a bright one for the favorite players today.
ROME, Dec. 5--Pope John XXIII assured about 10,000 people in St. Peter's Square at noon today that his illness was past and that he was convalescing.
HAZARD, Ky., Dec. 5 Labor unrest in the coal fields of Eastern Kentucky seems headed for a violent climax and the imposition of martial law.
Terry Baker, who throws a football with his left hand and a baseball with his right, needed both to carry off the Heisman Memorial Trophy Award last night.
Institute on corporate counsel under the auspices of the Fordham University School of Law, Columbus Avenue and 62d Street, 10 A.M. Continues tomorrow.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (UPI) Ron Ferraro, the nation's leading rider, won for the eighth time in three days today when he scored a triple at Pimlico.
Joseph A. Gimma proposed last night that the leadership of the New York County Republican organization be turned over entirely to Vincent F. Albano Jr.

With two weeks to go Bill Taylor of the Green Bay Packers continued to lead John Henry Johnson, the Pittsburgh Steelers fullback, for the National Football League's individual rushing honors, according to statistics released yesterday.

The New York Yankees, who can do very little wrong, received greetings yesterday from the Lagos (Nigeria) Yankees, who are valiantly and with great success trying to repress a natural inclination to field balls with their feet.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 5 (AP) Gov. Otto Kerner granted a sentence reduction today to Orville E. Hodge, a former state auditor who has served more than six years in prison for stealing $1,500,000 from the state treasury.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 A Federal judge ruled today that Tulane University could voluntarily admit Negro students since it was unconstitutional for the State of Louisiana to compel racial discrimination in private affairs.

THERE are few things that are completely unlike any other, but baumkuchen may well be one of them. This festive German cake is made to resemble an upright, limbless, hollow tree, and generally stands at least a foot high.
The Block brothers of Camden, John, Henry and Karl, ran into trouble at the meeting and were penalized. John and Henry are jockeys and Karl is their agent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5--The United States and the Soviet Union announced today formal agreement to cooperate in three peaceful uses of space. These are satellite weather observations, studies of the earth's magnetic field and worldwide communications through the use of satellites.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 5--Dean Acheson said today that an increase of conventional armed forces in Western Europe, coupled with stronger economic and political ties could lead to a solution of the problem and the unification of Germany.
USUMBURA, Burundi, Dec. 5 (Reuters)--Senator Allen J. Ellender denied today that he had made the remarks that led to his being barred from Uganda and Tanganyika.
Leading performers of the dance, screen, opera, theater and ballet will model famous costumes at the Pageant of the Performing Arts Jan. 6 at Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Businessmen urged the Internal Revenue Service today to rely more on controls on expense accounts imposed by companies themselves than on demanding detailed recordkeeping by employers for small expenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec.5 The blueprints were approved today for an international research program to study the sun and earth in the forthcoming period of minimum solar activity.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 5 (Reuters) Alsing Andersen, Danish Defense Minister when Denmark was occupied by Germany in 1940 and chairman of the United Nations Special Committee on Hungary in 1957, died here today. He was 69 years old.

The hopes that Premier Khrushchev's military withdrawal from Cuba would lead to an EastWest detente permitting solution of wider world problems are growing dim again. Though yesterday's U.S.-U.S.S.R. agreement on space satellite cooperation is a bright spot, the most important test of a detente is being made at the Geneva disarmament conference.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Internal Revenue Service's proposed new rules on expense account deductions have been under severe criticism here this week by the restaurant and bar lobby.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would invite President Kennedy to attend the second annual Gotham Bowl game between the University of Miami and Nebraska at Yankee Stadium Dec. 15.
Luchino Visconti, one of Italy's most creative directors, will direct a section of "The Bible," in which producer Dino De Laurentiis plans to film the Old Testament in its entirely.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Reserve Officers Association withdrew its opposition to the Defense Department's reorganization of Army National Guard and Reserve forces today.
Mayor Wagner yesterday directed William Reid, chairman of the City Housing Authority, to "slice through all obstacles" and put new housing policemen on the job at city projects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The first broad analysis of international affairs that was made by U Thant of Burma after he became in fact the Secretary General of the United Nations was remarkable for the number of puzzling statements it included.
NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 5 Dr. Leon H. Goldberg, a retired specialist in internal medicine, died Sunday in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. He was 64 years old and lived at 175 North Broadway here.

The State Liquor Authority announced yesterday that it had suspended the liquor license of the Copacabana night club for 10 days starting Jan. 7. The club is accused of having been a disorderly place.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 The amazing sales pace for new cars continued during November. New car sales for the entire month totalled 657,090 units, according to Ward's Auto motive Reports. That was a 12.3 per cent increase over the record 584,962 cars sold in the like month last year.
TRENTON, Dec. 5 Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he had "every expectation" that the Federal Government would be a major tenant in the proposed $270,000,000 World Trade Center in New York City.
IF there is a way to keep a from becoming tiresome on a stage, Seyril Schochen has not discovered it.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 5 Jasper McLevy, Bridgeport's Socialist Mayor from 1933 to 1957 who died Nov. 19 at the age of 84, left an estate valued at $125,000, according to his will, which was filed today.
The Kratter Corporation and the Transcontinental Investing Corporation announced yesterday that they had begun merger negotiations. Both companies are publicly owned real estate concerns.
The British pound remained firm in foreign exchange dealings here yesterday, with brisk demand for sterling from the European Continent.
A Renoir oil, "La Fete de Pan," was sold for $100,000 yesterday at an auction in the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

The Army Munitions Command, not given to frivolity, is practicing catching artillery shells in mid-air. Doing the catching is a cellular plastic material, so shock absorbent that eggs can be bounced on it without breaking.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Japanese and United States Cabinet officials ended three days of talks today with joint declarations of common and divergent views on expanding trade and fighting Communism.

The proposed merger of Eastern Air Lines and American Airlines is running into heavy weather. It already has been attacked by the Justice Department and the Antitrust Subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee. A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has recently recommended that it be turned down..

THE new, salaried president of the National Association of Manufacturers the spokesman for small and large American business has come a long away since his birth 54 years ago in a Lutheran parsonage in the small town of Big Rapids, Mich. Werner Paul Gullander

A 91-year-old dentist took his usual active part as a clinical instructor yesterday at a luncheon session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting and then sat back to review the state of the profession.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 5 Edward Lewis Wallant, novelist, died today of a stroke at Norwalk Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived at 23 Vollmer Avenue.

The young New York pianist Charles Milgrim gave a recital last night in Town Hall. His program included Beethoven's "Tempest" Sonata and shorter works by Bach, Chopin, Debussy, Ravel, Falla and Prokofieff.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 5 American University of Washington downed Adelphi College tonight, 73 56. Ron Rawlins led the visitors with 17 points, but high honors went to Steve Mallis, a sophomore Adelphi forward, with 28.
Plans for the Dec. 19 theater party at the evening performance of "Lord Pengo" at the Royale will be discussed today at a luncheon meeting of the directors of the Park Association of New York City.
A one-hour meeting between longshore-union and shippingindustry negotiators failed yesterday to produce progress toward a new labor agreement.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 5 (AP) The nuclear ship Savannah, whose reactors can carry her around the world without refueling, was tied up here today by a labor dispute.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 James C. Petrillo was defeated today for re-election as president of the Chicago Federation of Musicians, Local 10.
For the second time within a week, a factoring concern has announced the setting aside of funds to cover losses from a "possible fraud" by one of its borrowers.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York had good news for its 38,000 shareholders yesterday a year-end extra dividend of 10 per cent in stock. This represents its first stock distribution since its formation in April, 1959, by the merger of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
The United States Steel Corporation announced last night a price cut and a new product in the often turbulent market for metal conduit. The moves were expected to cause a stir in the field.

The system of gathering and quoting prices on over-thecounter stocks, which drew the attention last week of Chairman William L. Cary of the Securities and Exchange Commission, came under new scrutiny yesterday.
The nation's two largest overocean airlines, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, have decided to install lights on passenger and crew life vests.
ROME, Dec. 5 One of the world's best-known Roman Catholic theologians said today that the Ecumenical Council had "changed the atmosphere of the whole church:"

THE cosmetics industry has discovered an unexploited gold mine in the men's toiletry field and the rush is on. According to a report by Beauty Fashion, a trade publication, the market has been estimated to be worth more than $300,000,000 and the number of companies producing men's products has increased from 42 to 64 during this year alone.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) The Washington Senators acquired an infielder, Marv Breeding, an outfielder, Barry Shetrone, and a pitcher, Art Quirk, from Baltimore today.
LONDON, Dec. 5 The stock market threw off its dullness of yesterday, and many leading stocks gained.
A decline in cocoa and copper futures and moderately heavy trading in world sugar prices paced an otherwise quiet day on the commodity markets here.
Governor Rockefeller applauded the announced economic aims of the Kennedy Administration yesterday, but accused it of failing to take action to achieve them.

THE highest tide of Britain's empire, you might say, was marked by a song. The song was Noel Coward's "Mad Dogs and Englishmen" with its raffish yet exultant notes on the careless way the British ruled the earth.

ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 5 Nothing on the steel-aluminum bus humming through the Ohio countryside, made white by snow, indicates that it is special. Not even the word "Chartered" in the destination aperture above the windshield provides a clue. But it is.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The unemployment rate rose sharply in November to 5.8 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Department reported today.
OXFORD, Miss., Dec. 5 A professor at the University of Mississippi charged today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was "sluggish" in investigating campus demonstrations.
Public and private power interests are jointly working on a plan to build at a cost of $135,000,000 the largest steam electric power plant in Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 President Kennedy publicly expressed today his "fullest confidence" in Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations.
VIENNA, Dec. 5--A topranking Czechoslovak Communist party official called today for the complete eradication of Stalinism from the political life of the country.

The New York Stock Exchange, "though a public institution, still seems to have certain characteristics of a private club, a very good club, I might say ..." These words were spoken last Nov. 28 by William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at what up to then had been a routine annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association at Hollywood, Fla.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which has not yet scheduled a telecast of "Hedda Gabler," starring Ingrid Bergman, has informed the British Broadcasting Corporation that it can present the play in England on Dec. 28.

The dread combination of smoke and fog that has killed people on the streets and in homes and hospitals in England is a grim reminder that air pollution is not only a nuisance it is deadly. The smog that recently persisted, off and on, for several days in the New York area shows that it can happen here.

MISCHIEVOUS MISTY, a Weimaraner, holds a new distination. Competing in the Montreal Obedience Dog Training Club trials at St. Marguerite, Que., recently Misty gained her third and final leg, winning her Canadian utility diploma.
The New York Knickerbockers, desperately in need of talented basketball players, obtained Tom Gola from the San Francisco Warriors yesterday in exchange for Willie Naulls and Kenny Sears.

Playing football for the debtridden New York Titans really isn't as discouraging as trying to toast marshmallows in the rain. It just seems that way to outsiders who are cowed by the sight of flinty bill collectors at the door.

A list of drugs and baby food demanded by the Cuban Government in exchange for the release of 1,113 prisoners of the April, 1961, invasion, was reported yesterday to have been completed. The permission of the United States Government is being awaited.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 5--The central Government announced today that its troops had captured Kongolo, the last major Katangese stronghold in Northern Katanga.

The New York Rangers were denied a victory last night when Norm Ullman scored with 1:03 left to give the Detroit Red Wings a 3-3 tie at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 13,627 saw the National Hockey League game.
The Congress of Racial Equality is scouting the municipal bond market as a new battleground in its fight against segregation in the South.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 5 Three men who allegedly threatened to dynamite barbershops if their owners refused to join a price-fixing organization were arraigned in First District Court here today on charges of illegal possession of dynamite, extortion and conspiracy to commit extortion.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 5 (AP) A man who said he wanted to kill James R. Hoffa fired an air pistol at the labor leader in Federal court today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 5--The Government of South Vietnam said today that its troops had found a large cache of new Chinese-made weapons and equipment in the central highlands north of Banmethout. The cache included automatic weapons and mortars as well as ammunition, the Vietnamese Department of Defense said.
Talks are continuing between the top officials of the RapidAmerican Corporation and Spartans Industries, Inc., concerning acquisition or merger.
The autobiography of Claude Bowers, completed before his death in 1957, will be published Dec. 14 by Simon Schuster under the title of "My Life."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Can a native-born American be deprived of citizenship and made a man without a country?

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5--A proposal under which the five permanent members of the Security Council might be asked to bear an even larger share of the cost of financing United Nations peace-keeping forces was submitted today.

THAT Adlai E. Stevenson, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, chose the "Today" television program to rebut a Saturday Evening Post article in which his role in the Cuban crisis was discussed, was illustrative of the unusual influence of the morning news show in official Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) John E. Horne, Small Business Administrator, said today he believed there was still room for more Government-aided small business investment companies.
De Havilland Aircraft of Canada, Ltd., has received a $25,839,665 contract from the Army Transportation Material Command for production of 48 CV-2A Caribou transport aircrafts.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 Argentina's rudderless ship of state lurched into a new storm today with most of its key crew members not on board.
While patrolling the coast off South Korea in the fall of 1945, a few days after the surrender of Japan, a United States Navy commander, Archer W.P. Trench, spotted a sinking junk.

The master of the British cargo ship Sarah Bowater informed a Coast Guard hearing yesterday that his ship was traveling at 3.5 knots when she was in a collision with the tanker Chemical Transporter in dense fog off Staten Island Monday night.

ROBERT MOTHERWELL'S work at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 15 East 57th Street, is fascinating for a number of reasons. He has long been one of the leading names in the avant-garde and a consistent practitioner of uncompromising abstraction.
ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) Pietro Tomasi Marchese della Torretta died yesterday at the age of 89.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 5 Rear Adm. Luis de Florez, U.S.N.R., retired, who developed many devices for training Navy aircraft pilots in World War II, died today in Lawrence and Memorial Hospitals. He was 73 years old and lived in Pomfret.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney challenged Mayor Wagner today to specify what state taxes should be raised or new taxes imposed to meet the Mayor's request for $267,000,000 in new state aid to New York City.
Alec Guinness has agreed to star in the title role of "Dylan," Sidney Michael's play about the late Dylan Thomas.
A late wave of profit taking cut sharply into a strongly advancing stock market yesterday. Prices closed higher on average but well below their top levels of the day. Volume continued heavy.
The New York County Medical Society yesterday assailed the Trussell Report on nonprofit medical care insurance plans as "unacceptable and distorted."
A break in the nine-day-old city drivers' strike appeared likely last night.

Among five artists singing their roles in "Don Giovanni" for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera last night, it was Fernando Corena as Leporello who provided the most satisfaction.
Moscow, Dec. 5 (AP)--The Soviet Academy of Arts has removed liberal elements from its leadership and installed Vladimir A. Serov, a painter of the "socialist realism" school, as its president.

A BE TURNER, the late chess master, one of the top players in the country, was above all without malice. In his personal dealings, his sense of humor was always on tap, and this was reflected in his behavior at the chessboard.

Eliahu Elath, president of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, said here last night that his university's various schools were engaged in more than 300 research projects commissioned by foreign governments and institutions -- "most of them American."
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 5 Two bank robbers were drawn into a gun duel here today with a depositor who took one of their revolvers. They dropped a valise containing $52,149 and fled.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) The New York Knickerbockers led all the way tonight in a National Basketball Association contest as they crushed the Chicago Zephyrs, 133 117, to snap a-five-game losing streak.

In his commencement address at Yale University last June, President Kennedy urged upon the nation "a serious dialogue of the kind which has led in Europe to such fruitful collaboration among all the elements of economic society and to a decade of unrivaled economic progress."

BERLIN, Dec. 5 Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, said in a speech made public today that his regime was now ready to agree to compromise on Berlin and Germany. He said that he considered a German peace treaty part of a "longterm policy program" adopted by his Government.
A representative of the State Society of Pathologists charged yesterday that the City Health Department had given the public an inaccurate picture of the operations of private clinical laboratories.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 5 (AP) The surprising Mexican Davis Cup team completed a 5 0 sweep of India today by winning the two final singles matches. The team there prepared to leave for Australia to challenge for the big international tennis trophy at Brisbane on Dec. 26-28.
MONROE, N.Y., Dec. 5 (AP) The co-owner of a Long Island dairy company was wounded early today by two shotgun blasts fired from a car that had pulled alongside a tank truck he was driving.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 5 (AP) Senator Joe H. Bottum, a Republican, conceded today the election of George S. McGovern, Democrat, to the United States Senate.
Federal mediators intervened yesterday in the dispute between nine major newspapers and their printers, citing "the public interest" in seeking to avert a possible city wide shutdown.

THERE never was much limit to the varied talents of Jimmy Conzelman. Over the course of the years he has been professional football player, author, boxer, sculptor, football coach, song writer, football magnate, actor, baseball executive, piano entertainer, newspaper publisher, radio commentator, advertising vice president, band leader and one of the wittier afterdinner speakers.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 5 An unwanted schoolhouse of classical Greco-Roman design here has been converted into a modern split-level City Hall.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 5--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru flew to northeastern India today for a look at an area considered highly vulnerable to Chinese Communist aggression. He consulted with top military leaders at Tezpur, headquarters of the Indian Army corps that is responsible for northeastern defenses.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 5 (AP) A Federal judge held today that the use of United States funds in construction of a hospital did not obligate the hospital to operate on a racially integrated basis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 The General Assembly's Economic Committee unanimously approved today a joint declaration by the United States and the Soviet Union urging nations to plan for economic and social adjustments that would follow world disarmament.

Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy asserted here yesterday that American students planning to travel abroad without adequate knowledge of the United States would be doing this country a favor if they "stayed in bed at home."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) Through an out-of-court settlement the four children adopted by the late Muriel McCormick Hubbard, heiress to a farm machinery fortune, will receive 30 per cent of a $7,000,000 trust fund.
Theodore W. Kheel ruled yesterday that the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines was still responsible for pension payments to more than 800 retired employes even though the city had taken over its buses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 28:

HAVANA, Dec. 5 The Cuban Government nationalized privately owned retail and wholesale stores dealing in clothing, shoes and hardware today. The action, from which some stores were exempted, was regarded as a first step toward the imposition of rationing.

BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 5 (UPI) Quigg Newton, president of the University of Colorado, an increasingly controversial figure during the six years of his administration, said today he was resigning to become president of the Commonwealth Fund in New York.
The city's Commission on Human Rights was directed by Mayor Wagner yesterday to survey the ethnic composition of personnel in the Civil Service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today the local "sky bus" fares that United Air Lines plans to introduce between Cleveland and Miami, Cleveland and Pittsburgh and Miami and Pittsburgh on Friday.

Associated Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court last night received the Audubon Medal, the highest honor of the National Audubon Society, for distinguished service in conservation.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 5 (AP) Allegations of corruption in the Syracuse Police Department were made today at a public hearing.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 5 The Rev. and Mrs. Aaron J. Caplow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Caplow, to Henry David Michelman.
Governor Rockefeller signified yesterday that he was agreeing to Robert Moses' decision to give up his five state parks and power posts.
ALGIERS, Dec. 5--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella's "socialist" domestic policy ran into sharp criticism in the National Assembly today. Speakers called for broader measures to ease Algeria's economic crisis.
Bob Melvin led the Fordham basketball team to a 73-54 victory over Yale at the Rose Hill gymnasium last night.

SKI-JUMPING enthusiasts who had been mourning the loss of Lake Placid's annual tournaments on New Year's Day and Washington's Birthday can dig out their stadium boots and earmuffs. The events are on again.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5--Portugal criticized the United Nations today for not having branded as aggression the "warlike and subversive preparations" he said were under way against. Portugal in some African countries.

The names of the 103 young women who will be presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the WaldorfAstoria on Dec. 21 have been announced by Mrs. Eugene W. Ong and Mrs. Eben W. Pyne, co-chairmen for the 27th annual event.

Immediately after his election to a full term, Secretary General Thant is now tackling a problem that threatens the effectiveness and even existence of the United Nations. This is the problem of how to finance the most important functions entrusted to the United Nations by the Charter: its peace-keeping operations, as in the Middle East and the Congo.
The president of the Ford Motor Company called yesterday for "an industrial national guard" to insure the swift conversion of peacetime heavy industry to war production.
PARIS, Dec. 5 The six nations of the European Economic Community set the stage today for a potentially crucial clash in the negotiations for Britain's entry.
