THE snow had been blowing out of the north for long, gray hours on winds that had glanced off the Laurentides before keening into northern New England. It was none of the biting fury of a whipped blizzard; rather the steady whirl of billows relentlessly building up depths of light flakes.
LONDON, Dec. 5 The House of Commons, for the fifth time in the last 100 years, upheld today the right of the Lord Chamberlain to act as theatrical censor.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI) Most grain futures rallied for small gains late today on the Board of Trade.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) Billy Hoy scored 26 points and led St. Joseph's College to a 70-64 victory over Hofstra College in the opener of a college basketball doubleheader at the Palestra tonight.
WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 6 The final scenes of "I Was a Teen-Age Mummy" are being filmed in the basement of the Eugene Skinner home on Cross Highway here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The chairman of the House subcommittee on Africa, speaking at the urging of the State Department, said today that Senator Allen J. Ellender "has hurt us very much" by remarks about Africa attributed to him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy asked the Subversive Activities Control Board today to order three men and one woman to register as members of the Communist party.

The promoters of a restaurant corporation that used the name of Veronica Lake, the movie actress, to aid an allegedly fraudulent attempt to sell stock, have been ordered to show cause Tuesday why they should not be barred from the securities business in the state.
With one dissent, religious groups in the United States representing the three branches of Judaism approved yesterday the Israeli High Court of Justice's decision on Brother Daniel.

Adrian Van Sinderen, active in the American Horse Shows Association for 30 years, retired as the organization's chairman of the board of directors last night. The action was taken at a meeting of the board in the Union Club.
MANILA, Dec. 6 (AP) The unbeaten United States team scored its third victory today in an invitation basketball tournament here. The Americans routed Australia, 94 57.

New York University's basketball team, ready for its opening game against Georgetown in the second game of a Madison Square Garden double-header tonight, yesterday lost its leading scorer and rebounder.
The Joint Distribution Committee, an American agency that provides relief for needy Jews over the world, adopted a 1963 budget of $30,769,000 yesterday.
CARMICHAELS, Pa., Dec. 6 A coal mine explosion trapped 36 men some 650 feet underground today, and rescue crews struggled desperately to reach them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (UPI) The Carnation Company of Los Angeles, an evaporated milk manufacturer, filed a $1,029,828 antitrust damage suit today against water carriers to the Far East.

Sixty-eight per cent of a cross section of business and industrial leaders attending the annual congres of the National Association of Manufacturers believe that sales will be better in 1963 than in 1962.

Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who was dismissed as director of 20th Century-Fox's "Cleopatra" after a dispute with Darryl F. Zanuck about editing the $35,000,000 movie, confirmed yesterday that he will probably rejoin the production.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 The right of St. John's University to dismiss three students for having taken part in a civil marriage ceremony was upheld today by the New York Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Occasionally international discussions are as "full and frank" as the communiques always say they have been. This week's conference between United States and Japanese cabinet officials appears to have been one of those occasions, with the emphasis on "frank."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Federal Reserve Board approved today the formation of a new bank holding company United Virginia Bankshares, Inc. that world combine six banks in various parts of the state.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 6 (AP) Painter, a 7-year-old stallion by Tar Heel-Pretty Hanover, sold for a world record price of $130,000 yesterday at the closing session of the fall standardbred horse sales at Tattersalls.

HOUSEWIVES might do well to count their chickens this weekend and, if the freezer is not filled to capacity, supplement their number from the bargains currently offered at many stores. It is a while now since broilers and fryers have been so widely available at the modest price of 25 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Five career Federal employes received today $5,000 awards for distinguished public service.
The State Labor Department was urged yesterday to renew its attempt to obtain legislation providing for state licensing of employment agencies that recruit out-of-state domestic workers.

Educators and promoters, philanthropists and Jersey City officials all interested in acquiring title to Ellis Island argued yesterday before a Congressional hearing on the disposal of the 27-acre tract in New York Harbor.
OFTEN in a work of art length is not only necessary, but it is a factor contributing to a work's success; certainly to making the effect the artist wanted.

BONN, Dec. 6 Informed political sources said tonight that they expected the outline of an agreement for a new coalition government to emerge from a meeting tomorrow between Chancellor Adenauer and leaders of the Free Democratic party.
Glickman Corporation, a publicly owned real estate concern, sought yesterday to reassure investors that it was not involved in any financial problem of its founder, Louis J. Glickman.

The 788 River Drive Company has sold the 11-story apartment building at 788 Riverside Drive, corner of 156th Street, to Mardave Management, Inc., for investment. The house is on a plot 100 by 106 feet and contains 66 apartments.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 6 Stop Post! That promises to be the war cry of Nassau County's another college basketball powers Hofstra, Adelphi and Kings Point when the season gets into full swing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Kennedy Administration has decided that the Air Force does not need the Skybolt ballistic missile as a strategic weapon. The Air Force disagrees. Thus another major public controversy over a military weapon is in prospect.

LONDON, Dec. 6 Britain has told the European Economic Community that if she is prevented from joining by French and German refusals to compromise, all her military commitments to defense of the Continent will have to be reviewed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Howard Johnson restaurant chain told its employes today that its policy was to serve all persons, without racial discrimination.
Constant Huntington, former chairman of Putnam Co., Ltd., book publishers of London, died Tuesday in his home there. He was 86 years old.

Columbia's basketball five exhibited poise, speed and cohesion in a four-minute spurt at the end of the first half last night, scoring 17 points in that span en route to a 78-67 victory over Colgate at University Hall.

MAKING "little prune people" (pflaume maennchen) has been a part of the holiday tradition in southern Germany for centuries. Legend has it that they will bring good luck and an abundant harvest in the year ahead.

Class A stock of the Inland Credit Corporation was barred from opening on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the exchange sought "clarification" of a company announcement late Wednesday that it had suffered "possible fraud" losses.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (UPI) New York State's revenue from pari-mutuel betting this year included $424,522 in uncashed winning tickets from the 1961 season.

TAM HUNG DONG, Vietnam, Dec. 6 Vietnamese ground forces struck at a series of hamlets on the Camau peninsula today, but the killing was done from the air. The operation, a mixture of success in the air and frustration on the ground, showed how fleet...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) Dr. Barr and Dr. Tjio, two of the scientists honored here today, never worked on mental retardation. But their discoveries about chromosomes led Dr. Lejeune to his discovery about mongolism.
HONOLULU, Dec. 6 Dr. Joseph F.C. Rock, a Hawaiian botanist and an authority on western Chinese tribes, died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 6 The Government announced today that it was closing its consulates in Communist China and had ordered the Chinese to close theirs in India.

IN the International League playoffs of 1945 the versatile Red Kress of Baltimore was pitching a no-hit, no-run game against Montreal into the ninth inning. The first hit he yielded was followed by an error and he lost, 1 to 0. Being balked just short of greatness was virtually the story of the redhead's life. That life ended abruptly not long ago when a heart attack felled him at the age of 55.
THERE are many different opinions as to what con stitutes an opening bid, but most experts are willing to reduce the high-card requirements somewhat with a hand that contains a six-card major suit.
TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Sandys Bao have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bette Bao, to Winston Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald B. Lord of New York and Stamford, Conn.

MOUND CITY, S.D., Dec. 6 (UPI) Farmers of this tiny county seat community said today they had flatly rejected a Government "peace plan" to recover Federal farm records held for more than six months in a barricaded building.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 Brazil's banking system was paralyzed today by a national strike of its employes.

The task of achieving national goals of security, prosperity and wellbeing of all is too big a job for the Federal Government, the chief elective officer of the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) Chairman Weight Patman today urged the HouseSenate Economic Committee to make public a controversial report on operations of the powerful Federal Open Market Committee.
The $4,000,000 Marathon Oil Company account is leaving N.W. Ayer Son, Inc.

Events today: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Sir John Barbirolli, conductor, Aldo Parisot, cellist, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15; Daniel Ericourt, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Beveridge Webster, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Virgilio Dueno, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Adela Marshall, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

SANTA CLAUS, who is in town to find out what the children want for Christmas, has released a preliminary report on his research to date. It shows that many of today's youngsters yearn for the same kinds of things that their parents did.

The forced resignation of Argentina's Economic Minister Alsogaray signals still another and possibly dangerous crisis in the country's internal affairs. In a sense there has been an unsettled crisis ever since President Frondizi was overthrown last March.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 Delegates from African, Asian and Soviet-bloc nations accused the "NATO powers" today of helping Portugal to suppress independence movements in Angola.
The State Liquor Authority held up approval yesterday of a restaurant liquor license for the Playboy Club, which plans to open here tomorrow night.

BONN, Dec. 6 For many Germans there is a sad note in the political turbulence shaking Bonn these days. It is what these Germans consider the personal tragedy of Chancellor Adenauer's stubborn, sometimes seemingly desperate effort to...
The United Seamen's Service honored William Francis Gibbs, naval architect and marine engineer, last night at the agency's 20th anniversary dinner meeting on the superliner United States.
LONDON, Dec. 6 British officials rejected with vigor and sorrow today what they regarded as an attack on their country yesterday by Dean Acheson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Republican National Committee set in train here today what it hopes will be a more successful campaign in 1964 than the ones just past.

The family and community programs of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center will be the beneficiary of a preview performance on the evening of Dec. 26 of "Oliver!". The musical opens the next night at the Imperial Theater.

A "slightly censored" edition of the Folies Berg re, with more than 50 dancing and strutting girls from France, will be one of many attractions of the $10,000,000 French Pavilion at the 1964 New York World's Fair.
The city's nine major newspapers face a dual strike threat that may shut them down after midnight tonight. Further negotiation efforts with the aid of Federal mediators will be undertaken today.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 6--Dr. Walter Hallstein of the European Economic Community warned American farmers today not to look for greatly expanded sales in the community.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Civil rights groups announced today a new drive to change the rules of the Senate and House and pave the way for rights legislation.

Carnegie Hall is still flourishing. Rescued from oblivion two years ago and faced with a new competitor since the emergence last September of Philharmonic Hall, Carnegie is currently enjoying a busy season and looking confidently to the future.

The Canadian dollar made a strong showing in foreign exchange dealings yesterday. The dollar closed at 93 cents offered, its high for the day, compared with its Wednesday closing price of 92.969 cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Dr. John P. Hagen, director of the first United States space program, Project Vanguard, is leaving the Feder al Government after almost three decades.
SOME of today's best buys in carpets and furniture come from studio sets used in television shows and commercials.

Samuel Knepper has purchased for investment the leasehold on the L-shaped business property surrounding the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 48th Street, in the Times Square area. The leasehold is for 17 years at a rental of $14,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The House Committee on Un-American Activities has scheduled public hearings next week on alleged efforts by the Communist party to infiltrate non-Communist peace organizations.
Six persons were sentenced to prison terms yesterday for defrauding the public of $750,000 in the sale of unregistered stock.

The statistical profile of the recent stock market makes a pretty picture. From the close of trading on Oct. 23 the day after President Kennedy's strong speech on Cuba through Nov. 30 the rise in stock prices has added $50,000000,000 in value on the New York Stock, Exchange.

Four of the world's greatest violinists will honor the memory of a late colleague at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, Dec. 26. Nathan Milstein, Erica Morini, Ziho Francescatti and Isaac Stern will make a joint appearance at a memorial concert to Fritz Kreisler for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Supreme Court was asked today to reconsider its decisions giving Congressional committees broad power to make witnesses answer questions about Communism.
A union attempt to bar white-collar steamship company employes from doing the work of striking longshoremen was struck down yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

J. Truman Bidwell, former chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, went on trial in Federal Court yesterday for the second time on income tax evasion charges. His first trial ended in a hung jury.

THE boating scene turned up a riddle the other day designed to test even an expert in such grade-school sticklers as what is big, red and eats rocks. This one has nothing to do with a Big Red Rock Eater. It concerns power and sail: What is 26 feet long, carries 150 square feet...

IT was Rostand's turn last night to enter the television compression chamber. The extravagance and exuberance of "Cyrano de Bergerac," the richness of its language, its wit and its grand style, were given the cathode purge. Out of a joyous and poignant classic was made a humorless soap opera in costume.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 6 (UPI) The windows and transom of the courtroom where James R. Hoffa is on trial were sealed off with newspapers today while the Government argued a motion in secret.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) The Government said today that Palmer, Alaska, was still getting a "warning level" amount of radioactive iodine from the Soviet Union's latest nuclear tests, but that the fallout shower was thinning over most United-States cities.
Stock prices eased yesterday as volume slackened. An afternoon advance blunted declines earlier in the day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) The Administration is considering asking Congress to expand and liberalize the $451,000,000 area redevelopment program.

If anything perturbs the otherwise serene disposition of Lionel Bart, the young English creator of "Oliver!" who is here for the Show's Broadway opening on Dec. 27, it is any attempt to classify him as a writer.
The Book-of-the-Month Club yesterday announced it would award $56,500 to libraries in 48 states for the purchase of books.

A frugal acquaintance tells this terrible story. His wife, after many years of steadfastly ignoring the subject, became interested in shooting. She found she liked it almost as much as knitting and frozen daiquiris.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 6 Israel's High Court of Justice ruled today that a Jew who "converts to Christianity is not called a Jew" under the Law of Return. The law recognizes the right of every Jew to settle in Israel.

THE village of Sidi-Bou-Said, once a suburb of Carthage, is now a suburb of Tunis. "As you drive out from Tunis, you see the town surging up the hillside to break on the cliff's edge like a wave of the sea, the houses white as foam, the minaret and lighthouse hanging in the air like the highest drops of spray."
The Federal Aviation Agency has expanded its study of three possible sites for a fourth major airport in the New York metropolitan region.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (AP) The total amount bet at horse racing tracks in New York State reached a record sum of $1,127,023,764 this year, the State Tax Department reported today.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a manufacturer of mining and other industrial equipment, said yesterday it was holding merger conversations with two coal mining machinery companies and an electric machine company as part of an expansion program into related fields.

There was some superb ensemble playing by the Loewenguth Quartet in Town Hall last night. The French group is made up of Alfred Loewenguth and Jacques Gotkovsky, violinists; Roger Roche, violinist, and Roger Loewenguth (the leader's brother), cellist. And they played like a single artist.

Dr. Israel S. Wechsler, a former president of the American Neurological Association and the American Friends of Hebrew University, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He had served the hospital since 1917, as staff physician, teacher and, ...

Seven college football players were chosen yesterday for both The Associated Press and United Press International allAmerica teams. These seven seniors also were chosen for the American Football Coaches Association team last week.

Governor Rockefeller's address on the nation's economy before the National Association of Manufacturers was clearly designed to present an alternative to the Administration's policies with 1964 in mind.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP) A heavy snow blanketed the infield at Pimlico today and caused the feature race to be transferred from the greensward to the dirt track. There, the snow melted.
Forty-six Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish clergymen and educators urged the Soviet Government yesterday in a cablegram "to lift its official policy of oppression against its Jewish citizens."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Probably it was just luck, but maybe it was that sixth sense called "a nose for the news," which was responsible for the unplanned encounter of this department today with one of the many reporters who were given a fill-in of the secret...
Independent importers of heavy residual fuel oil fear that the hopes of independent tanker operators for a sharp rise in freight rates may be realized in the next two months.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivered a speech here last night about what he called "a major American industry speechmaking."
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) A member of the Illinois Public Aid Commission, who had failed to block the state's new birth control program, resigned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Soviet troops in Cuba were reported today to be engaged in the construction of underground fortifications and additional airfields throughout the island in an apparent effort to bolster Premier Fidel Castro's defenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson has provoked a debate that was far different from the one he hoped to stimulate with a major speech at West Point, N.Y., yesterday.

A 15-year-old boy who received psychiatric treatment two years ago was held without bail yesterday on a charge that he threw 9-year-old Lourdes Bass to her death Tuesday from a 14th-floor roof in Brooklyn.
THE only thing vastly wrong, with "Jumbo," which arrived at the Music Hall yesterday, along with the Christmas stage show, is that it is hitting the screen about 25 years late.

If there is a criticism of George Mira, the University of Miami's know-all, do-all quarterback, it is that he throws a football too hard. That has been the only charge against the young man from Key West, Fla., who, though a junior, already...
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 The wrangling of military leaders kept Argentina in a state of tension tonight.

GENEVA, Dec. 6 The International Commission of Jurists said today that the Spanish Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco has shed some of its "Fascist trappings" without abandoning "the intolerance and subjugation of all opposition which characterize a totalitarian system."
Public-links tournament golfers received a word of encouragement yesterday from the Metropolitan Golf Association. Many more of them were made eligible for the organization's amateur championship.
ROME, Dec. 6 The Ecumenical will try to speed up its activities when it reconvenes next Sept. 8.

When a nation's security is threatened, as that of the United States was during the recent Cuban crisis, that nation's leaders are justified in telling lies to its people, Arthur Sylvester, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, told a press gathering here last night.

THREE aging rebels or, as the program called them, iconoclasts were at Carnegie Recital Hall last night to hear some of their music played. The Grand Old Man was Edgard Var se, now 77. Henry Cowell is 65 and Stefan Wolpe 60.
HARTFORD, Dec. 6 Graeme Keith Howard of Roughland, Norfolk, Conn., a former executive of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, died today at Hartford Hospital. His age was 66.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 A Government committee is finding the hazards of pesticides very difficult to assess.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 President Kennedy let Adlai E. Stevenson get all the laughs when they shared a public platform here tonight.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 6 Following, in translation, are excerpts from the ruling and the dissent by the Israeli High Court of Justice on the application by Oswald Rufeisen, now known as Brother Daniel, to be recognized as a Jew of Christian faith.
The State Education Department took a step yeseterday toward giving college credits through proficiency examinations.
Future Walker Cup golf competition will be based on 18-hole matches instead of 36, the United States Golf Association said yesterday.
Government securities rose yesterday in a more active market. Corporates remained stalled. State and municipal obligations moved in fair volume out of syndicate.

Dreams of belated glory inspired second-stringers on the New York Giants to huff and puff a little harder yesterday during the National Football League club's workout in the Fordham University gymnasium.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 6 (UPI) J. Haden Alldredge, former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, who fought for equitable freight rates for the South, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 6 (AP) A district attorney's stenographer said today she had received a telephoned threat against the life of her husband, a police officer, who testified at a hearing on police corruption.
United States immigration officials told the New York representative of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga yesterday that he must leave the country voluntarily within 15 days or face deportation.

ALGIERS, Dec. 6 Mohammed Khider, chief of Algeria's ruling National Liberation Front, has promised that the coming "purification" of the Government bureaucracy inherited from the French will not be a political purge.
The Mayor's Committee on Job Advancement is asking the nation's leading industries and advertising agencies to correct a "distorted" picture of the American scene.
A selective list of New York restaurants appears every Friday on this page.
Managers of money positions at the big New York City commercial banks are trying to explain what happened in the final hour or so on Wednesday.
Importers charged yesterday that the Department of Defense had made substantial informal increases in its procurement restrictions on imported materials and equipment.
A move toward taxing revenue-producing installations of the Port of New York Authority developed within the City Council yesterday.
LONDON, Dec, 6 The death toll in Britain's worst fog in a decade has reached 67 in London, where conditions today were the most serious in three days.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 (AP) The composition of the Connecticut General Assembly is being attacked in a Federal district court suit.
Striking city drivers voted yesterday to end their 10-day walkout and return to work today.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 6 Officials pointed out today that Mr. Struelens's visa had been canceled 14 months ago and that he had remained in the country since then "at the tolerance" of the United States Government.
New York County Democrats nominated Maurice J. O'Rourke by a 3-to-1 margin last night as the Manhattan Democratic Commissioner on the Board of Elections.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 (AP) The Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company, reported today record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

ALL were, and some still are, painters. Yet Picasso did it. Braque did it. Matisse did it. Even Delaunay did it. And if you pay a visit to the Leonard Hutton Galleries, 41 East 57th Street, you can see that Andr Derain did it too. Did what? Made sculpture.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 Israel accused Arab representatives today of cooperating with neo-Nazi and fascist groups in the United States, Latin America and elsewhere "to exploit anti-Semitism as a political weapon."
TRENTON, Dec. 6 Gov. Richard J. Hughes has asked the Legislature to reconvene on Monday to act on his highway safety program.
The Board of Estimate postponed final action on the proposed $100,000,000 Lower Manhatten Expressway last night after a sometimes-stormy sixhour public hearing.

OXFORD, Miss., Dec. 6 (AP) In its first public statement since the bloody riot over a Negro student, the University of Missisippi faculty today praised the controversial editor of the school newspaper and asked the school to fight a court order that an expelled student be reinstated.
Gusts of up to 45 miles an hour buffeted the rain-soaked city yesterday between 11 A.M. and 2 P.M., shattering windows and spinning an airliner parked at an Idlewild Airport passenger gate.

The producers of the "Festival of Performing Arts," which is supposed to resume on television on Jan. 15 or 22, are continuing to tape one-hour programs. But the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the sponsor, still has not arranged for stations here and in Washington to carry the programs.

Myron I. Borg Jr., a member of Hamershlag, Borg Co., stockbrokers at 25 Broad Street, died yesterday in New York University Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived on Skyview Drive in Stamford, Conn.
Three off-duty policemen broke up a Harlem bank burglary early yesterday and arrested two men after one of them had fired a shot. No one was injured.
A strong move to institute classification of motion pictures by legislation was made in Washington yesterday by a committee of Romam Catholic bishops.
INDIA'S new Defense Minister, Yeshwantrao Bal wantrao Chavan, is almost the complete opposite of his predecessor, V.K. Krishna Menon.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 6 (AP) The head of the International Air Transport Association said today that civil aviation needed a better safety record more than a supersonic transport.
Certified public accountants are asking the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to delay for a short time enforcement of the new expense account recordkeeping requirements.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 Premier Khrushchev and President Tito discussed today the possibility of closing the 14-year-old breach between the Soviet and Yugoslav Communist parties.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec, 6 A Three Century Christmas House Tour, showing homes decorated in Colonial, Victorian and contemporary holiday style, will be conducted by the Stamford Garden Club on Tuesday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.

THE looms of craftsmen throughout the Middle West are now concentrating on exotic and elegant wall hangings and curtain fabrics, to judge by an exhibition that opens today at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53d Street.

DUBLIN. DEPRESSED by the prospect of losing a splendid row of Georgian houses in Lower Fitzwilliam Street, Eoin O'Mahony took direct action one afternoon last week. He placed mourning wreaths on numbers 16 and 22, where distinguished Dubliners once lived.

William H. McKeon, the Democratic state chairman, challenged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to put his "own house in order" before criticizing the Kennedy Administration's handling of the national economy.
The board of governors ofo the American Stock Exchange voted yesterday to remove eight issues from the trading list effective at the market opening today.

HAZARD, Ky, Dec. 6 (UPI) Heavy snowfall in the eastern Kentucky coal fields curtailed picketing of nonunion mines by United Mine Workers union members today, but a group of pickets camped in the snow at near-by Leatherwood had state police worried about possible trouble tomorrow.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec.6--Premier Cyrille Adoula's Government faces a serious challenge in Parliament on its Katanga policy.
What may be the post-Cuba line of Soviet policy on Germany and Berlin has been outlined in a noteworthy speech by Walter Ulbricht, the Communist satrap who rules East Germany for the Russians.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 The General Assembly's Economic Committee adopted unanimously today a resolution requesting the Secretary General and varous international agencies to give high-priority assistance to governments requesting aid in land reform.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Rail and truck loadings for the week ended Dec. 1 were substantially above the preceding Thanksgiving Day holiday week. However, both were below the corresponding week in 1961.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6 (AP) Dr. Bernard D. Davis, noted for his researches into the complex growth-control mechanisms of living cells, was named tonight as the first Adele Lehman Professor in the Harvard University Faculty of Medicine.
A statement was issued yesterday by 20 scholars criticizing Senator Ellender for his remarks.
Elementary pupils of Public School 189 sat in awe yesterday as they watched an Asian dance troupe perform for them.

The National Committee of the Republican party is meeting in Washington this weekend for a look back at the campaign of 1962 and a look ahead to the campaign of 1964. One factor in the look both ways is the role of the party in the South.
World sugar futures advanced 7 to 13 points and cocoa futures fell 22 to 30 points in active trading yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 West Germany's Supreme Administrative Court has suggested to the Federal Government that it reconsider and withdraw its case against the West German Association of Victims of Nazism on constitutional grounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) President Kennedy has seen to it that the 13 days of the Cuban crisis are engraved, not only in memory but literally, for the 14-man group that helped him devise the strategy to meet it.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 6 A long-range pattern of stress and strain is gradually becoming evident on the Indian subcontinent as a result of Chinese Communist aggression.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The "Mona Lisa" will be shown in the United States, the French Embassy said today.

LISBON, Dec. 6 The foreigner is king in this capital of old-world courtesy, but none is quite so welcome in this balmy December as the Chinese. In fact, the Chinese may well be more popular here than in Albania, for Lisbon has become the capital of anti-Indian rancor.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 William S. Ginn, former vice president of the General Electric Company, said in a deposition released today that he and business competitors had destroyed all documents of price-fixing meetings in the electrical equipment industry.

Considering that Pace College's basketball team is traveling by ferry to the middle of New York's harbor Governors Island just to hold practices, the Setters' future certainly has taken a decided turn for the better.

THERE is a large envelope on a shelf in the house of Pablo Casals at Santurce, Puerto Rico. It is marked "Kennedy." The envelope contains correspondence on world affairs that Mr. Casals conducts with the President.

AN opossum may not be able to spell the word persimmon but he is every bit as familiar with the juicy goodness of that tomato-like fruit as its human fanciers. There is a saying in the South, where persimmon trees flourish, that if you find a 'simmon tree, you're bound to catch a possum close by.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) Syracuse and the University of California at Los Angeles wind up their football seasons against each other here tomorrow. Each needs a victory for a 5-5 won-lost record.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) Export buying helped most grain futures early today on the Board of Trade, but wheat and some rye contracts fell near the close.
The view, often asserted by network executives, that many writers who made their names on television are now too busy in lucrative fields elsewhere is a "legend," Dale Wasserman said yesterday.
CLOSE figuring entered into the play of the deal shown today. South's figuring was correct and he made his contract, West's was inadequate and he lost his chance to defeat the contract.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Dec. 7 King Hassan II appeared today to have won a substantial majority in a referendum on his proposal for a constitution for Morocco.
HARTFORD, Dec. 6 Graeme Keith Howard of Roughland, Norfolk, Conn., a former executive of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, died Thursday at Hartford Hospital. His age was 66.

VIENNA, Dec. 7 The Soviet bloc's denunciations of dissident Albania were intensified today when a Czechoslovak Communist party official accused Al banian leaders of "cold-blooded anti-Soviet subversion."

LONDON, Dec. 7 Miss Barbara Fell was sentenced to two years in jail today for having flown classified documents to a Yugoslav diplomat while she was a top official in the Government's information office.
The Treasury securities market continued its upward and active trend yesterday. Movement of municipal obligations out of syndicate quickened and corporate-debt issues were steady in brisk trading.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 (AP) Sigmund and Abraham Sommer, Metuchen real estate developers, have asked the New Jersey State Racing Commission for approval to buy Freehold Raceway.
Consolidated Edison has abandoned its plans to build a huge generating plant and fuel storage facility near Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

Ellis Island, carried by the Federal Government as surplus property for eight years, will remain abandoned and forlorn for the forseeable future, it was indicated yesterday at the end of a Congressional hearing here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) The new United States track and field federation charged today that the Amateur Athletic Union had repudiated a coalition agreement to try to provide the best Ameriran athletes for international competition. The federation said it would proceed full speed with its own program of events.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 In Guatemala City, the telephone directory has long been an anachronism. Street numbers and call numbers still correspond, but the majority of names of subscribers do not.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 Hudson County, although its population has declined consistently for the last 32 years, will have jobs for 8,000 clerical workers, 1,000 sales people and at least 7,200 craftsmen by 1966.

American Airlines charged yesterday that antitrust concepts applicable to unregulated industry had erroneously been applied to the airline business, a regulated industry, in judging the proposed merger of American and Eastern Air Lines.

One thing was certain as the 29th consecutive college basketball season began at Madison Square Garden last night. Never had a team moved into the Eighth Avenue arena as undermanned as the Violets of New York University were for their season's opener against the Hoyas of Georgetown.

LONDON, Dec. 7 Any United States decision to abandon the Skybolt ballistic missile would cause widespread "despondency" in the British Government and harm the relations between the two Governments, qualified sources said here tonight.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI) A formula for joint Government and private participation in developing the orerich Guayana region of Venezuela was outlined today by Harry Jones, Director of Latin American affairs for Westinghouse International.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) Bobo Newsom, a big righthanded pitcher who spent 24 years in the major leagues, died today in an Orlando hospital of a liver ailment. He was 55 years old.
A reversal in the personal fortunes of Louis J. Glickman, a prominent real estate syndicator, yesterday brought tremors to the New York real estate world.
Dame Margot Fonteyn will dance in Washington next week when the American Bellet Theater gives its first performances there as a resident company.
A $165,000,000 plan to redevelop the City Hall-Foley Square area into a 60-acre government park focused on City Hall was announced yesterday.

NEW YORK. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange gave ground in the late trading today and final prices were irregularly lower for the session. Changes were confined largely to fractions, except in the more volatile issues.

NEW YORK. Usually the defenders against a no-trump contract should stick to their longest suit and try to establish it, but in today's deal they found the successful finesse by shifting suits on every one of the early tricks.

NEW YORK. The Ling-Temco Vought Inc., directors have approved a plan to refund part of the Dallas company's long-term debt, Robert McCulloch, chairman, has announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25-- This is the merriest Christmas Washington has seen since the war. There is a buoyancy in the air that has not existed here since the beginning of the great struggle with the Communist world.

NEW YORK. Thousands of New Yorkers are streaming into the City Center daily just to see "The Nutcracker." Britain's holdovers from colonial days still fill positions of importance and often make vital decisions. The nature of the ad-- ministration, despite titular alterations, has also remained largely constant.

The vote favored the repeal of the parliamentary system instituted in September 1961, when Joao Goulart succeeded President Janio Quardros, who resigned.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan, 7--Governor Edmund G. Brown today promised California four years of "bold, controversial leadership." The second Democrat to hold the state's highest office in twenitieth century California began his second term with an invitaition to, and in the acknowledged expectation of, disagreement, "not for its own sake, but for the health of the commonwealth."

NEW YORK. There is a deep chasm be tween the musical, "Oliver," and Charles Dicken's novel, "Oliver Twist." It is as wide as the distance between a nineteenth-century novelist of genius with a burning social conscience and a musical geared to modern show business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP ) --The Bureau of Mines estimated today that the nation's 1962 mineral output had a record value of $18,730,000,000. This represents an increase of nearly $600,000,000 from the previous high of 1961.

Enough time has passed since the sudden crisis in Senegal to bring reassurance. On Dec. 17 Premier Mamadou Dia was overthrown by a parliamentary motion of censure. When he attempted a coup, President Leopold Senghor rallied his troops and arrested Mr. Dia and four or five of his followers. The National Assembly gave President Senghor emergency powers and all has been calm since.

With the new Congress about to convene, the lobbyists are gathering in Washington. NEW YORK. A mass of subfreezing air, backed by gusty winds, spread over the Northeast yesterday and gave New York its coldest day of the new year and lowest reading since Feb. 2, 1961.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8-- Lawyers for Gov. Ross Barnett and Lieut. Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. of Mississippi pleaded today for a jury trial on the criminal contempt charges against them.
NEW YORK. A few weeks ago Leon ard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic investigated Leos Janacek's "Slavonic Mass," a work that has had very few local performances.
BONN, Feb. 8--Ann uneasy Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, forced Chancellor Adenauer yesterday into a firm reaffimnation of his 12-year-old policy of European union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The United States suspended today more than $3,000,000 of economic aid to Ceylon. The Agency for International Development said that the Ceylonese Government had failed to offer "adequate" compensation ...
MOSCOW, Feb. 8--A Russian writer once known for "formalist" tendencies, who later turned to greater conformism, has been honored with one of Soviet Union's highest civilian awards.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 8--Nicolas Reisini, president of Cinerama, Inc., asserted today that the assumption of a $15,000,000 loan by a major theater owner did not presage a struggle for control for Cinerama.
Before the start of the last round of the annual Hastings Christmas Congress, a delicate situation existed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz said today there were too many signs that the country was getting used to excessive unemployment.

BERLIN, Feb. 8--Walter Ulbricht dashed hopes tonight for a settlement under which West Berliners could gain permission to visit friends and relatives cut off in East Berlin since Aug. 13, 1961, by the Communist-built wall.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8, (AP)--The executive board of the International Olympic Committee drew up a charter today designed to bar any country guilty of discrimination against foreign athletes for political, racial or religious reasons.

NEW YORK. No state-maker in American history has matched the reputation Sam Houston enjoys. That the name of this irrepressible Texan continues to glisten is owing not only to his charismatic leadership and the solidity of his work but also to the dedication of his biographers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, jolted the banking industry recently by breaking a time-honored tradition.
NEW YORK. The Iraqi regime of General Kassim, which was overthrown yesterday, was itself founded through a bloody revolution on July 14, 1958.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- The Government is expected to issue the final rules for making measles vaccine soon, clearing the way for their licensing perhaps by mid-March.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Phoenix of Republican political hopes was rising this week from the ashes of the 1962 election. The voice of Rockefeller was heard in the land and on Capitol Hill, those ancient legislative mariners, Ev and Charlie, were feeling the heat from zealous underlings anxious for the fray.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Alliance for Progress in its present form, it has now become clear, is not going to accomplish the task that was set for it. This fact is an indication of the increasing problems that confront us to the south.

In a West German cultural bulletin there appeared several days ago a startling statistic. During 1962 Max Frisch's "Andorra" racked up more performances in West Germany than any play except one by Goethe, one of the German immortals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Key Federal financial officials are finding that some lending instistitutions may be tempted to make unsound loans.

The Soviet Union accounts for only little more than half of all Communist bloc industrial production, a study by Czechoslovak economists indicates. This is a smaller margin of Soviet superiority over the rest of the bloc than any other partial data available in the past has indicated.

Although no major records were broken, for a change, track and field continued to make exciting news over the weekend. The principal developments were at the Los Angeles Times meet, which produced a series of upsets that staggered a capacity crowd of 13,459 in the Sport Arena.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 10 The positions of India and Pakistan in the Kashmir dispute "appear at the moment to be irreconcilable," the chief Pakistani negotiator said tonight. The two countries "must move closer together or there is not much use going on" with the current discussions, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan declared.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--A surging spirit of bi-partisanship so intoxicated Governor Rockefeller on a visit to the capital this week that he provided free long-distance transportation for three New York City Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-- One of the great moments of history took place the other day when the Mona Lisa passed Whistler's Mother on the Jersey Turnpike. The old lady was on her way down to Atlanta, and the young woman was going up to New York, both by courtesy of President De Gaulle.
Mayor Wagner continued yesterday his efforts to persuade the city's nine major newspapers and their printers to end the press trike now in its 66th day.
PITTSBURGH Feb. 3--Tension seemed to be mounting in the steel market last week.
LONDON, Feb. 10--Brig. Gen. Alfred Cecil Critchley, who excelled in sports, war and business, died at his Surrey home yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 10--For Frenchmen and for statesmen in many foreign chancelleries a question of mounting importance is: Will de Gaulle quit as President of France when he finishes his term three years from now? The answer to this question is a conditional yes.

The Arab world is being shaken by another revolution. Premier Kassim of Iraq, who massacred King Feisal and his pro-Western regime in 1958, has himself been overthrown by the younger military men who helped him to power and has been executed by a firing squad, together with his principal lieutenants. A new Government has been installed, but the real power seems to rest in a military junta.
LONDON, Feb. 10--John Henry Taylor, Britain's grand old man of golf, five times British Open champion, died at Northam, Devonshire today. He was 91 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9-- Canada is the second largest nation in the world, but with a mere 18,000,000 inhabitants. Virtually every Canadian knows this and hardly any American does--and therein lies the fundamental and continuing problem of their relations.
